In early 2015, public opinion regarding the government's effectiveness in reducing terrorist threats was more positive than it is currently [9].  Specifically, a survey conducted at the beginning of 2015 indicated that a substantial percentage of Americans felt the government was performing well in this area [10].  ![This image shows the legend of political affiliations: Independent, Republican, and Democrat, suggesting the following data will be broken down by these groups.](image1)  Among Democrats, this positive sentiment was particularly strong, with a large majority expressing approval [9].  For Republicans, while still a majority, the approval rate was somewhat lower than that of Democrats [9].  It's important to note that views on terrorism and related issues often differ across political lines, as illustrated in various polls and surveys ![This image shows that terrorist threat is a more important issue for Republicans compared to Democrats.](image5).

In 2015, 72% of surveyed adults, 63% of Republicans, and 85% of Democrats believed that the government was doing very/fairly well in reducing the threat of terrorism.

Seniors with higher income exhibit a strong inclination towards online engagement, with a significant percentage actively participating in the digital world [3].  Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, a notable 90% access the internet ![90% of higher-income seniors go online](image4).  While smartphone adoption is less universal compared to general internet usage, it remains considerable within this demographic, with 42% of higher-income seniors owning smartphones ![42% of higher-income seniors have smartphones](image3).  Tablet computers are also a popular device among higher-income seniors, as evidenced by 39% ownership within this group ![39% of higher-income seniors own a tablet](image5).

The percentages of higher-income seniors who go online, have a smartphone, and own a tablet computer are [“90%”, “42%”, “39%”] in the Pew Research Center’s Internet Project July 18-September 30, 2013 tracking survey.

Ecosystem players are crucial for the growth and robustness of the digital commerce landscape [3, 7]. These players span across various categories essential for facilitating online business and consumer interactions.  For instance, marketplaces like Amazon and Snapdeal, alongside travel platforms such as MakeMyTrip and Cleartrip, represent significant segments within this ecosystem ![Illustrates marketplaces and travel platforms](image1).  Furthermore, the ecosystem encompasses vertical players focusing on specific sectors like fashion, exemplified by Myntra and Jabong, or eyewear through Lenskart, demonstrating the specialization within the market ![Shows vertical players in fashion, eyewear, baby products, health, jobs, transport, recharge, matchmaking, ticketing, real estate and local services](image1).

Beyond marketplaces and vertical specialists, the ecosystem also relies heavily on platforms that provide the technical backbone for e-commerce operations, payment solutions like PayU and CCAvenue for transaction processing, and robust logistics networks for delivery [2]. Financial institutions, including banks like HDFC and Citibank, and comparison platforms such as Smartprix and PriceBaba, are also integral, adding layers of financial and informational support to the ecosystem ![Depicts platforms, payments, banks, logistics, and comparison services](image2).  Moreover, the ecosystem extends to enterprise solutions, consulting services, and specialized tools like e-commerce software and data entry services, highlighting the diverse range of supporting functionalities [2] ![Shows enterprise solutions, consulting, photography, e-commerce software, data entry and servicing tools](image2).

There are sixteen types of ecosystem players explicitly listed in the provided slides.

Americans hold similar views regarding the Republican and Democratic parties when it comes to policy ideas and ethical standards [8].  When considering ethical standards, 41% of Americans believe the GOP has high ethical standards, and a near identical 42% think the same of the Democratic Party [4].  The Republican Party is seen as having good policy ideas by 50% of people, while the Democratic Party is also viewed similarly by 50% of people ![The Republican Party and the Democratic Party are equally perceived to have good policy ideas, with 50% of respondents agreeing for each, while slightly more people believe the Republican Party has high ethical standards (48%) compared to the Democratic Party (42%).](image2).  However, despite these perceptions of policy and ethics, only 22% of Republicans and Republican leaners reported following news about congressional elections in their state very closely ![A breakdown of news consumption about congressional elections by different demographics, showing that 22% of Republicans/Lean Republicans followed very closely.](image1).  Therefore, 22% of Republicans/Lean Republicans, the party holding the highest total percentage for good policy ideas and high ethical standards, followed news about congressional elections very closely.

In late 2014, the Indonesian telecom market was composed of several key players [1]. As visually summarized, these included major GSM operators like Telkomsel, XL Axiata, and Indosat, along with CDMA operators ![Operators in 2014 included GSM and CDMA providers](image1).  A more comprehensive overview of 2014 reveals a diverse ecosystem encompassing GSM, CDMA, LTE, and WiMAX operators [5]. Specifically, the GSM sector was served by Telkomsel, XL Axiata, Indosat, and 3, while CDMA operators included Smartfren, Telkom Flexi, Esia, and StarOne. Furthermore, Bolt 4G operated the LTE network, and both Bolt 4G and WiGO provided WiMAX services [5].  However, when focusing on the 2013-2014 period, discussions often revolved around the dominant GSM operators, namely Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat, particularly in relation to frequency spectrum concerns [2, 3]. These three were notably identified as entering a 'red zone' regarding frequency allocation [2, 6].  Therefore, when juxtaposing the operators specifically emphasized in the 2013-2014 timeframe against the broader spectrum of operators active in 2014, those not explicitly shared in common are the operators beyond these primary GSM entities.

The operators not in common are: ['3', 'Smartfren', 'Telkom Flexi', 'Esia', 'StarOne', 'Bolt 4G', 'WiGO'].

Americans have varying levels of trust in information from international organizations regarding the coronavirus outbreak.  Older adults, specifically those 65 and older, show a lower level of distrust in the World Health Organization (WHO), with only a small percentage expressing distrust ![Distrust in WHO information among people over 65 years old is 8%](image2). In contrast, when considering trust in the European Union (EU), while a large majority of postgraduates express trust, indicating a lower level of distrust, the percentage of postgraduates who distrust EU information is higher than the percentage of older adults who distrust WHO information [6].  Specifically, about 22% of postgraduates do not trust information from the EU, while only about 8% of people over 65 do not trust information from the WHO.

Therefore, there are 14 percentage points fewer people over 65 years old who do not trust information from the World Health Organization compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union.

Despite many holding a negative view on the ongoing military actions against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, as reflected by the sentiment that the effort is "not too well" or "not at all well" [1, 9], a contrasting perspective emerges regarding the anticipated success of the campaign.  While current assessments of the military effort remain unfavorable, there's an observable increase in the conviction that the U.S. and its allies will eventually achieve their objectives [4].  A considerable majority, specifically two-thirds, express confidence in the definite or probable success of the U.S.-led campaign against Islamic militants, marking an 11-point increase from July [2]. This indicates a more positive outlook on the ultimate outcome, even amidst concerns about the present progress [5].

![The public's belief in the success of the campaign increased from July to December 2015](image1)

![The public's view on how well the current military effort is going remains largely negative over time](image2)

Even though perceptions of the immediate progress of the military campaign were largely negative, a majority of people believed in late 2015 that the U.S. and its allies would ultimately succeed against ISIS.

Within the initial 90 minutes following the incident, Lufthansa acknowledged the situation via Twitter [3].  Subsequently, within 120 minutes, reflecting the gravity of the event, Lufthansa, mirroring its subsidiary Germanwings, adopted a black and white color scheme for its logo on social media platforms [6]. This adjustment on social media happened in a similar timeframe to Germanwings’ change [6]. Before this change to reflect the somber mood, the Lufthansa logo was in its standard colors as depicted in a general company representation ![Lufthansa standard logo in color](image2). This shift to monochrome was a visible representation of corporate sensitivity in response to the crisis.

Lufthansa's logo colors transitioned to black and white within 120 minutes following the incident.

In a survey conducted from April 25 to May 1, 2018, it was found that opinions on ethical standards are quite varied across different groups [2, image2]. While a considerable portion of the public believes that at least one of the major parties has high ethical standards, a notable segment thinks neither party does [2].  Interestingly, this view is more pronounced among those with higher education [3, 7].  Independents, in particular, are more inclined than partisans to say that neither the Republican nor the Democratic party possesses high ethical standards [9].

![A table showing the percentage of people who think both, one or neither party has high ethical standards, broken down by different demographic groups including party affiliation.](image1)

Specifically, when considering Democrats, approximately two-in-ten, or 18%, expressed the view that neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party has 'high ethical standards' [9].  Therefore, 18% of Democrats in the survey believed neither party has high ethical standards.

A notable portion of Cuban voters express a desire for Trump to run for president in 2024, as shown in the image ![Cuban voters show a higher percentage compared to other Latino subgroups in wanting Trump to run for president](image4).  In contrast, other Latino subgroups like Mexicans and Puerto Ricans show less support for Trump remaining a major national political figure [7].

Cuban voters are most likely among Hispanic origin groups in the United States to vote for a Republican candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives and to say Trump should run for president in 2024.

In 2008, following Obama's victory, Republican voters showed a tendency towards moderation, with nearly sixty percent advocating for GOP leaders to collaborate with President Obama [8]. This inclination to work with the opposing party was also evident in the opinions of McCain voters, where a majority felt Republican leaders should cooperate with Obama [5].  However, by 2016, this moderate sentiment among Republicans appeared to have diminished, as a significant majority continued to favor a more conservative direction for the GOP, a preference consistent with previous years [7]. ![This image illustrates the consistent preference among Republicans for a more conservative direction from 2008 to 2016.](image5).

Conversely, Democratic voters have shown a shift in the opposite direction. In the aftermath of Obama's victories, a smaller fraction of Democrats favored a more liberal direction for their party [9].  But by 2016, there was a notable increase in the proportion of Democratic voters desiring a more liberal stance, marking a significant change from the post-election sentiments in both 2008 and 2012 [9, 10].  ![This image depicts the increasing desire among Democrats for a more liberal direction from 2008 to 2016.](image3).

In summary, from 2008 to 2016, Republican voters remained largely consistent in their conservative leanings, while Democratic voters shifted from a more moderate stance to a more liberal one.

In comparing voter opinions on appointing opposition party members, a notable difference emerges between the elections of Donald Trump in 2016 and Barack Obama in 2008.  Specifically, voters of Donald Trump in 2016 were less inclined towards bipartisan cabinet appointments compared to voters of Barack Obama in 2008.  Only about a quarter (26%) of Trump voters thought he should appoint Democrats to his administration [6], as shown in the data that illustrates the divided opinion amongst Trump voters with a plurality stating it doesn't matter if Democrats are appointed ![Trump voters' opinion on appointing Democrats is divided, with a plurality saying it doesn't matter](image2). In stark contrast, a majority of Obama voters (52%) after his victory in 2008 believed he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet [8], which is double the proportion of Trump voters favoring Democratic appointments.  This difference is visually represented in the data showing Obama voters were more in favor of bipartisan cabinet appointments ![Obama voters were more in favor of bipartisan cabinet appointments](image2).  Therefore, voter opinions on appointing opposition party members differed significantly, with Obama's voters in 2008 showing a much stronger preference for bipartisan appointments than Trump's voters in 2016.

Current ratings regarding the U.S. military effort against ISIS remain negative, yet there's an observable increase in the view that the U.S. and its allies will eventually be successful [3].  This is highlighted by the shift in public opinion between July and December 2015, as illustrated in the data ![Showing the trend of success belief in US campaign against ISIS from July to December 2015](image3).  In July 2015, 55% of people believed in the success of the U.S. and its allies' campaign against Islamic militants, and this number increased to 66% by December 2015 [7].  In summary, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more positive between July and December 2015.

Public perception is divided on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence compared to other religions, with opinions becoming increasingly politically polarized [1].  While overall public sentiment has slightly shifted from a high in 2014, the partisan divide on this issue has reached a historical peak [4, 8].  Notably, Republican views have remained largely consistent, with a high percentage believing Islam encourages violence, while Democratic opinions have shown a decrease since 2014 [6, 8].  ![Shows the percentage of different demographic groups who think Islam is more likely to encourage violence over time.](image1) This divergence is further emphasized by the stark contrast between conservative Republicans, a large majority of whom associate Islam with violence, and liberal Democrats, most of whom do not [7].  ![Illustrates the trend of Republican and Democrat opinions on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence over time.](image5)  Although younger adults are generally less inclined to believe Islam encourages violence compared to older demographics, this age gap has narrowed recently [2].  In conclusion, perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence are divided and heavily influenced by political affiliation, with a widening partisan gap and some shifts in views over time, especially among Democrats and younger individuals.

A significant majority of Americans are familiar with the idea of machines potentially taking over many human jobs [7].  This widespread awareness contributes to a general sense of realism regarding this prospect. ![This image shows the percentages of Americans who have heard a lot, a little, or nothing at all about the concept of robots and computers doing many jobs currently done by humans.](image2)  Indeed, a notable portion of the population finds the idea to be extremely realistic [8].  However, this perceived plausibility is overshadowed by a dominant sentiment of worry rather than enthusiasm [9].  In fact, Americans are significantly more likely to express worry than enthusiasm about this future scenario [9]. ![This image displays the percentages of Americans who are very/somewhat worried or enthusiastic about the concept, broken down by their level of awareness.](image5)  Those who are more informed about the concept of automation tend to perceive it as even more realistic and express stronger feelings, both enthusiasm and worry [6].  While a considerable percentage believe it is extremely realistic that machines will perform many human jobs ![This image shows the percentage of Americans who find the concept of machines doing most human jobs in the future to be extremely realistic.](image1), the prevailing view is one of concern, anticipating potential negative consequences such as increased inequality and challenges in finding purpose in life [4]. ![This image displays possible negative and positive outcomes of machines doing many jobs currently done by humans, and whether Americans think these outcomes are likely or not.](image3).  In conclusion, Americans largely perceive the automation of human jobs as a realistic possibility but are more inclined to feel worried than enthusiastic about it.

Public sentiment regarding automation in the workforce is complex.  While some recognize the economic efficiencies of replacing human workers with machines if they perform better and at a lower cost, as noted by the 41% who hold this view, a larger proportion, 58%, believe there should be restrictions on the number of jobs businesses can automate. This division is visually represented in ![Public opinion is split on whether there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines](image2), and is also reflected in survey data indicating that nearly six-in-ten Americans share this concern [7]. Despite this division on the general principle of job replacement limits, a significant consensus emerges when considering specific types of limitations. An overwhelming majority, 85% of Americans, strongly favor limiting robots and computers primarily to roles that are hazardous or detrimental to human health [9, 10]. This preference for focusing automation on undesirable jobs is further substantiated by the strong public support for policies that restrict machines to dangerous tasks, along with favorable attitudes towards implementing a guaranteed basic income and national service initiatives for workers displaced by automation, as illustrated in ![Public strongly supports limiting machines to dangerous jobs and supports policies for worker displacement](image4).  Although partisan opinions diverge on broader policies like universal basic income and national service [3], there is a general agreement across party lines on the idea of limiting the extent to which businesses can replace human jobs with machines [2, 3]. In conclusion, public opinion generally favors limiting the use of machines in the workforce, particularly to dangerous and unhealthy jobs, and supports policies to aid workers displaced by automation.

Perceptions regarding the job market have significantly improved recently, with a majority of Americans now believing that there are plenty of jobs available in their local communities [4, 6].  Notably, positive views on job availability are now at a high point in the last twenty years for both Republicans and Democrats [10]. However, a noticeable partisan divide exists in these perceptions.  While a substantial majority of Republicans, around 71%, express confidence in job availability, a smaller majority of Democrats, about 53%, share this view [7]. This partisan gap is further illustrated in the visual data, showcasing that Republicans are more likely to perceive "plenty of jobs available" compared to Democrats. ![Republicans are more likely to say plenty of jobs are available than Democrats](image1)  This difference is not new; it has been present and even more pronounced in previous years, as seen in the historical trends where the gap between Republican and Democrat perceptions of job availability has fluctuated but persisted over time. ![Trend of perceived job availability from 2001 to 2019, showing partisan divide](image4).  Currently, 71% of Republicans believe jobs are plentiful, while 53% of Democrats agree, marking a clear difference in their assessments of the job market [3].

In conclusion, Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to perceive plenty of jobs being available in their communities.

This indicates a growing desire within both parties for stronger opposition and less compromise.

In January 2019, there was an increase in the percentage of both Republicans and Democrats who wanted their leaders to 'stand up' to the opposition compared to January 2018.

Latinos generally recognize the importance of racial discrimination, as a majority believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really exists is a significant problem [1]. However, when examining this perception through the lens of political affiliation, a notable difference emerges. Among Latinos, a higher percentage of Democrats express concern about the issue of people not acknowledging racial discrimination [4].  Specifically, nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party, representing 73%, consider it a bigger problem that people fail to see racial discrimination where it truly exists [6].  In stark contrast, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners, approximately 62%, are more inclined to believe that the greater issue is people perceiving racial discrimination where it is absent [6]. This divergence in viewpoints is visually summarized in ![Latinos overall believe not seeing racial discrimination is a bigger problem, with a significant gap between Democrats and Republicans](image3), clearly demonstrating the differing perceptions of racial discrimination between Latino Democrats and Republicans.  In conclusion, Latino Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to perceive the failure to recognize existing racial discrimination as a greater problem.

Americans perceive various reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM fields [2, 3].  Many believe that a significant factor is the lack of encouragement for girls and these minority groups to pursue STEM from a young age [5].  This lack of early encouragement is considered a major reason for the limited diversity in STEM [5].  Furthermore, limited access to quality education that prepares individuals for STEM fields is another critical barrier, particularly for blacks and Hispanics [6].

![Major reasons for underrepresentation include lack of encouragement and quality education](image5)

This educational disparity is echoed by STEM employees themselves, who are more likely than those in non-STEM jobs to point to lack of access to quality education as a major obstacle [1].  Discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is also a significant reason, especially for blacks in STEM, with a large majority believing it is a major contributor to underrepresentation [7, 8].  In fact, black STEM workers are more likely to report experiencing discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity compared to other groups in STEM [10].  While some suggest that a lack of belief in their ability to succeed in STEM or a lack of interest might play a role, the data strongly suggests that systemic issues like lack of access to quality education, lack of early encouragement, and discrimination are key factors driving the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs.

The major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs include lack of early encouragement, limited access to quality education, and discrimination in recruitment and promotion.

Americans generally hold a somewhat critical view of the quality of STEM education in K-12 public schools.  In fact, most U.S. adults tend to rate K-12 STEM education as average or worse when compared to other developed nations [8, 10].  Only a quarter of Americans believe that K-12 STEM education in the U.S. is at least above average relative to other developed countries ![25% of Americans consider K-12 STEM education in public schools to be at least above average](image5).  Interestingly, individuals with postgraduate degrees in STEM fields, while generally positive about postsecondary STEM education, express even stronger concerns about K-12 STEM education [1].  Specifically, a mere $13\%$ of STEM postgraduate degree holders rate K-12 STEM education as above average, and a significant $51\%$ consider it to be below average [9]. This perspective is notably more critical than that of the general public.

In summary, while both U.S. adults and STEM postgraduate degree holders express concerns about K-12 STEM education, those with STEM postgraduate degrees tend to hold a more critical view.

To articulate uncertainty, this document uses both confidence and likelihood language [9].  Confidence in the validity of a finding is evaluated qualitatively by considering the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, alongside the degree of expert agreement on that finding [9]. These factors determine the confidence level, which can range from very high to inconclusive depending on the robustness of evidence and expert consensus, as illustrated in ![Confidence levels range from very high to inconclusive based on evidence and consensus](image2).  Conversely, likelihood offers a quantitative estimate of uncertainty, expressed probabilistically [7]. It describes the probability of an impact occurring, with levels ranging from very unlikely to very likely, each associated with specific probability ranges, as shown in ![Likelihood levels with associated probability ranges](image3). Both confidence and likelihood levels are established through the expert assessment and consensus of chapter author teams, who evaluate available literature, evidence quality and quantity, and the level of agreement across different studies [5]. In conclusion, expert assessment of evidence and consensus determines the levels of confidence and likelihood.

Educational background and political affiliation significantly shape perceptions of political parties' ethical conduct.  Individuals with higher education, such as college graduates, exhibit nuanced perspectives, with a notable portion acknowledging ethical shortcomings in at least one of the major parties [3].  In contrast, views diverge sharply along partisan lines, as demonstrated by the consistent differences in how Republicans and Democrats assess each other's ethical standards and policy ideas [4].  Independents, distinct from partisans, are more inclined to perceive a lack of ethical standards in both parties [7].  ![College graduates are less likely to say neither party has high ethical standards compared to those with less education](image4).  This is further highlighted when considering political leanings; independents, especially those leaning towards either party, still express greater skepticism about the ethical standards of both parties compared to strong partisans [7].  ![Independents are more likely to say neither party has high ethical standards compared to both Republicans and Democrats](image4).

Furthermore, perceptions of extremism are also deeply influenced by political alignment.  Substantial proportions within each party consider the opposing party to be "too extreme," highlighting a significant partisan divide [4].  This divergence is evident when comparing the views of Democrats and Republicans on the perceived extremism of each party [9].  ![Democrats are more likely to view Republicans as too extreme, and Republicans are more likely to view Democrats as too extreme](image3).  Interestingly, while more Americans overall find the Republican Party "too extreme" compared to the Democratic Party, these views have shown some fluctuation over time [9]. ![Democrats are slightly more likely to be seen as having high ethical standards, while Republicans are slightly more likely to be seen as too extreme](image2).

In summary, perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism are significantly shaped by both educational attainment and political affiliation, revealing distinct viewpoints among different segments of the population.

Public perception indicates a nuanced view of ethical standards within the Republican and Democratic parties.  While a considerable portion of the public, approximately four-in-ten, believes that each party upholds high ethical standards [2], this view isn't uniformly shared.  Notably, when considering both parties together, a quarter of the public perceives neither the Republican nor the Democratic party as having high ethical standards [6]. In fact, assessments of ethical standards are quite similar for both, with around 41% viewing the GOP as ethical and 42% saying the same for the Democratic Party [9].  Interestingly, independents stand out as more critical, with about a third stating that neither party possesses high ethical standards [1].

![Percentage of people with different education levels who think neither party has high ethical standards](image1)

This sentiment is especially pronounced among those with higher education levels; approximately 31% of individuals with a college degree or higher education believe that "high ethical standards" does not describe either party [8]. This contrasts with individuals with less educational attainment, where fewer hold this view [5].  Partisan alignment significantly shapes these perceptions, as individuals affiliated with a party are more inclined to view their own party as ethical, even if somewhat less positively than they view policy ideas [4, 7].

![Breakdown of the percentage of people who think neither party has high ethical standards, by political affiliation](image2)

However, when it comes to being "too extreme," the Republican Party is somewhat more often viewed as such compared to the Democratic Party, although this perception has slightly decreased for the GOP recently [3].

![Comparison of public opinion on policy ideas, ethical standards and extremism for Republican and Democratic parties](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of ethical standards are largely similar for both parties, yet shaped by education and political affiliation, while the Republican party is slightly more often seen as "too extreme" than the Democratic party.

Public perception of ethical standards within political parties is significantly shaped by education level.  A notable portion of the public, about a quarter, believes that "high ethical standards" apply to neither the Republican nor the Democratic party [4]. However, this view is more pronounced among those with higher education; nearly a third of college graduates express this sentiment [9].  In fact, individuals with at least a college degree are more inclined to say that neither party possesses high ethical standards, with a significant $31\%$ holding this view [7].

![College graduates are more likely to disapprove political parties](image1)

Conversely, those with less educational attainment, such as a high school degree or less, are less likely to think that neither party has high ethical standards [1].  Educational attainment also strongly correlates with political preferences.  Individuals holding postgraduate degrees are significantly more inclined to favor the Democratic candidate over the Republican, by a ratio of roughly two-to-one [2]. This preference for Democrats is also evident among those with a four-year college degree, although to a lesser extent [2].

![The public holds similar views of ethical standards for both Republican and Democratic parties](image2)

Interestingly, independents are more likely than those affiliated with either party to believe that neither party has high ethical standards [10].  Despite these varying perceptions of ethical standards, attentiveness to political news remains consistent across party lines, with identical shares of Republicans and Democrats reporting that they closely follow news about upcoming elections [3].

![Individuals with higher education are more inclined to say neither party has high ethical standards](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences are clearly differentiated by education level, with higher education correlating with increased skepticism towards the ethical standards of both parties and a stronger preference for the Democratic party.

Public sentiment regarding President Trump's handling of economic policy is somewhat varied, with 53% of the public expressing at least some degree of confidence in his decision-making in this area [3].  This level of confidence in his economic policy decisions has seen a slight positive trend since earlier assessments ![Trend of public confidence in Trump's ability to make sound economic policy decisions over time](image3).  However, when considering ethical standards, a similar pattern of divided opinions emerges, particularly along partisan lines.  While a considerable majority of Republicans tend to rate the ethical standards of the Trump administration favorably, a large proportion of Democrats hold a negative view [5].  This partisan divergence in perceptions of ethical standards is clearly visualized when comparing the opinions of Republican-leaning and Democrat-leaning individuals, highlighting a substantial gap in their assessments ![Distinct partisan views on the ethical standards of the Trump administration officials](image1).  In summary, public views on both President Trump's handling of economic policy and the ethical standards of his administration are significantly shaped by partisan affiliations.

Public sentiment regarding President Trump's capabilities shows a nuanced pattern, especially concerning economic policy and international crises.  Initially, public confidence in Trump was mixed across various key issues [1]. However, there's been a noticeable uptick in confidence since January in his ability to manage both international crises and the economy [2, 3].  For instance, confidence in his handling of international crises has risen from 35% in January to 43% currently [10].

![Trend of confidence in handling international crisis and economic policy over time](image1)

This upward trend is also reflected in economic policy, where confidence has increased from 46% in January to 53% [7].  While these numbers show improvement, it's worth noting that opinions remain divided, with a significant portion of the public still expressing little to no confidence in these areas [6, 9]. Currently, 53% express at least some confidence in his economic decisions, while 54% have little to no confidence in his handling of international crises [6, 9].

![Current confidence levels for various policies in May 2018](image4)

Partisan lines strongly influence these perceptions. Republicans have shown increasing support for Trump, with a significant 80% now agreeing with him on many or all issues, a substantial rise from 69% last August [4].  This partisan divide is starkly illustrated when comparing Republican and Democrat confidence levels.

![Partisan breakdown of agreement and confidence levels](image2)

Republicans' confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has surged from 73% in January to 84% [5]. In contrast, views among Democrats are vastly different, highlighting a deep partisan chasm in how Trump's capabilities are perceived [image2].  Despite some fluctuations over the past year, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has generally seen an increase since the beginning of the year, particularly among Republicans, though overall opinions remain mixed and heavily divided along partisan lines.

Public confidence in President Trump's capacity to manage both international crises and economic policy has generally seen an uptick since January [8]. As visualized, the confidence in his handling of international crises has grown from 35% in January to 43% in May 2018, although it is still under the 48% mark recorded in April 2017 ![Public confidence in handling international crisis has increased since January but is still lower than April 2017](image2).  Similarly, confidence in his ability to make sound decisions on economic policy has also shown an upward trend [4], reaching 53% in May 2018 [3], which is reflective of the overall public sentiment regarding various facets of his presidential performance ![Public confidence levels across different aspects of Trump's presidency](image1).  However, when considering views on his conduct, partisan lines are clearly drawn.  A substantial 85% of Democrats express disapproval of his conduct [1], contrasting with Republicans, among whom 45% have mixed feelings and 38% express approval [6] ![Democrats overwhelmingly dislike Trump's conduct, while Republicans are more divided in their feelings](image5).  In conclusion, public confidence in Trump's abilities concerning economic and international matters has increased, yet sentiment towards his conduct continues to be significantly divided along partisan lines.

Public confidence in Donald Trump's ability to navigate international crises and manage economic policy shows interesting trends.  Currently,  $43\%$ of the public expresses confidence in his handling of international crises, while a slightly larger $53\%$ are confident in his economic policy decisions [5, 3].  This indicates a slightly higher level of public trust in his economic abilities compared to his crisis management on the international stage.  ![Comparison of public confidence in Trump's handling of international crisis and economic policy](image3).

Looking at the change over time, both areas have seen an increase in public confidence since January.  Confidence in his handling of international crises has risen from $35\%$ in January to the current $43\%$ [5]. Similarly, confidence in his economic policy handling has also increased from $46\%$ to $53\%$ over the same period [3, 6].  Notably, Republicans have shown a significant surge in confidence regarding his international crisis management, increasing from $73\%$ in January to $84\%$ currently [9].

Overall, public confidence in Trump's abilities to handle both international crises and economic policy has improved since the beginning of the year, with economic policy enjoying slightly higher confidence levels than international crisis management.

Public opinion on President Trump's conduct reveals a stark partisan divide.  Democrats overwhelmingly express disapproval, with a large majority consistently stating they dislike his behavior [2, 5].  ![Democrats strongly disapprove of Trump's conduct](image1).  This sentiment has remained largely unchanged over recent months [2, 4].  Even when considering the ethical standards of the Trump administration, Democrats remain highly critical, especially liberal Democrats, with a vast majority giving low marks [8].  ![Liberal Democrats overwhelmingly rate Trump administration ethical standards poorly](image2).

However, within the Republican party, opinions are more varied. While a significant portion of Republicans express liking Trump's conduct, a considerable number have mixed feelings [3, 5].  ![Republicans show mixed feelings towards Trump's conduct](image1).  Conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of Trump's conduct compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [6].  Furthermore, views on the ethical standards of the Trump administration also diverge within the Republican party, with moderate and liberal Republicans expressing more negative views than their conservative counterparts [9, 10].  Interestingly, there has been a strengthening of Republican alignment with Trump on policy issues over time [7].  Looking at trends over a short period, there was a slight shift in Republican opinions on Trump's conduct between August 2017 and May 2018, with a decrease in those who like his conduct and an increase in those with mixed feelings, although Democrats’ disapproval remained consistently high during this period [5]. ![Changes in opinions about Trump's conduct between Aug 2017 and May 2018 within both parties](image3).

Overall, Democrats consistently disapprove of Trump's conduct and ethical standards, while Republicans exhibit more varied opinions, with internal divisions and some shifts over time, though a general alignment on policy has increased.

Public perception of the ethical standards within the Trump administration is notably low, with a significant majority expressing negative views [1, 9].  In fact, when compared to previous administrations dating back to Ronald Reagan's era, the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are rated more poorly by the American public [1].

![This image visually represents a comparison of ethical ratings across different presidential administrations, with Trump's administration listed at the top, suggesting a lower ranking relative to past presidents.](image1)

While approximately four-in-ten Americans perceive the ethical standards as either excellent or good, a considerably larger proportion,  $58\%$, deem them to be not good or poor [1]. This negative sentiment is further underscored by the intensity of disapproval, where a substantial $42\%$ of the public strongly disapproves of President Trump's handling of his presidential duties [4].  Despite these low ratings for ethical conduct, public opinion regarding Donald Trump's overall job performance has remained relatively stable throughout his presidency, mirroring the levels observed at its commencement [2].  The public's low evaluation of the Trump administration's ethical standards stands in contrast to consistent, albeit not overwhelmingly positive, ratings of his job performance [2, 9].  In conclusion, ethical standards for Trump administration officials are rated lower compared to past administrations, yet this has not drastically altered public approval of Trump's overall job performance.

Americans' perceptions of ethical standards in political parties and their approval of political figures like Trump are notably shaped by their educational backgrounds.  Those with higher education are more inclined to believe that neither the Republican nor Democratic parties possess high ethical standards [6].  In fact, a substantial portion of college graduates,  more so than those with less education, express this view, suggesting a more critical perspective on party ethics with increased education levels [1, 6].

![College graduates are more likely to think neither party has high ethical standards](image4)

Furthermore, political affiliation significantly dictates opinions on ethical standards and political figures. Independents, in particular, hold a more negative view of the ethical standards of political administrations compared to those affiliated with either party [2].  This is further highlighted when considering partisan leanings, as Republicans and Democrats tend to view their own party more favorably in terms of ethical conduct, even if they are somewhat less positive [3]. This partisan divide is evident in views of Trump, where strong party lines dictate approval ratings, demonstrating how political affiliation strongly colors perceptions of ethical standards and political figures [8].

![Public views on Republican and Democratic party's ethical standards](image1)

Ultimately, both educational attainment and political affiliation are critical factors influencing how individuals perceive ethical standards within political parties and form opinions on leaders such as Trump.

Voter reactions in 2016 presented a nuanced landscape when compared to previous elections. While about half of voters expressed happiness about Donald Trump's victory, mirroring reactions to Barack Obama's reelection in 2012 [6], this level of happiness was notably less than the enthusiasm following Obama's initial election in 2008 [5].  ![This image displays the percentage of voters happy with the presidential election outcome across different years, highlighting a decrease in happiness in 2016 compared to 2008.](image3)  In fact, in 2008, a significantly larger percentage of voters reported feeling hopeful about Obama's election than voters felt about Trump's election in 2016 [4].  However, digging deeper into the emotional responses, we find a complex mix.  Many voters reported feeling hopeful about Trump's election, yet a considerable portion also expressed feelings of unease [2].  ![This image lists various emotions expressed by voters following Trump's election, including hopeful, proud, uneasy, sad, scared, and angry.](image2)  A striking feature of the 2016 election was the strong partisan divide in reactions, with the vast majority of Trump voters happy about his win and a similar majority of Clinton voters unhappy, a more pronounced divide than seen in 2008 [1].  Moreover, surprise was a dominant emotion across the electorate, with a large majority of voters overall, including both Trump and Clinton supporters, expressing surprise at Trump's victory [10]. ![This image shows the percentage of voters who were surprised or not surprised by Trump's victory, broken down by all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters.](image4)  This election year was also characterized by negativity and a perceived lack of focus on issues, factors that likely shaped voter reactions and contributed to a more negative post-election sentiment compared to previous years [7, 9].

In summary, voter reactions in 2016 were marked by a mix of hope and unease, a strong partisan divide in happiness levels, widespread surprise at the outcome, and a generally more negative post-election sentiment compared to previous U.S. presidential elections.

Following Trump's election, a stark emotional divide emerged between voters.  A significant majority of Trump voters expressed positive feelings, with an overwhelming $96\%$ reporting hopefulness and $74\%$ pride in the election outcome [1, 3].  This confidence is further highlighted by the fact that $88\%$ of Trump voters felt confident about the kind of president he would be, with only a small $10\%$ expressing serious concerns [9].

![Trump voters overwhelmingly felt hopeful and proud, while Clinton voters felt the opposite](image5)

In stark contrast, Clinton voters experienced a range of negative emotions.  The most prevalent reaction was unease, affecting $90\%$ of Clinton supporters, followed by sadness $(77\%)$ and fear $(76\%)$ [1, 8].  Anger was also a significant emotion, felt by $62\%$ of Clinton voters [8]. These negative feelings were particularly pronounced among Clinton voters with college degrees, who were more likely to express anger and sadness compared to those without a degree [2, 6].

While Trump's supporters were largely optimistic about his presidency, with $56\%$ believing he would have a successful first term [4], Clinton voters held considerably more pessimistic views.  Only $15\%$ of Clinton supporters anticipated a successful first term for Trump, while a large $76\%$ expected it to be unsuccessful [10].  This level of pessimism was notably higher than McCain voters' expectations for Obama's first term in 2008, where $39\%$ believed Obama would be successful [10].

![Clinton voters' expectations for Trump's success were much lower than McCain voters' expectations for Obama's success in 2008](image2)

Despite the widespread negative emotions, a majority of Clinton voters, $58\%$, expressed a willingness to "give Trump a chance," although a substantial $39\%$ stated they could not see themselves giving him a chance due to his perceived character [7].

![A majority of Clinton voters were willing to give Trump a chance, while a significant portion were not](image3)

In summary, Trump voters reacted to his election with strong positive emotions and confidence in his presidency, while Clinton voters experienced predominantly negative emotions and held pessimistic expectations for his first term.

Following the 2016 election, perspectives on Donald Trump's upcoming presidency were sharply divided among voters, particularly between those who supported him and those who supported Hillary Clinton.  An overwhelming majority of Trump voters, specifically $97\%$, anticipated a successful first term for him [6], mirroring the optimism Obama voters had for their candidate in 2008.  This confidence extended to their overall view of his presidency, with $88\%$ expressing confidence in the kind of president he would be [8].  ![Trump voters are largely confident about the kind of president Trump will be](image1).  Conversely, Clinton voters held a much more negative outlook.  A significant $76\%$ of Clinton supporters predicted an unsuccessful first term for Trump [4], a stark contrast to the nearly four-in-ten McCain supporters who anticipated success for Obama in 2008 [4].  ![Clinton voters largely expect Trump's first term to be unsuccessful](image4).  Despite these negative expectations, a majority of Clinton voters, $58\%$, indicated a willingness to "give Trump a chance and see how he governs" [10], although a considerable $39\%$ expressed an inability to do so due to their perception of his character [10]. ![Some Clinton voters are willing to give Trump a chance, but a notable portion cannot due to his perceived character](image3).  This demonstrates a clear divergence in initial reactions, with Trump voters exhibiting strong optimism and confidence, while Clinton voters were largely pessimistic yet somewhat divided on their willingness to observe his presidency.

In summary, Trump voters were overwhelmingly optimistic and confident about his first term, whereas Clinton voters were largely pessimistic, though a portion were willing to give him a chance despite concerns about his character.

Trump voters prioritized tangible policy areas such as health care, the economy, and immigration for Trump's presidency [1, 6]. ![Trump and Clinton voters' priorities for Trump's presidency](image1).  In contrast, Clinton voters emphasized unifying the country and rectifying divisions that arose during the campaign [8]. This divergence in priorities reflects distinct perspectives on Trump's leadership, as Trump voters largely expressed confidence in understanding his vision for the country [5]. ![Trump voters have a good idea of Trump's vision while Clinton voters do not](image2).  Conversely, a significant majority of Clinton voters felt uncertain about his goals [5].  Adding to this contrast, Clinton voters were more inclined to anticipate negative changes in Washington under Trump’s leadership [7]. ![Clinton voters think Trump will change Washington for the worse](image5).  Moreover, Clinton voters displayed a greater desire for Trump to prioritize the needs of all Americans, beyond just his supporters. ![Clinton voters want Trump to prioritize all Americans](image3).  These differing priorities and perceptions indicate that Trump voters assessed his leadership based on expected policy outcomes, while Clinton voters were more concerned with his leadership style and its impact on national cohesion.

Even among Trump's supporters, confidence in his handling of foreign policy is not the highest, with only about half expressing strong confidence [7]. In stark contrast, a large proportion of Clinton voters indicated having no confidence at all in Trump's ability to make sound decisions on foreign policy, as shown in image1 illustrating the confidence levels of both voter groups across various issues. ![Confidence levels of Trump and Clinton voters across different issues, highlighting the "None at all" responses from Clinton voters on foreign policy](image1). This sentiment is further supported by text quote [4], which notes that nearly two-thirds of Clinton supporters have absolutely no confidence in Trump concerning foreign policy.

Conversely, when examining expectations for race relations after the election, a notable difference emerges between voter groups.  Image2 visually represents that a significant percentage of Trump voters were optimistic, anticipating improvements in race relations. ![Voter expectations for race relations post-election, showing Trump voters' anticipation of improvement](image2). However, the vast majority of Clinton voters held a contrasting view, with an overwhelming percentage expecting race relations to deteriorate [5]. This stark pessimism among Clinton voters is clearly depicted in image3, where the majority believe race relations will worsen. ![Differing expectations on race relations between Clinton and Trump voters, emphasizing Clinton voters' pessimistic outlook](image3). Overall, a considerable portion of voters expressed pessimism regarding the trajectory of race relations under Trump's presidency [10].

In conclusion, Clinton voters were markedly less confident in Trump's foreign policy capabilities and considerably more pessimistic about the future of race relations under his leadership compared to Trump voters.

Following the 2016 election, there was a widespread skepticism among voters regarding improvements in race relations under President Trump [10].  In fact, a significant portion of voters anticipated a decline in race relations, with nearly half of all voters expecting things to get worse  [5].  ![This image shows the percentage breakdown of Trump and Clinton voters' expectations on race relations, categorizing them into 'Better', 'No difference', and 'Worse'.](image1)  This pessimism was particularly pronounced among Clinton voters, with an overwhelming majority believing that race relations would deteriorate [1]. Conversely, Trump voters held a much more optimistic outlook, with half anticipating improvements in race relations [9].  However, looking at the broader picture of political unity, few individuals believed that partisan relations in Washington would actually improve following Trump's election [6].  While Trump supporters expressed somewhat less optimism about improvements in partisan relations compared to Obama voters in 2008, Clinton voters were notably more inclined than McCain voters in 2008 to foresee a worsening of these relations [4].

In summary, survey data reveals a stark contrast in confidence levels: Trump voters were considerably more confident than Clinton voters that Trump's presidency would improve both race relations and political cooperation, though overall voter sentiment leaned towards skepticism, especially concerning race relations.

Voters held pessimistic views regarding race relations following the 2016 election, with a significant proportion anticipating a worsening situation under Trump’s presidency [1, 3].  Specifically, nearly half of all voters believed race relations would deteriorate, a sentiment strongly echoed by a large majority of Clinton voters, as depicted in the stark contrast between those who thought race relations would worsen versus improve among Clinton voters ![Clinton voters overwhelmingly believe race relations will worsen under Trump](image4). This contrasts with expectations for partisan relations, which were more mixed. While a notable portion of voters anticipated no change in partisan dynamics, there was also a considerable segment that expected them to worsen, mirroring the negative outlook on race relations to some extent [8]. However, when comparing the anticipation of improved partisan relations in 2016 to that after Obama's 2008 victory, it reveals a lower level of optimism in 2016, suggesting a shift in voter sentiment regarding political cooperation [10, 9].  Interestingly, the enthusiasm of a president's supporters may not necessarily translate to a universally held belief in improved political outcomes, as illustrated by the notion that ![Enthusiastic supporters for a president may lead to political gridlock](image3), potentially hindering progress and effective governance.  In conclusion, voters were more pessimistic about race relations than optimistic about partisan relations after the 2016 election, and enthusiastic support for a president was perceived by some as a potential impediment to political progress.

Republican voters have consistently desired a more conservative direction for their party, with a significant $60\%$ currently favoring this stance, a trend that has remained stable in recent years [4].  This preference for a conservative direction among Republicans is visualized over time, showing a persistent lean towards conservatism rather than moderation within the GOP. ![Republicans consistently prefer a conservative direction](image2).  In contrast, Democratic voters are increasingly inclined towards a more liberal direction for their party. Currently, $49\%$ of Democrats advocate for a more liberal stance, a notable increase from just $38\%$ shortly after the midterm election two years prior and even more significantly compared to the periods following Obama's presidential victories [9]. This shift in Democratic voters' preference for a more liberal direction is further illustrated, highlighting the growing desire for a leftward movement within the Democratic party. ![Democrats are increasingly favoring a liberal direction](image1).  Despite these differing ideological preferences, overall voter reactions to the 2016 election outcomes reveal mixed sentiments.  Approximately $52\%$ of voters expressed happiness about the Republican Party maintaining control of Congress, while $45\%$ were unhappy [10].  This happiness is largely driven by Republican voters, with a striking $94\%$ of Trump voters reporting satisfaction with the GOP's continued congressional control, while a vast majority of Clinton supporters, $87\%$, expressed unhappiness [8]. The overall happiness with Republican control is observed with the contrasting levels of happiness and unhappiness among voters. ![Voters are divided on their happiness about Republican control of Congress](image5).  These reactions highlight a significant partisan divide, which is even more pronounced than observed in the 2008 election cycle, indicating an increasing polarization in voter sentiment based on election outcomes [5].

In summary, while Republican voters have maintained a consistent conservative preference, Democratic voters have become increasingly liberal, and reactions to the 2016 election outcomes underscore a deepened partisan divide compared to previous election cycles.

In 2016, a notable proportion of voters perceived the political landscape as exceedingly negative, with an overwhelming 92% reporting heightened levels of negative campaigning compared to previous election cycles [3]. This contrasts sharply with the sentiment observed after the 2008 election.  Voter attitudes towards bipartisan cooperation also differed significantly between these two periods.  In 2008, as Barack Obama prepared to take office, a considerable 78% of his voters expressed the view that Democratic leaders in Washington should collaborate with Republicans, even if it meant some disappointment for their own supporters [9]. McCain voters held a similar perspective, with 76% favoring cooperation [9]. This contrasted with the sentiment surrounding Donald Trump's election in 2016, as shown in a graphical representation comparing voter expectations in both years ![This image contrasts voter expectations in 2008 and 2016 regarding political leaders working with or standing up to the president, highlighting a shift in attitudes towards bipartisan cooperation.](image1).

Notably, in November 2008, a higher percentage of Republican and Republican-leaning voters, nearly 59%, were inclined towards their party's leaders working with Obama [10]. This figure stands in contrast to the 2016 election aftermath where, while a majority of Republican and Republican-leaning voters (53%) still preferred Trump to collaborate with Democratic leaders, a smaller proportion compared to 2008 held this view [5].  Conversely, in 2016, a substantial 65% of Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters preferred their leaders to strongly oppose Donald Trump on issues important to Democrats, even if it hindered progress in Washington [4]. This inclination to stand firm against the newly elected president was more pronounced among Democrats in 2016 than the Republican stance of opposing Obama in 2008.  The graphic further emphasizes this shift, directly comparing voter preferences for leaders to either work with or stand up to the president in both 2008 and 2016  ![This image visually compares the percentage of voters who believed leaders should work with or stand up to the president in November 2008 and November 2016, illustrating the change in voter expectations across these two election periods.](image5).  Overall, voter expectations for bipartisan cooperation were significantly higher in 2008 compared to 2016, with a marked increase in partisan polarization regarding whether political leaders should work with or oppose the newly elected president in 2016.

The 2016 presidential campaign was overwhelmingly viewed as negative by voters, with a significant $92\%$ perceiving more "mudslinging" than in previous elections [7, 9].  This perception of heightened negativity is clearly illustrated by the overwhelming majority of voters who believed there was more mudslinging in the 2016 election compared to past contests ![92% of voters perceived more mudslinging in 2016 election](image1).  This negativity appears to have influenced voter evaluations of various political actors involved in the election.  For instance, "the voters" themselves received a relatively low grade, with only $40\%$ awarding themselves an A or B [4].  Furthermore, institutions like the press and pollsters, heavily criticized during the election cycle, also received poor grades from voters, with substantial portions assigning them failing marks [3].  The average grades given to various entities, including the press and pollsters, highlight this critical perspective from the voters ![Grades given to different entities involved in the 2016 election campaign](image4).  Even the major political parties, the Republicans and Democrats, faced harsh judgment, receiving failing grades from approximately $30\%$ of voters, a peak in negative evaluations since 1988 [5].  This pervasive negativity and critical assessment across the board suggest that the perceived negativity of the 2016 campaign strongly correlated with diminished voter perceptions of political entities and actors involved.

In conclusion, voter perceptions of political entities in the 2016 election were negatively impacted by the overwhelmingly negative nature of the campaign.

The emotional landscape following Donald Trump's unexpected 2016 election victory was sharply divided, reflecting the deep partisan polarization of the electorate.  A significant majority of voters, across party lines, were initially taken aback by the outcome [1].  For those who supported Donald Trump, the prevailing sentiments were overwhelmingly positive.  Many Trump voters expressed feelings of happiness, surprise, and relief, as captured by their own words describing their reactions ![Words like "Happy", "Surprised", and "Relieved" were frequently used by Trump voters to describe their feelings.](image3).  Indeed, a large proportion of Trump voters reported feeling hopeful and proud about the election results [6].

Conversely, Clinton voters experienced a wave of negative emotions. "Shocked" was a frequently used descriptor, followed by "disappointed" and "disgusted" [8].  The sense of shock and disbelief was palpable, with many Clinton supporters also expressing feelings of sadness, fear, and unease in response to Trump's victory [6]. The contrasting emotional responses are starkly evident when comparing the words chosen by each group to describe their reactions ![Words like "Shocked", "Disappointed", and "Disgusted" were frequently used by Clinton voters, contrasting sharply with the positive emotions of Trump voters.](image3).  Overall, a considerable portion of all voters reported feeling uneasy about the election outcome [10].

Adding to this charged atmosphere, the 2016 election was widely perceived as exceptionally negative, dominated by mudslinging [7]. An overwhelming majority of voters believed there was more negative campaigning compared to previous elections ![A large majority of voters felt there was more mudslinging in the 2016 election.](image1).  Interestingly, despite the intense emotions and negative campaign environment, voters did not give high marks to many of the key players in the election, including both the Republican and Democratic parties, and even Donald Trump himself.  The average grades given to Trump and the Republican Party were quite low ![Average grades for Trump and the Republican Party were low, indicating a general disapproval of campaign conduct.](image4).

In conclusion, the emotional responses to the 2016 election highlighted a stark divide between Trump and Clinton voters, with Trump supporters experiencing positive feelings like hope and pride, while Clinton supporters felt shock, disappointment, and unease, all within the context of a campaign widely seen as negative and marked by mudslinging, which resulted in low grades for many involved.

Voters from both sides expressed surprise at Donald Trump's victory, with a significant majority of all voters, including 87% of Clinton supporters and 60% of Trump supporters, reporting they were surprised by the outcome [3].  This sense of surprise is visually represented, showing that 67% of all voters were surprised, compared to 60% of Trump voters and a larger 77% of Clinton voters who felt the same ![This image illustrates the percentage of voters from different groups who were surprised by Trump's victory](image2).  When asked to describe their reaction in a single word, "happy" was the most common response among Trump voters, alongside mentions of "surprise" and "shock" [8]. In stark contrast, Clinton voters frequently used words like "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" to summarize their feelings [7].  A detailed breakdown of these one-word reactions further emphasizes this emotional divide, illustrating the frequency of positive terms like "Happy," "Hopeful," and "Relieved" among Trump voters, and negative terms such as "Shocked," "Disappointed," and "Disgusted" among Clinton voters, showcasing the divergent emotional landscapes following the election results ![This image displays word clouds representing the most frequent one-word reactions to Trump's victory from both Trump and Clinton voters, highlighting the emotional disparity between the two groups](image3).  These emotional reactions reveal that the election outcome defied expectations for a large portion of both voter bases, leading to sharply contrasting feelings of elation and dismay. The emotional reactions to Trump's victory underscore the differing pre-election expectations between Trump and Clinton voters, characterized by widespread surprise and a stark contrast between positive and negative emotional responses.

Despite the shared surprise at Donald Trump's unexpected victory, sentiments diverged sharply between voter groups.  A significant majority of voters, including 73% overall, expressed surprise, with this reaching 87% among Clinton supporters and 60% of Trump voters [5, 9].

![Surprise was a common reaction, but less so for Trump voters compared to Clinton voters.](image1)

While "surprise" was a common descriptor, the underlying emotions differed drastically.  Trump voters frequently used terms like "happy," "hopeful," and "relieved" to summarize their feelings, whereas Clinton voters leaned towards "shocked," "disappointed," and "sad" [2, image4].

![Trump voters' feelings leaned positive, while Clinton voters' feelings were largely negative, reflecting the election outcome.](image4)

This divergence is further emphasized by the fact that 97% of Trump voters reported happiness about his win, contrasted with 93% of Clinton voters expressing unhappiness [7].  However, in a point of convergence, voters largely agreed on the future possibility of a female president; a substantial 79% anticipated a female president within their lifetime, with no significant differences between men and women, or Trump and Clinton supporters [1].

In conclusion, while both Trump and Clinton voters were largely surprised by the election outcome, their sentiments diverged significantly, with Trump voters expressing happiness and Clinton voters unhappiness, yet both groups shared similar expectations for a female president in the future.

Public perception regarding government efforts against terrorism has shifted notably.  Americans' overall ratings of the government's work in reducing terrorist threats are currently at their lowest point since the attacks of September 11, 2001 [2].  A significant drop in positive evaluations has occurred across the political spectrum since early 2015 [3].  This decline is evident across party lines, with positive ratings decreasing among Democrats, Independents, and Republicans alike [3].

![Trend of public concern shifting towards government policies not going far enough to protect the country over time](image3)

Interestingly, concerns about government policies potentially overreaching and restricting civil liberties have diminished since Edward Snowden's disclosures in 2013 [8].  In fact, there's been a shift in public sentiment towards a greater worry that anti-terrorism policies are insufficient in protecting the nation [10].  This shift is particularly pronounced among Republicans [4]. Currently, a majority of Americans express more concern about policies not going far enough rather than going too far [10].

![Breakdown of public concern about anti-terrorism policies by age groups](image2)

Examining political affiliations, consistent proportions of conservative Republicans, moderate/liberal Republicans, and conservative/moderate Democrats share the apprehension that anti-terrorism policies are not extensive enough [1].  However, liberal Democrats are divided, with equal shares concerned about policies going too far and not far enough [1].  Notably, Democrats are now the only political group where a majority still rates government efforts positively, although this positive view has also decreased [3].

![Comparison of government performance ratings by political parties](image4)

Age also plays a role in these perceptions. Older Americans, particularly those 50 and above, are more likely to give negative ratings to government anti-terrorism efforts compared to younger adults [6, 9].  Conversely, younger adults tend to be more positive in their evaluations [6].

![Detailed breakdown of government performance ratings by age, education and political affiliation](image5)

In conclusion, public perception of government efforts against terrorism has become more negative over time, with a prevailing concern that policies are not going far enough, and these perceptions vary across political affiliations and age groups, with older individuals and Republicans expressing greater skepticism.

Age and political viewpoints significantly shape how people perceive the government's actions against terrorism.  Younger adults, particularly those under 30, express a greater worry that the government might be overstepping its bounds in anti-terrorism policies, demonstrated by their concerns about excessive restrictions on civil liberties [3]. In contrast, older age groups are more inclined to believe the government isn't doing enough to ensure national security [1]. This is further supported by data showing that older individuals are more likely to rate government anti-terrorism efforts negatively [6], with a majority of those over 50 expressing dissatisfaction with the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats [10].  ![Older individuals are more concerned that government anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country](image2).

Political affiliation also plays a crucial role.  Republicans are notably more critical of government efforts compared to Democrats, while Independents fall somewhere in the middle, as visualized in the varying levels of approval across party lines ![Independent, Republican and Democrat groups have different levels of approval on government anti-terror policies](image1).  Over time, there's been a shift in these perceptions.  While concerns about government overreach on civil liberties were higher in 2013, following revelations about NSA surveillance [8], the prevailing sentiment has shifted towards a greater worry that the government isn't doing enough to protect the country [5].  This trend is evident across the political spectrum, with negative assessments of government efforts increasing among Democrats, Independents, and Republicans alike since early 2015 [7].  ![Trend of concern that government policies have not gone far enough to protect the country is rising while concern on government overreach is decreasing](image5).  In conclusion, age and political ideology are key determinants in how individuals evaluate government anti-terrorism efforts, and these perceptions are dynamic, evolving alongside events and political climates, generally showing a growing concern that the government is not doing enough to counter terrorism.

Older Americans are generally less satisfied with the government's efforts in reducing terrorist threats compared to their younger counterparts [2].  For example, a majority of individuals aged 50 and above feel the government is underperforming in this area, while younger adults are more divided in their assessment [4].  This difference in opinion across age groups is clearly visualized in the varying ratings of government performance. ![Shows the percentage of different age groups rating government performance positively or negatively](image4).  When it comes to the balance between civil liberties and security, adults under 30 are notably split, showing nearly equal concern for both excessive restrictions on civil liberties and inadequate protection against terrorism [10]. However, older demographics, particularly those 65 and older, lean more towards prioritizing security over civil liberties.  This inclination is further demonstrated when examining the varying levels of concern about anti-terrorism policies going "too far" versus "not far enough" across different age groups. ![Shows the percentage of different age groups concerned about civil liberties vs. security](image5).  In conclusion, older Americans are more critical of the government’s anti-terrorism performance and prioritize security more than civil liberties compared to younger Americans in 2015.

Public concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has decreased significantly since July 2013 [2], a period marked by Edward Snowden's revelations about NSA surveillance.  This shift is visually represented in the trend from 2004 to 2015, demonstrating a move from greater concern about policies restricting civil liberties to a stronger worry that policies are insufficient for national protection ![Trend of Americans' concern about government anti-terrorism policies from 2004 to 2015, showing a shift towards concern that policies do not go far enough.](image2). Republicans and Democrats have both become more inclined to believe that anti-terrorism policies are not sufficiently robust since Snowden's disclosures in 2013; however, this shift is more marked among Republicans [4].  Examining the trends across political affiliations reveals diverging opinions, particularly between Republicans, Democrats and Independents over time ![Trend of concern about anti-terrorism policies by political party from 2004 to 2015, illustrating diverging opinions between Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image3).  Currently, opinions vary across age groups; while adults under 30 are divided in their concerns, majorities in older age brackets express greater worry about the lack of adequate protection rather than excessive restrictions on civil liberties [8].  This is further illustrated by the breakdown of opinions across different age demographics, showing how concerns about civil liberties versus protection vary with age ![Breakdown of opinions on anti-terrorism policies by age group, revealing variations in concern about civil liberties versus protection.](image4).

In summary, public opinion has shifted towards greater concern that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country, with this trend being more pronounced among Republicans and older age groups compared to Democrats and younger adults.

Public perception surrounding the U.S. military campaign against ISIS presents a complex perspective.  Although current evaluations of the campaign remain largely unfavorable, with a significant portion indicating it's progressing "not too well" or "not at all well" as of December 2015 ![A bar chart showing that in December 2015, 58% of people think the US effort against ISIS is going not too well or not at all well](image4) [4], there's a consistent approval of the military action itself [6], a trend that has held steady since August 2014 ![A line chart showing that approval of the US military campaign against ISIS has remained steady at around 63-64% from Aug 2014 to Dec 2015](image2).  Notably, despite these persistent negative ratings of the present campaign status [1], there is a growing optimism regarding the eventual success of the U.S. and its allies [9], with two-thirds now expressing belief in ultimate success, marking an increase from 55% in July 2015 ![A bar chart showing that the percentage of people who believe the US and its allies will definitely or probably succeed in the campaign against ISIS increased from 55% in July 2015 to 66% in December 2015](image5).  Political affiliations play a role in shaping these perceptions, with Democrats showing a higher likelihood of viewing the current campaign favorably compared to Republicans [2]. However, when considering the long-term prospects of the campaign's success, partisan divides diminish [2], although Republicans express greater concern that the U.S. might not be assertive enough in combating ISIS ![A bar chart showing that 75% of Republican are concerned that the US will not go far enough to stop ISIS](image3) and consider ISIS as a more critical issue compared to Democrats and Independents ![A bar chart comparing the level of concern about ISIS issue across Republican, Democrat and Independent](image1).
