Advanced RAG represents an evolution, introducing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies to significantly enhance the quality of information retrieval [1]. Indexing techniques are refined through methods like sliding windows, fine-grained segmentation, and metadata incorporation [1].  ![Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG by adding rewrite and rerank modules to the retrieval process.](image1)  These enhancements address the shortcomings of Naive RAG by optimizing the retrieval process [1].

Modular RAG marks a further progression, offering remarkable adaptability by allowing module substitution and reconfiguration [5].  It moves beyond the fixed structures of its predecessors, incorporating specialized components such as Search, Memory, Routing, Predict, and Task Adapter modules to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities [7]. The flexibility of Modular RAG is evident in its capacity to adjust module arrangements and interactions dynamically, as seen in frameworks like Demonstrate-Search-Predict (DSP) and iterative Retrieve-Read flows, showcasing sophisticated module synergy [6].  ![Modular RAG allows for flexible orchestration of modules, enhancing adaptability and versatility compared to Naive and Advanced RAG.](image1) This modularity supports adaptive retrieval and allows for easier integration with other technologies, pushing beyond the limitations of fixed retrieval processes [6].  The progression from Naive RAG to Modular RAG showcases an increasing sophistication in handling document retrieval and query processing, with Modular RAG offering a highly adaptable architecture compared to the more linear approaches of Naive and Advanced RAG [10].

In summary, Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG frameworks differ in their approach to document retrieval and query processing through increasing levels of sophistication and adaptability in their architectures and methodologies.

The RAPTOR system incorporates two distinct querying approaches: tree traversal and collapsed tree methods [9].  The collapsed tree retrieval method has been shown to outperform tree traversal in experiments [10]. The advantage of collapsed tree retrieval lies in its flexibility; by searching through all nodes concurrently, it can retrieve information at the most relevant level of detail for a given question [10]. In contrast, tree traversal maintains a consistent ratio between high-level thematic information and granular details, regardless of the query’s nature [10]. ![Collapsed tree retrieval shows better performance than tree traversal with varying context lengths](image3).

When comparing RAPTOR with Dense Passage Retrieval (DPR) methods, RAPTOR generally demonstrates superior performance [1, 2, 6, 8]. RAPTOR’s tree-based retrieval process allows it to select nodes from different layers of the tree, aligning with the question's level of detail, often yielding more pertinent and thorough information compared to DPR [7]. ![RAPTOR retrieves more relevant information for questions compared to DPR](image1).  On the QASPER dataset specifically, RAPTOR consistently surpasses both DPR and BM25 across various Language Models [2, 6]. As shown in Table 3, RAPTOR's F-1 scores are consistently higher than DPR and BM25 when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA [2, 6]. This is attributed to QASPER's requirement for synthesizing information within NLP papers, a task for which RAPTOR’s hierarchical summaries are better suited compared to methods that only extract the top-k most similar raw text segments [2].  RAPTOR also achieves better accuracy on the QuALITY dataset when compared to DPR and BM25 [4]. ![Table comparing the accuracy and F1 scores of RAPTOR, DPR, and BM25 on the QUALITY and QASPER datasets](image4).

In conclusion, collapsed tree retrieval is more effective than tree traversal, and RAPTOR, utilizing a tree-based structure, outperforms DPR in terms of performance on the QASPER dataset and other evaluation metrics.

RAPTOR employs two distinct methods for querying its tree structure: tree traversal and collapsed tree [6, 10].  The performance of these methods across different context lengths reveals that the collapsed tree approach consistently outperforms tree traversal, as visualized in Figure 3 ![Collapsed tree outperforms tree traversal at various context lengths](image3). This is attributed to the collapsed tree method's enhanced flexibility, allowing it to search all nodes concurrently and retrieve information at the most suitable level of granularity for each question [5, 7].  Furthermore, RAPTOR's performance is evaluated using metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR, demonstrating robust results across different models; for instance, when RAPTOR is paired with SBERT, it achieves a METEOR score of 19.20% [image6, 3].  In terms of ROUGE and BLEU scores, RAPTOR with SBERT also shows competitive results, achieving a ROUGE score of 30.87% and a BLEU-1 score of 23.50% [image6]. In summary, the collapsed tree retrieval method is superior to tree traversal in terms of performance across different context lengths, and RAPTOR exhibits strong performance in ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR metrics.

RAPTOR’s performance is assessed using a variety of metrics to thoroughly evaluate its capabilities. On the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR paired with UnifiedQA excels, achieving not only higher scores than BM25 and DPR but also establishing a new state-of-the-art in METEOR metric [4].  This improvement is consistently seen across different Language Models (LLMs), including GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, where RAPTOR demonstrates superior F-1 Match scores compared to BM25 and DPR [5].  ![Comparison of metrics with and without RAPTOR for different retrieval methods, showing consistent improvements when RAPTOR is used](image1).  Looking at a broader comparison with other state-of-the-art systems, RAPTOR coupled with UnifiedQA achieves a METEOR score of 19.1, outperforming other models in this metric [8].

For effective querying, RAPTOR employs a collapsed tree approach with a maximum token limit of 2000 [6]. The context length plays a role in tree traversal strategies, with options like 1000 and 1500 tokens impacting performance [image2].  Additionally, the depth of tree traversal, indicated by the number of layers queried, influences the outcomes [image3].

In summary, RAPTOR consistently shows enhanced performance across various evaluation metrics when integrated with different retrieval methods, and the context length is a relevant factor in optimizing tree traversal within its architecture.

The RAPTOR retrieval system demonstrates notable performance improvements over traditional methods like BM25 and DPR across a variety of datasets and metrics, as evidenced in multiple evaluations.  Specifically, when assessing accuracy on the QUALITY dataset, RAPTOR consistently surpasses both BM25 and DPR, achieving higher scores when paired with both GPT-3 and UnifiedQA models, highlighting its effectiveness across different language models ![RAPTOR accuracy outperforms BM25 and DPR on the QUALITY dataset.](image2).  This trend of outperformance is further substantiated on the QASPER dataset, where RAPTOR exhibits superior F-1 scores compared to BM25 and DPR across GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, indicating its robust performance regardless of the language model employed [3, 6].

For instance, when considering the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR not only exceeds the performance of BM25 and DPR in metrics like ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, but also establishes a new state-of-the-art in METEOR score when combined with UnifiedQA 3B [1, 2].  The improvements are quantitatively significant; RAPTOR's ROUGE-L score is notably higher than BM25 and DPR, and it consistently outperforms them across BLEU and METEOR metrics as well ![RAPTOR excels in ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR metrics compared to other methods.](image3).  These quantitative advantages are supported by qualitative analysis, which reveals that RAPTOR’s tree-based retrieval mechanism enables it to select nodes from various tree layers, aligning with the question's level of detail more effectively than DPR, which often retrieves less comprehensive raw text chunks [7, 8]. This is visually represented in illustrations comparing RAPTOR's and DPR's retrieval processes for thematic questions ![RAPTOR and DPR retrieval comparison for thematic questions.](image4). Furthermore, integrating RAPTOR with different retrievers such as SBERT, BM25, and DPR consistently enhances their performance on both the QUALITY and QASPER datasets, as shown by improved accuracy and F1 scores respectively ![RAPTOR improves accuracy and F1 scores when combined with different retrievers.](image1). In essence, RAPTOR stands out as a superior retrieval system, consistently outperforming BM25 and DPR across different datasets and evaluation metrics by leveraging a hierarchical tree structure for more effective contextual information retrieval [4, 5].  RAPTOR generally outperforms BM25 and DPR in terms of retrieval performance across various datasets and metrics.

RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance over traditional retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR across various datasets and evaluation metrics [9]. In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR significantly surpasses BM25 and DPR in ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR scores, indicating improved text generation quality [1].  ![RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR in both Model Accuracy (QUALITY) and Answer F1 (QASPER)](image1).  This enhanced performance is also evident in the QASPER dataset, where RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR when paired with different Language Models such as GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, achieving higher F-1 Match scores [4, 5].

The tree-based structure of RAPTOR, created through recursive clustering and summarization, is crucial to its effectiveness [9].  This structure allows RAPTOR to synthesize information from different levels of abstraction, which is particularly beneficial for complex, multi-hop queries that require a broader understanding of the text [3].  As depicted, RAPTOR, when combined with various retrievers like SBERT, BM25, and DPR, consistently enhances their performance across metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR [6]. ![RAPTOR improves performance of different models in ROUGE, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, METEOR metrics](image6).  The higher-level summary nodes in RAPTOR's architecture enable it to outperform methods that rely solely on top-k raw text chunks, which may lack the necessary context for answering complex questions [4].

Furthermore, RAPTOR achieves state-of-the-art results, setting new benchmarks in certain metrics. For example, RAPTOR paired with UnifiedQA achieves a new state-of-the-art METEOR score on the Narrative QA dataset, even surpassing other recursively summarizing models [7, 10].  On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark with a 55.7% F-1 score, outperforming other advanced models like CoLT5 XL [8]. ![RAPTOR achieves higher accuracy than BM25 and DPR in both GPT-3 Acc. and UnifiedQA Acc.](image7).  The hierarchical structure allows RAPTOR to capture both general themes and specific details, contributing to its robust performance across different question-answering tasks [10].

RAPTOR consistently outperforms other retrieval methods due to its hierarchical tree structure that effectively synthesizes information across different levels of abstraction, leading to improved performance metrics across various datasets.

RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance compared to other models, particularly when considering F-1 Match and accuracy metrics across various language models.  In the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms both BM25 and DPR in F-1 Match scores, irrespective of whether it's paired with GPT-3, GPT-4, or UnifiedQA, achieving margins of at least 1.8% over DPR and 5.3% over BM25 [8].  This advantage is visually represented, showing RAPTOR consistently achieving higher F-1 Match scores than BM25 and DPR across different language models. ![RAPTOR F-1 Match scores are higher than BM25 and DPR across different language models](image4). Similarly, when evaluating accuracy on the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR paired with GPT-3 and UnifiedQA surpasses BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% [9].  This trend is further supported by data highlighting RAPTOR's accuracy exceeding that of BM25 and DPR when used with both GPT-3 and UnifiedQA language models. ![RAPTOR's accuracy is better than BM25 and DPR when using GPT-3 and UnifiedQA](image2). Notably, RAPTOR, especially when combined with GPT-4, establishes new state-of-the-art results, achieving a 55.7% F-1 score on QASPER, outperforming CoLT5 XL [10], and reaching an impressive 82.6% accuracy on the QuALITY dataset, significantly exceeding CoLISA's performance by 21.5% [3]. The remarkable accuracy of RAPTOR with GPT-4 on the QuALITY dataset, especially when compared to models like Longformer-base, DPR with DeBERTaV3-large, and CoLISA, is evident. ![RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieves the highest accuracy on the QuALITY dataset, outperforming Longformer-base, DPR, DeBERTaV3-large and CoLISA](image5). In summary, RAPTOR generally exhibits enhanced F-1 Match and accuracy scores compared to models like BM25, DPR, CoLT5 XL and CoLISA when integrated with various language models.

RAPTOR demonstrates robust performance improvements across various datasets. On the QASPER dataset, which requires synthesizing information from NLP papers, RAPTOR consistently outperforms methods like BM25 and DPR with different language models, achieving F-1 scores of $53.1\%$, $55.7\%$, and $36.6\%$ when paired with GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA respectively, surpassing DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points [4].  ![RAPTOR's F-1 score is consistently higher than BM25 and DPR across different Language Models on the QASPER dataset](image2). Furthermore, RAPTOR sets a new benchmark on QASPER when combined with GPT-4, achieving a $55.7\%$ F-1 score, which is superior to CoLT5 XL's score of $53.9\%$ [3].  ![RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieves a higher F-1 score than other models on QASPER dataset](image5).

In the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR also shows significant improvements in accuracy. It achieves an accuracy of $62.4\%$, outperforming DPR and BM25 by $2\%$ and $5.1\%$ respectively [7].  When paired with GPT-4, RAPTOR achieves a state-of-the-art accuracy of $82.6\%$ on the QuALITY dataset, significantly surpassing the previous best result of $62.3\%$ [8]. ![RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on the QUALITY dataset](image4).  The benefits of using RAPTOR are also evident when comparing performance with and without RAPTOR integration across different retrievers. For example, SBERT with RAPTOR achieves a 56.6% accuracy on QUALITY, compared to 54.9% without RAPTOR [6].

For the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR paired with UnifiedQA establishes a new state-of-the-art METEOR score and surpasses other recursive summarization models across multiple metrics like ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, and BLEU-4 [2, 6].  ![RAPTOR achieves superior performance on Narrative QA compared to other models across ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR metrics](image7).  These results collectively highlight RAPTOR's effectiveness in enhancing retrieval and question-answering performance across diverse datasets and evaluation metrics when integrated with various language models.

RAPTOR consistently enhances performance across different datasets and evaluation metrics when used with various models, often achieving state-of-the-art results.

RAPTOR showcases robust performance across a range of evaluation metrics and datasets, consistently outperforming traditional retrieval methods.  Specifically, on the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR surpasses BM25 and DPR by significant margins in metrics such as ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR [1].  ![RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance over SBERT, BM25 and DPR across ROUGE, BLEU and METEOR metrics](image1).  Notably, RAPTOR paired with UnifiedQA establishes a new state-of-the-art METEOR score on this dataset [5, 9]. In the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR also sets a new benchmark, achieving a higher F-1 score than CoLT5 XL [2].  ![RAPTOR exhibits higher accuracy and answer F1 compared to BM25 and DPR baselines](image3).  Compared to other models like recursively summarizing models, RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance across all metrics, benefiting from its hierarchical tree structure that captures both general themes and specific details [3].  Even when evaluated using only titles and abstracts, RAPTOR maintains its performance advantage over BM25 and DPR on the QASPER dataset [8].  ![RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieves the best accuracy on both the entire test set and its hard subset](image4).  RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval system effectively augments language models with multi-level contextual information, leading to enhanced performance in question-answering tasks compared to other models [10].  In summary, RAPTOR performs exceptionally well across various evaluation metrics and datasets, consistently outperforming other models.

The evaluation process for assessing model responses involves multiple annotators to ensure reliability, and generally, these annotators show a high level of agreement, particularly on objective aspects of the responses [1, 10]. Questions about task fulfillment are crucial in these evaluations [6], with annotators judging whether a response completely, partially, or does not fulfill the prompt's task [image4]. When comparing Chameleon to baseline models, the inter-annotator agreement reveals interesting patterns.  A notable portion of comparisons, roughly 10% of cases, shows no agreement among the three annotators, which is considered a tie in the evaluation [9]. This suggests that in a non-negligible number of instances, distinguishing between the models is challenging, leading to varied perceptions among annotators.  The detailed breakdown of agreement levels when comparing Chameleon to Gemini+ and GPT-4V+, as well as their original versions, highlights the nuances in human evaluations [image2].  Despite the presence of ties and instances where annotators disagree, a substantial portion of evaluations, between 28% to 35%, shows unanimous agreement among all three annotators, demonstrating a considerable level of consensus in many judgments [9]. In summary, while there's a good level of inter-annotator agreement on task fulfillment and relevance when comparing models to Chameleon, a notable portion of evaluations result in ties or disagreements, indicating the complexity of relative model assessment.

Inter-annotator agreement was assessed to ensure the quality and reliability of evaluations for Chameleon and its baselines [7].  In relative evaluations, where Chameleon was directly compared to other models, annotators showed varying levels of agreement. For instance, in comparisons between Chameleon and Gemini+ or GPT-4V+, there was no agreement among all three annotators in slightly over 10% of cases, while unanimous judgments occurred in about 28% to 35% of cases. In a majority of instances, approximately 55% to 60%, two out of three annotators were in agreement [1].  This distribution of agreement levels can be visualized in tabular form, detailing the specific counts and percentages of agreement for Chameleon against different baselines like Gemini+ and GPT-4V+ across categories of full agreement, two-annotator agreement, and no agreement ![Shows the percentage of agreement among annotators for relative evaluations between Chameleon and baselines.](image2).

Absolute evaluations, where each model's output was judged independently, showed high agreement, especially for objective properties such as the presence of objectionable content.  In these cases, annotators almost always reached unanimous judgments [2].  Figure 10, although not provided here, further illustrates the levels of agreement for each question in the absolute evaluations [3].  Task fulfillment was a critical question in absolute evaluations, and while disagreements sometimes occurred, they were often between close judgments rather than opposite ones [4].  The task fulfillment rate for Chameleon and comparison models in absolute evaluation is depicted, highlighting the percentage of responses that fully, partially, or do not fulfill the task ![Illustrates the task fulfillment rates for Chameleon and baseline models in absolute evaluations.](image1).

In conclusion, inter-annotator agreement varied between relative and absolute evaluations; relative evaluations showed moderate agreement levels, while absolute evaluations, particularly for objective aspects, exhibited high agreement.

During relative evaluations, annotators' agreement offers insights into the consistency and reliability of model comparisons. In comparisons between Chameleon and other models, agreement levels vary. For instance, when comparing Chameleon against Gemini and GPT-4V, unanimous agreement among all three annotators occurred in approximately 28.6% to 35.4% of cases, with two out of three annotators agreeing in about 55.2% to 59.3% of instances, and no agreement among annotators in roughly 9.3% to 13.1% of cases as shown in the confusion matrix. ![This image shows the agreement level between annotators when comparing Chameleon to Gemini and GPT-4V, categorized into "All 3 annotators agree," "2 of 3 annotators agree," and "No Agreement."](image1) This suggests that in a significant portion of evaluations, opinions on model performance are not entirely consistent, highlighting the challenges in definitively distinguishing model superiority.

Regarding safety evaluations, Chameleon models demonstrate high safety ratings, with the majority of responses deemed safe across different parameter sizes and datasets.  For crowdsourced prompts, the 7B parameter model shows 99.2% safe responses, while the 34B model increases to 99.7% safe responses. Even with red teaming efforts to elicit unsafe content, the 34B model maintains a 93.9% safety rate.  The trend suggests that larger parameter models like the 34B version are associated with a slight increase in safety compared to the 7B model, across both crowdsourced and red team evaluations. ![This image displays a table showing the safety evaluation of Chameleon models with 7B and 34B parameters on crowdsourced and Red Team datasets, indicating the percentage of safe, unsafe, and unsure responses.](image3)

In summary, annotator agreement in Chameleon comparisons is moderate, indicating evaluation complexity, while safety evaluations reveal high safety ratings for Chameleon, with larger models showing marginally improved safety performance.

Chameleon models demonstrate strong safety metrics, with the 7B parameter model achieving a 99.2% safe rate and the 34B model even higher at 99.7% [image4]. This high safety performance is paired with robust capabilities in commonsense reasoning, where Chameleon-34B notably outperforms Llama-2 70B in 5 out of 8 tasks [3].  In benchmarks assessing world knowledge and problem-solving, such as MMLU, both Chameleon models surpass their Llama-2 counterparts, with the 34B variant approaching the performance levels of Mixtral 8x7B and Gemini-Pro [5].

![Safety rates for Chameleon 7B and 34B models, showing very high safe percentages.](image4)

Furthermore, in math-related tasks, both models exhibit strong capabilities; for example, Chameleon-34B surpasses Llama2-70B and even Mixtral 8x7B on the GSM8k benchmark [6]. Detailed performance across a range of commonsense reasoning and math benchmarks, including PIQA, SIQA, HellaSwag, WinoGrande, GSM8k, and MATH, is presented, showcasing the competitive edge of Chameleon models against other models like Llama-2, Mistral, and Gemini [image5].

![Detailed benchmark results comparing Chameleon models against Llama-2, Mistral, and Gemini in commonsense reasoning and math tasks.](image5)

In summary, Chameleon models, particularly the 34B version, exhibit excellent safety alongside strong performance in both commonsense reasoning and math tasks, outperforming or matching many larger models in benchmark evaluations.

The RAR (Retrieving and Ranking) augmented method significantly improves the performance of the LLaVA1.5 model in fine-grained visual recognition tasks.  As demonstrated in the 4-shot setting, RAR (LLaVA1.5) achieves an average top-1 accuracy of 60.9% on fine-grained datasets, a notable increase from the CLIP initial retrieval result of 55.6% [1]. This improvement is further emphasized when considering the 8-shot setting, where RAR (LLaVA1.5) reaches 67.7% accuracy, compared to CLIP’s 61.8% ![RAR (LLaVA1.5) achieves higher accuracy than CLIP+KNN and LLaVA1.5 Finetuning on fine-grained datasets in 4-shot setting](image1).  This enhancement highlights RAR's ability to discern subtle differences in categories through its ranking process, effectively utilizing contextual understanding [1].  In zero-shot object recognition, RAR (LLaVA1.5) also shows a clear advantage, achieving an AP of 8.6, surpassing the CLIP w/ box baseline which scores 7.2 in average precision ![RAR (LLaVA1.5) outperforms CLIP w/ box in zero-shot object recognition based on AP metric](image5).  The integration of the retrieving and ranking mechanism in RAR enhances the LLaVA1.5 model's capabilities in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition tasks.

The RAR approach is designed to enhance zero-shot recognition, particularly for datasets with extensive and fine-grained vocabularies [8]. Benchmarks reveal that RAR significantly improves zero-shot object recognition performance. Specifically, on the LVIS dataset, RAR achieves a $6.4\%$ improvement, and on the V3Det dataset, it gains $1.5\%$ in zero-shot object recognition performance [5].  This is particularly notable given the complexity of V3Det, which encompasses 13,204 distinct classes, demonstrating RAR's effectiveness in navigating large and detailed category landscapes [9]. The use of MLLMs for ranking, augmented by retrieval mechanisms, is crucial for this performance enhancement [9].

The experimental results, as presented in tables, highlight the performance differences between CLIP and RAR models across various Average Precision (AP) metrics. ![This table shows the performance metrics of CLIP and RAR models, indicating the improvements achieved by RAR in different AP categories.](image1) and ![This table shows another set of performance metrics comparing CLIP, RegionCLIP and RAR models, further illustrating RAR's performance gains in different AP metrics.](image2). These tables clearly show that RAR consistently outperforms the baseline CLIP models.  This improvement is visually supported by examples showing how RAR refines object predictions in large vocabulary scenarios, moving from less accurate initial predictions to more precise labels like correctly identifying a "doughnut" instead of just "pastry" ![This image illustrates the motivation for RAR and showcases improved detection results with RAR in large vocabulary datasets, highlighting the refinement from general categories to specific ones.](image3). The method's efficacy stems from its retrieving and reranking mechanism, which allows MLLMs to access a richer context from external memory, especially beneficial for identifying rare classes [7]. For instance, retrieved candidates are reranked to prioritize more accurate labels such as "earring" and "polo_shirt" over broader or less relevant terms, showcasing the precision RAR brings to object recognition ![This image displays examples of retrieved and reranked object labels, demonstrating how RAR refines initial retrieval results to more accurate and relevant classifications.](image4).

In summary, RAR models significantly improve zero-shot object recognition by enhancing the precision and relevance of object labels, especially in datasets with large and fine-grained vocabularies, outperforming baseline models like CLIP in terms of accuracy and detailed classification.

To efficiently recognize objects in detection datasets, the multimodal retriever system first focuses on retrieving relevant information by querying a large database [3]. For object detection datasets, a specific pre-processing step is applied, involving cropping images based on proposal bounding box coordinates and using blurring techniques on non-target areas to direct focus to the objects of interest [8]. This pre-processing is crucial because cropped sub-images in detection datasets are often small, which limits the effectiveness of direct image-to-image retrieval. Therefore, the system uses CLIP’s image-text interaction capabilities to perform image-to-text retrieval to obtain the top-k category information [6]. As illustrated in ![Pre-processing steps including bounding boxes and category retrieval for object detection](image4), the system processes bounding boxes to isolate objects and retrieves category labels for each.  Subsequently, the retrieved category labels and image embeddings are integrated and passed to Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) for ranking [5]. MLLMs utilize their linguistic and semantic analysis abilities to evaluate the contextual appropriateness of each class name with the input image and refine the ranking [4]. The entire process of retrieval and ranking by MLLMs is depicted in ![Diagram showing multimodal retriever, database, retrieval and ranking stages](image3).  In summary, the multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects in detection datasets through pre-processing steps like cropping and blurring, followed by image-to-text retrieval for category suggestions, and finally, ranking these suggestions using MLLMs for accurate recognition.

The error analysis reveals distinct outcomes for Step-Back + RAG when applied to TimeQA and StrategyQA datasets. In TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG demonstrates a substantial ability to rectify errors from the baseline model, correcting $39.9\%$ of incorrect predictions, while only introducing errors in $5.6\%$ of cases [4]. Furthermore, it effectively addresses errors originating from RAG itself, fixing $21.6\%$ of them, with a modest $6.3\%$ error introduction to RAG [4]. This is visually summarized, highlighting the proportions of correct and incorrect predictions in relation to Step-Back and RAG. ![Error analysis comparison between Step-Back, RAG and Baseline models](image2). In contrast, for StrategyQA, the improvements are less pronounced; Step-Back + RAG corrects $15.4\%$ of baseline errors and introduces $6.1\%$ new errors [10].  Similarly, it fixes $12.7\%$ of RAG errors, with a $4.4\%$ error introduction to RAG [10].  This discrepancy is further emphasized by the visualization of error types and their distribution in StrategyQA. ![Error type distribution in StrategyQA](image1).  Notably, in TimeQA, error analysis points to reasoning and retrieval augmentation failures as dominant error sources, with a significant portion attributed to retrieval issues despite the abstraction provided by Step-Back, indicating the inherent challenges of the TimeQA task [6]. TimeQA is designed for temporal reasoning, while StrategyQA involves more complex multi-hop reasoning [7]. The datasets differ in size and nature, as TimeQA is a knowledge QA dataset, whereas StrategyQA is geared towards strategic question answering [7, image5]. The differing error analysis outcomes suggest that while Step-Back + RAG enhances both, its impact is significantly greater on TimeQA, possibly because the abstraction step is particularly beneficial for temporal reasoning and knowledge retrieval in TimeQA, whereas the complexities of strategic multi-hop reasoning in StrategyQA pose different challenges that are less directly addressed by Step-Back prompting.

In summary, error analysis for Step-Back + RAG shows more pronounced improvements in TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, indicating a varying effectiveness of the approach depending on the dataset and task complexity.

The 'Step-Back' prompting method demonstrates notable improvements in performance, particularly on knowledge-intensive tasks such as TimeQA and SituatedQA [7, 10].  Compared to baseline models like PaLM-2L and other prompting techniques like Chain of Thought (CoT) and Take a Deep Breathe (TDB), 'Step-Back' prompting, especially when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), achieves significantly higher accuracy [4]. For example, on TimeQA, baseline models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2L achieved accuracies of $45.6\%$ and $41.5\%$ respectively, while 'Step-Back + RAG' reached a remarkable $68.7\%$ [4].

![Step-Back and Step-Back + RAG achieve the highest accuracy on TimeQA and SituatedQA compared to other methods.](image1)

This table visually represents the superior performance of 'Step-Back' and 'Step-Back + RAG' methods across various benchmarks, including TimeQA and SituatedQA, compared to PaLM-2L with different prompting techniques and GPT-4.  Error analysis reveals that 'Step-Back' prompting effectively corrects a substantial portion of errors made by baseline models and even RAG alone [5].  Specifically, it can fix approximately $39.9\%$ of errors from baseline predictions and $21.6\%$ of errors from RAG [5].  However, it's also important to note that 'Step-Back' prompting can introduce new errors, although the rate of error introduction is relatively low, around $5.6\%$ compared to baseline and $6.3\%$ compared to RAG [5].

![Step-Back prompting introduces 'StepBack Wrong' errors alongside other error types.](image3)

This chart illustrates the error distribution associated with 'Step-Back' prompting, highlighting that while it introduces 'StepBack' related errors, it also addresses errors stemming from reasoning and RAG. Despite these new errors, the overall impact of 'Step-Back' prompting is overwhelmingly positive, leading to significant performance gains and demonstrating its effectiveness in improving accuracy on complex question-answering tasks [5, 10].  Furthermore, the method exhibits robustness against the number of exemplars used in few-shot learning, indicating its sample efficiency [9].

In conclusion, 'Step-Back' prompting, especially when integrated with RAG, generally outperforms baseline models and other prompting methods by enhancing accuracy and rectifying errors, although it may introduce a small percentage of new errors; its effectiveness is validated across different benchmarks in knowledge-based question answering.

Large language models like PaLM-2L and GPT-4 show varied baseline performance across different Question Answering (QA) tasks. For instance, on MuSiQue, a challenging multihop reasoning benchmark, their performance is relatively low, with PaLM-2L at $35.5\%$ and GPT-4 at $38.5\%$ [1]. Conversely, StrategyQA sees stronger baselines for both models, possibly due to its binary classification nature [1]. Methods like Chain of Thought (CoT) and Take a Deep Breathe (TDB) prompting offer marginal improvements on MuSiQue, suggesting their utility in tasks requiring inherent reasoning [1]. However, these methods don't significantly enhance performance on StrategyQA, likely because the high baseline already limits improvement [1]. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) does boost performance, approximately $4\%$ on MuSiQue and $2\%$ on StrategyQA [1].

The Step-Back Prompting method stands out, leveraging abstraction to achieve superior results, outperforming even GPT-4 on both MuSiQue ($42.8\%$) and StrategyQA ($86.4\%$) [1].  Compared to baseline models on TimeQA, GPT-4 achieves $45.6\%$ and PaLM-2L $41.5\%$, highlighting the task's difficulty [9]. Applying CoT or TDB to these baselines yields no improvement, whereas RAG improves accuracy to $57.4\%$, indicating the fact-intensive nature of TimeQA [9]. Step-Back combined with RAG further elevates accuracy to $68.7\%$ on TimeQA, demonstrating the effectiveness of abstract concepts for reliable retrieval [9]. This is further supported by performance analysis across TimeQA, TQA Easy, TQA Hard and SituatedQA, where Step-Back and Step-Back + RAG consistently outperform other methods and baselines as shown in ![Step-Back and Step-Back + RAG outperform other methods on TimeQA, TQA and SituatedQA](image2). Similarly, on MMLU Physics and Chemistry, Step-Back also demonstrates performance gains over PaLM-2L and GPT-4, as seen in ![Step-Back improves performance on MMLU Physics and Chemistry compared to other methods](image1).  On MuSiQue and StrategyQA benchmarks, Step-Back and Step-Back + RAG again show improved performance relative to PaLM-2L and GPT-4, detailed in ![Step-Back and Step-Back + RAG enhance performance on MuSiQue and StrategyQA](image5).

Error analysis of Step-Back Prompting reveals that while StepBack question generation itself rarely fails, reasoning errors constitute more than half of the mistakes [10].  A significant portion, around $45\%$ of errors, are attributed to failures in retrieving relevant information, despite the abstraction provided by Step-Back aiming to simplify retrieval [10]. This difficulty in retrieval, even with Step-Back's abstraction, underscores the complexity of tasks like TimeQA [10]. Error distribution in Step-Back prompting, as depicted in ![Error distribution of Step-Back prompting highlighting Reasoning and RAG errors as dominant](image3), shows that Reasoning Error and RAG are indeed the major sources of errors.

In conclusion, Step-Back Prompting, especially when combined with RAG, generally enhances performance across various QA tasks compared to GPT-4 and other prompting methods; however, Reasoning and Retrieval Augmented Generation remain the primary sources of errors when using Step-Back Prompting.

The Step-Back Prompting method, especially when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), significantly enhances the performance of PaLM-2L across various Knowledge QA tasks [5].  On TimeQA, a task known for its difficulty as highlighted by the baseline models of GPT-4 and PaLM-2L achieving only $45.6\%$ and $41.5\%$ respectively [4], Step-Back + RAG achieves a remarkable accuracy of $68.7\%$ [4]. This improvement underscores the effectiveness of abstracting high-level concepts for more reliable information retrieval. In contrast, simpler prompting methods like Chain of Thought (CoT) or Take a Deep Breathe (TDB) show no improvement in baseline models for TimeQA [4]. The table clearly demonstrates that PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG outperforms other methods on TimeQA. ![Table showing performance of PaLM-2L and other methods on TimeQA and SituatedQA](image2)

Similarly, on the challenging Multi-Hop reasoning benchmark MuSiQue, where baseline PaLM-2L performance is low at $35.5\%$ [7], Step-Back Prompting again proves beneficial.  While RAG alone improves performance by approximately $4\%$ on MuSiQue, Step-Back with RAG pushes the accuracy to $42.8\%$, outperforming even GPT-4 on this task [7]. StrategyQA, with its higher baseline performance, also sees improvement with Step-Back + RAG, reaching $86.4\%$ accuracy [7]. This table summarizes the performance gains of Step-Back prompting with RAG on MuSiQue and StrategyQA compared to other methods. ![Table comparing performance of PaLM-2L and other methods on MuSiQue and StrategyQA](image5)

In summary, PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG demonstrates superior performance across TimeQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA compared to baseline models and other prompting techniques.

Based on the dataset's entity distribution, the 'celebrity' category constitutes a notably larger percentage of entities compared to the 'landmark' category, as depicted in the provided visualization ![the dataset's category distribution, showing celebrity at 49.3% and landmark at 9.1%](image1). This is further supported by another representation of category distribution, where 'landmark' is shown at 9.9% ![a different representation of category distribution with landmark at 9.9%](image5). In terms of popularity, entities within the 'celebrity' category exhibit the highest average pageviews and overall popularity when compared to other categories [5].  In summary, the 'celebrity' category has a higher percentage of entities and greater popularity compared to the 'landmark' category within this dataset.

Entity detection significantly boosts the model's effectiveness, as evidenced by studies comparing performance with and without this component [2]. The variant incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the one lacking it, highlighting its crucial role in enhancing the model's overall performance.

![The table shows that incorporating entity detection (w/ ED) leads to better performance compared to not including it (w/o ED) across all evaluation metrics, including ROUGE+, BLEUt, METEORt, and BELURT +](image2)

Furthermore, retrieval augmentation plays a vital role in improving performance, particularly for long-tail entities, effectively mitigating hallucinations [1].  The model architecture itself incorporates retrieval augmentation to gather relevant entity information [9].  Analysis shows that retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM outperforms existing baseline models across all evaluated metrics, emphasizing its efficiency in generating entity-centric responses and its substantial positive impact [4].

![The table displays that retrieval augmentation (w/ RA) increases accuracy and reduces hallucination rates compared to without retrieval augmentation (w/o RA), especially for torso and tail entities.](image7)

In summary, both entity detection and retrieval augmentation are critical for enhancing the SnapNTell model's accuracy and reducing hallucination rates, leading to improved performance, especially for long-tail entities.

The SnapNTell model demonstrates superior performance compared to existing baseline models, as evidenced by its outperformance in various evaluations [4, 5].  This enhanced performance is significantly attributed to its architecture that incorporates retrieval augmentation, which enriches responses with entity-centric information, leading to more accurate and coherent answers [5, 9].  The impact of retrieval augmentation is particularly noticeable when addressing long-tail entity queries, effectively reducing inaccurate or hallucinated responses, especially for torso-to-tail entities as opposed to head entities, as illustrated in performance metrics across different entity types. ![Retrieval augmentation improves accuracy and reduces hallucination, particularly for torso and tail entities](image1).

The architecture of the SnapNTell model, depicted in its design, starts by taking an image-question pair as input and leverages retrieval augmentation to gather pertinent information about the entity within the image [2]. This information, combined with the input question, is then processed through embedding layers and fed into a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate a knowledgeable response [2].  Furthermore, the inclusion of entity detection as a component is crucial for the model's effectiveness.  Comparing performance with and without entity detection highlights a marked improvement when entity detection is incorporated, emphasizing its necessity in achieving overall effectiveness. ![Entity detection significantly improves model performance across various metrics](image3).

The SnapNTell dataset itself is designed to be particularly challenging, differentiating itself from traditional VQA datasets by revealing more pronounced performance disparities among different models and generally showing lower performance across the board for baseline models [8].  This suggests that the SnapNTell dataset is effective in evaluating a model's ability to recognize entities and generate entity-focused responses [8].  In pairwise comparisons against ground-truth data, the SnapNTell model shows a significantly smaller difference compared to baselines, further underscoring its robustness and accuracy [7].  The model’s architecture and the challenging nature of the SnapNTell dataset together contribute to a more rigorous evaluation of visual question-answering systems.

In conclusion, the SnapNTell model outperforms other models in accuracy due to key components like retrieval augmentation and entity detection, effectively addressing the challenges of entity-centric visual question answering, especially on the uniquely demanding SnapNTell dataset.

The effectiveness of incorporating entity detection in SnapNTell is clearly demonstrated through performance analysis. An ablation study comparing the model with and without entity detection highlights its crucial role [4]. The results reveal a marked improvement when entity detection is included, underscoring its necessity for the model's overall effectiveness [4].  ![Performance improvement with ED](image5). As depicted in the table, the model's performance with entity detection (w/ ED) significantly surpasses the variant without it (w/o ED) across all metrics: ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BELURT. The inclusion of entity detection noticeably enhances the performance of SnapNTell across various evaluation metrics.

SnapNTell is designed to tackle the challenges of long-tail entity queries in VLLMs, focusing on evaluating a model's ability to recognize entities and provide detailed, entity-specific knowledge [5].  The evaluation of answer quality in SnapNTell employs established NLP metrics like BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE, and BLEURT, alongside accuracy and hallucination rate metrics [9].  The performance of different methods on the SnapNTell dataset, using metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT, is detailed in ![Performance of various methods on SnapNTell using ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT metrics](image5).  A retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM developed for SnapNTell outperforms existing baseline models across all these metrics [7].  The distinctiveness of the SnapNTell dataset is further underscored by performance differences compared to traditional VQA datasets, where baseline models exhibit less variation and generally lower performance [10], as illustrated in ![Performance comparison of different methods across VQA datasets including SnapNTell](image3). Human evaluation, carried out by a panel of judges, provides additional insights into the model's performance [8], suggesting that while the proposed approach is superior to baselines, there's still potential for improvement to consistently match human-level accuracy [2].  The impact of entity detection on the model’s effectiveness is also significant, enhancing performance as shown by ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT metrics in ![Performance comparison with and without Entity Detection using ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT metrics](image6).  SnapNTell generally outperforms other methods in terms of evaluation metrics, but human evaluation indicates room for further improvement to reach human-level performance.

SPECTER demonstrates enhanced performance in document classification when compared to other models [5]. For instance, on the MeSH dataset, SPECTER achieves an F1 score of 86.4, outperforming the best baseline by 2.3 points [5].  ![SPECTER surpasses baselines in document classification, user activity, and citation prediction tasks](image3)  SPECTER also excels in user activity prediction, exceeding Citeomatic with a MAP score of 83.8 on co-view tasks [5]. In citation and co-citation tasks, SPECTER generally outperforms other baselines, except SGC which leverages citation graphs during training; however, SPECTER leads on co-citation data, achieving an nDCG of 94.8 [5]. For recommendation tasks, SPECTER maintains top performance with an nDCG of 53.9 [8]. Visually, SPECTER embeddings are better at capturing topical information than SciBERT, resulting in tighter clusters [6]. ![Visual comparison of SPECTER and SciBERT embeddings reveals SPECTER's improved topic clustering](image2)  This visual distinction is confirmed by DBScan clustering, where SPECTER achieves homogeneity and completeness values of 0.41 and 0.72, while SciBERT scores 0.19 and 0.63 [6].  In summary, SPECTER outperforms other models in document classification and citation prediction, and exhibits improved topic clustering compared to SciBERT.

The SPECTER model demonstrates significant advancements across a range of evaluation tasks, achieving an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics, which is a 3.1 percentage point increase over the next best baseline [1].  This overall improvement is visually supported by the comprehensive results table, where SPECTER consistently outperforms other models like Doc2vec, Fasttext-sum, and SciBERT across various tasks including classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction and recommendation. ![SPECTER consistently outperforms other models across various tasks](image4).

Specifically, in document classification, SPECTER achieves a macro F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH dataset and 82.0 on the MAG dataset, outperforming the best baselines by a notable margin [6].  For predicting user activity, SPECTER attains MAP scores of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on the co-read task, surpassing Citeomatic, a strong baseline in this area, by 2.7 and 4.0 points respectively [6]. The model also excels in recommendation tasks, exhibiting the highest nDCG of 53.9 compared to other models, although the performance differences are generally smaller in this domain due to the integration of other informative features in the ranking model [7].

Interestingly, an ablation study reveals that the inclusion of certain metadata fields can negatively impact SPECTER's performance [3]. Removing the abstract as input significantly reduces performance, highlighting its importance. However, adding author names as input, alongside the title and abstract, unexpectedly hurts performance, possibly due to the sparsity of author names and tokenization issues [3]. Similarly, adding venues tends to slightly decrease performance, except for document classification, where it makes slight sense due to venue's correlation with paper topics [3].  These findings are reflected in the performance table illustrating the effects of adding or removing metadata. ![Adding venue or author metadata generally decreases SPECTER's performance](image5).  This characteristic of SPECTER, not relying on authors or venues, makes it particularly useful in scenarios where such metadata is unavailable, such as anonymized submissions or preprints [4].  Furthermore, SPECTER's architecture, initialized with SciBERT and trained with triplet loss, contributes to its effectiveness. ![SPECTER architecture is initialized with SciBERT and trained with triplet loss](image2). Even without task-specific fine-tuning, SPECTER surpasses SciBERT models that are fine-tuned on end tasks, demonstrating the robustness and versatility of SPECTER embeddings [2].  In direct comparison, SPECTER achieves superior performance compared to fine-tuned SciBERT across different training signals. ![SPECTER outperforms fine-tuned SciBERT across different training signals](image3).

In conclusion, the SPECTER model generally outperforms other models across classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction and recommendation tasks, and the inclusion of additional metadata like author and venue tends to negatively affect its performance, except for document classification where venue makes slight sense.

SPECTER demonstrates a clear performance advantage over SciBERT across a range of tasks, showcasing substantial improvements in document representation [4].  This is quantitatively evidenced in performance metrics for tasks like classification, user activity prediction, and citation prediction, where SPECTER consistently outperforms SciBERT as shown in ![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT across various tasks including classification, user activity prediction, and citation prediction](image1).  Even when SciBERT undergoes task-specific fine-tuning, it generally remains inferior to the fixed representations provided by SPECTER, highlighting the inherent effectiveness of SPECTER's approach [5, 3].  This performance gap is further illustrated in a comparison against SciBERT fine-tuned on co-view, co-read, and co-citation data, where SPECTER maintains its superior standing as depicted in ![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT even when SciBERT is fine-tuned on different tasks](image5).  Furthermore, visualizing the embeddings of both models reveals that SPECTER excels in encoding topical information, achieving more compact clusters and consequently better homogeneity and completeness scores compared to SciBERT [2, 9]. This visual disparity, indicating improved topical separation by SPECTER, is apparent in ![SPECTER embeddings show better topical separation compared to SciBERT embeddings](image2). In conclusion, SPECTER exhibits superior performance and provides enhanced topical distinction in its embeddings when compared to SciBERT.

SPECTER generally shows superior performance compared to fine-tuned SciBERT in document classification tasks [7].  This is visually represented in `![SPECTER and SciBERT embeddings are projected using t-SNE for visualization.](image2)`, which displays the t-SNE projections of SPECTER and SciBERT embeddings, suggesting SPECTER's embeddings are more effective at capturing topical information [1, 9].  Examining the performance metrics, as depicted in `![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT across various tasks, including classification tasks like MAG and MeSH, according to the performance comparison table.](image5)`, SPECTER achieves higher scores in classification tasks such as MAG and MeSH compared to SciBERT.

Even when SciBERT is fine-tuned on task-specific signals like co-view, co-read, or co-citation, SPECTER, without fine-tuning, still exhibits better results in document classification (CLS), as illustrated in `![Performance table comparing SPECTER and fine-tuned SciBERT on CLS, USR, CITE, and REC tasks with different training signals.](image3)`.  Notably, SPECTER outperforms SciBERT fine-tuned on end tasks and multitask combinations without requiring any additional fine-tuning [3]. Therefore, SPECTER demonstrates more effective performance than fine-tuned SciBERT in document classification tasks.

The performance enhancements to BERT-MRC models, particularly through the application of different loss functions, demonstrate varied improvements in F1-scores across diverse datasets. For Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, enhancements like DSC consistently outperform others; for instance, on English CoNLL 2003, BERT-MRC with DSC achieves an F1 improvement of +0.29, surpassing both Focal Loss (FL) and Dice Loss (DL) enhancements ![DSC provides the highest F1 score improvement for English CoNLL 2003](image1). This trend continues across other NER datasets; on Chinese MSRA, DSC boosts the F1 score by +0.97, again leading the enhancements ![DSC leads F1 score improvements on Chinese MSRA dataset](image2). Similarly, on English OntoNotes 5.0, DSC provides a substantial F1 improvement of +0.96 compared to the baseline BERT-MRC ![DSC enhancement shows a +0.96 F1 score gain on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset](image4).  The benefits of DSC are also evident in Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks. On datasets like SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef, the DSC loss consistently provides a significant performance boost in both EM and F1 scores compared to XLNet, another strong baseline model [5]. For paraphrase identification tasks on MRPC and QQP datasets, DSC again shows the most considerable F1 score gains compared to FL and DL enhancements when applied to BERT models ![DSC shows the highest F1 score improvement in paraphrase identification tasks](image5).  Across these varied tasks and datasets, DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 scores, suggesting its robustness in addressing data imbalance issues and enhancing model performance [6].

In summary, enhancements to BERT-MRC models result in varied F1-score improvements across datasets, with DSC loss generally providing the most consistent and significant gains.

Experiments on NER datasets, including English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0, have assessed the performance of the BERT-MRC model [9], which is a model that formulates Named Entity Recognition as a machine reading comprehension task [5].  For the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC achieves an F1 score of 93.04, but with DSC enhancement, it reaches 93.33, showing an improvement by using DSC, as presented in  ![BERT-MRC and its DSC variant performance on English CoNLL 2003 dataset, showing DSC improvement](image3).  Likewise, on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC achieves an F1 score of 91.11, and with DSC enhancement, it increases to 92.07, further illustrating the positive impact of DSC, as seen in ![BERT-MRC and its DSC variant performance on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, showing DSC improvement](image5). The DSC enhancement demonstrates consistent performance improvement for BERT-MRC across both English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets [9]. In conclusion, DSC enhancement improves the performance of BERT-MRC on both English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

The BERT-MRC model, a state-of-the-art approach for Named Entity Recognition (NER), is significantly enhanced by the application of DSC loss, achieving new state-of-the-art performance on NER datasets [1, 6]. The experimental results on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset demonstrate this improvement, where BERT-MRC with DSC loss achieves a higher F1 score compared to other enhancements like FL and DL, and significantly outperforming the baseline BERT-MRC model and other models like ELMo and CVT.  ![BERT-MRC with DSC loss achieves the highest F1 score on English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image2). Similarly, on the Chinese MSRA dataset, BERT-MRC with DSC loss again shows superior performance, achieving the highest F1 score, outperforming not only BERT-MRC with FL and DL losses but also other advanced models such as Lattice-LSTM and Glyce-BERT. ![BERT-MRC with DSC loss achieves the highest F1 score on Chinese MSRA dataset](image7).

In conclusion, enhancements, particularly DSC loss, substantially improve the performance of BERT-MRC model on both English CoNLL 2003 and Chinese MSRA datasets.

The performance enhancements, including Focal Loss (FL), Dice Loss (DL), and DSC loss, have varying impacts on BERT and XLNet depending on the specific NLP task and dataset. For Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, significant performance boosts are observed with the introduction of DSC loss [4]. For instance, on SQuADv1.1, DSC loss improves XLNet's F1 score by +1.25, and on QuoRef, it leads to a +1.46 increase in EM score compared to XLNet alone [4].

![DSC loss significantly improves performance on MRC tasks for both BERT and XLNet.](image1)

Similarly, in paraphrase identification tasks, these enhancements show positive effects. On the QQP dataset, BERT with DSC loss achieves a higher F1 score compared to BERT with Cross-Entropy (CE) loss [4, image4].  Dice Loss (DL) and DSC loss also show improvements over standard Cross-Entropy loss when fine-tuning BERT for paraphrase identification [image4].

![DSC, DL, and FL enhancements improve BERT's performance on paraphrase identification tasks.](image4)

In Named Entity Recognition (NER), DSC loss consistently delivers the highest F1 scores across different datasets [7].  When applied to a BERT-MRC model for English CoNLL 2003 NER, DSC loss outperforms FL and DL, achieving a higher F1 score [image5]. This demonstrates the effectiveness of DSC in enhancing NER performance [5].

![DSC loss provides the best performance enhancement for BERT-MRC on the English CoNLL 2003 NER dataset.](image5)

However, for accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification, the benefits of DL and DSC are not apparent. In fact, on datasets like SST-2 and SST-5, BERT with CE loss performs slightly better than or comparable to BERT with DL or DSC loss [9, image3]. This indicates that these enhancements might not be suitable for tasks where accuracy is the primary metric [9]. Although, in sentiment classification tasks,  when considering data imbalance scenarios such as '+ positive & negative' datasets, DSC shows some improvement over standard BERT [image2].

![Dice Loss and DSC do not enhance performance in sentiment classification tasks on SST datasets.](image3)

![DSC shows slight improvements in imbalanced sentiment classification datasets.](image2)

In conclusion, DSC loss generally provides consistent performance improvements across various data-imbalanced NLP tasks such as MRC, NER, and paraphrase identification, but it is not designed for and may not improve accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification [1, 7, 9].

The Dice-based loss (DSC) is proposed to bridge the gap between training objectives and evaluation metrics like the F1 score [1].  Across various datasets, models employing DSC consistently achieve the highest F1 scores, particularly showing significant improvement over Dice Loss (DL) on more imbalanced datasets, highlighting DSC's effectiveness in such scenarios [2]. For instance, on paraphrase identification datasets like MRPC and QQP, both BERT and XLNet models enhanced with DSC loss consistently outperform their counterparts using Focal Loss (FL) or DL, as visualized in performance metrics across MRPC and QQP datasets.

![BERT and XLNet models with DSC consistently achieve the highest F1 scores on MRPC and QQP datasets compared to FL and DL.](image5)

The impact of different training objectives is evident when considering datasets with varying degrees of imbalance [5]. Datasets like "$^+$ positive", which are balanced, tend to yield better performance compared to the original dataset, while more imbalanced datasets like "+negative" underperform [3].  However, DSC's consistent top performance across datasets, as seen in the performance variations across different training sets , suggests its robustness to dataset imbalance [2].

![DSC consistently performs best across different training datasets and their variants, showing robustness to dataset imbalance.](image2)

In tasks like Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC), DSC loss also provides a substantial performance boost in both EM and F1 scores for BERT and XLNet models.  On datasets like SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef, the DSC-enhanced models consistently surpass XLNet in F1 score, demonstrating its effectiveness in accuracy-oriented tasks as well.

![DSC loss provides a performance boost in F1 scores for BERT and XLNet models on MRC datasets like SQuAD and QuoRef.](image4)

However, for accuracy-oriented tasks such as text classification on SST datasets, Dice Loss (DL) and DSC show slightly worse performance compared to Cross-Entropy (CE) loss, indicating that DSC is not ideally suited for tasks primarily focused on accuracy [10]. This is further illustrated in the SST-2 and SST-5 datasets performance comparison where BERT with CE achieves slightly higher accuracy than with DL or DSC.

![BERT with CE achieves slightly higher accuracy than with DL or DSC on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets, indicating DSC is not ideal for accuracy-focused tasks.](image1)

In summary, across different datasets and tasks, models using DSC loss generally exhibit superior or comparable F1 scores compared to those using FL or DL, particularly excelling in imbalanced datasets and MRC tasks, while not being the optimal choice for accuracy-centric text classification tasks.

Data augmentation techniques, such as "+positive" and "+negative", significantly alter the performance of BERT models on datasets like QQP [5]. For instance, using "+positive" augmentation, where positive training examples serve as templates, enhances performance compared to the original dataset. Conversely, "+negative" augmentation, which uses negative examples as templates, leads to underperformance relative to the original dataset [6].  This is because "+positive" tends to balance the dataset, while "+negative" can exacerbate imbalance or reduce the overall training data size, impacting the model's ability to generalize [6].

The impact of these augmentations is quantitatively measured using metrics like F1 score.  As shown in `![Performance improvements on MRPC and QQP datasets using different loss functions](image3)`, when comparing different loss functions on datasets like MRPC and QQP, DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 scores, indicating its robustness across datasets with varying characteristics [3].  Furthermore, on sentiment analysis tasks like SST-2 and SST-5, while Dice Loss (DL) and DSC show slightly worse accuracy compared to Cross-Entropy (CE) as seen in `![Comparison of BERT models with different loss functions on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets](image1)`, this suggests that these losses are not primarily optimized for accuracy-oriented tasks [1].  In Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, experiments on datasets such as Chinese OntoNotes4.0 reveal that hyperparameters in Tversky Index (TI) significantly influence performance, with variations in  $\alpha$ leading to different optimal F1 scores, highlighting the importance of hyperparameter tuning in different tasks and datasets `![Performance of different loss functions on Chinese Onto4.0 and English QuoRef datasets](image2)` [4].

Data augmentation and loss function choices considerably affect BERT model performance across various NLP tasks, and these effects are measured through accuracy and F1 score metrics depending on the task type.

The Dice-based loss (DSC) significantly enhances BERT model performance across various datasets, especially in tasks like Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC).  For instance, using DSC with BERT or XLNet leads to a notable performance increase in both Exact Match (EM) and F1 scores [1].  Specifically, on datasets like SQuAD v1.1 and QuoRef, DSC surpasses XLNet, indicating its effectiveness in improving model accuracy [1]. This is further illustrated in performance metrics where BERT+DSC consistently achieves higher F1 scores compared to other loss functions like DL and FL across datasets such as MRPC and QQP, as seen in the performance improvements from original BERT to BERT+DSC in different datasets. ![BERT+DSC achieves the highest F1 score across datasets like MRPC and QQP](image1).

However, the effectiveness of DSC is task-dependent. While DSC excels in tasks geared towards F1 score optimization, it is not ideally suited for accuracy-oriented tasks such as sentiment classification. Experiments on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets reveal that BERT with Cross-Entropy (CE) achieves slightly better accuracy than when using DL or DSC [3]. This suggests that for sentiment analysis, simpler loss functions like CE may be more appropriate, as shown in the accuracy scores for BERT with different loss functions on SST datasets. ![BERT with CE performs better than BERT with DL or DSC in sentiment classification tasks on SST datasets](image4).

Data augmentation techniques also play a crucial role in model performance. Positive data augmentation, which balances the dataset, generally improves performance, while negative augmentation may lead to performance degradation due to dataset imbalance [4].  Despite these variations, DSC maintains consistent and superior performance across different datasets compared to Focal Loss (FL) and DL, especially in imbalanced datasets, highlighting its robustness and general applicability [6].  This consistent outperformance of DSC is evident when comparing the F1 scores of BERT with different loss functions across datasets like SQuAD, QuoRef, MRPC and QQP. ![DSC consistently outperforms DL and FL across different datasets in terms of F1 score](image3).

In summary, DSC consistently improves BERT model performance in F1-score oriented tasks across various datasets, outperforming other loss functions and demonstrating robustness across different data augmentation scenarios, although it is less effective for accuracy-focused tasks like sentiment classification.

Traditional metrics like BLEU rely on n-gram matching, which means they count how often word sequences appear in both the machine translation and human reference translations [1]. This approach, while improved over time, often misses the deeper semantic meaning in translations [1]. In contrast, COMET-RANK, a newer metric, demonstrates superior performance across various language pairs. For instance, in evaluations with English as the target language, COMET-RANK consistently shows stronger correlations with human judgments compared to BLEU and even outperforms BLEURT, a metric specifically designed for English [9].

![COMET-RANK generally achieves higher evaluation scores than BLEU across different language pairs where English is the target language.](image3)

Looking at language pairs where English is the source, COMET models, including COMET-RANK, again outperform BLEU and other metrics by considerable margins [10].  This consistent outperformance is visually represented, showing COMET-RANK achieving higher Kendall Tau correlation scores compared to BLEU, both for translations into and out of English.

![COMET-RANK shows higher Kendall Tau correlation compared to BLEU in evaluating translation quality for both directions of language pairs involving English.](image5)

Therefore, COMET-RANK generally outperforms BLEU in evaluating translation quality across various language pairs, indicating a trend of more accurate and human-aligned assessments by COMET-RANK.

CodeBERT stands out as a bimodal pre-trained model crafted for both natural language and programming languages, demonstrating state-of-the-art results in downstream tasks [2].  Its effectiveness is evident when compared to other models, as it consistently outperforms RoBERTa and models pre-trained solely on code in NL-PL probing scenarios [7]. The model’s architecture, based on Transformer, is trained with a hybrid objective function, including replaced token detection, which allows it to leverage both bimodal and unimodal data effectively [9].

![CodeBERT outperforms RoBERTa and code-only models in both NL and PL probing across various programming languages.](image2)

Looking at probing performance across different programming languages, CodeBERT (MLM) generally shows better results than baselines such as RoBERTa and models pre-trained only with code, in both NL and PL probing tasks [8].  For instance, in PL probing, CodeBERT (MLM) achieves significantly higher scores than RoBERTa across Ruby, Javascript, Go, Python, Java, and PHP [image2].  Similarly, in NL probing, CodeBERT (MLM) also demonstrates superior performance across these languages [image2]. This consistent outperformance highlights CodeBERT's enhanced capability in understanding both natural and programming languages in a probing context across varied programming languages [8].

In summary, CodeBERT generally exhibits superior performance in probing tasks for both programming and natural languages across different programming languages when compared to models like RoBERTa and code-only pre-trained models.

The sentiment classifiers demonstrate varied effectiveness in detecting negative sentiment.  Looking at the precision scores for negative sentiment, many classifiers struggle, with values generally being low across the board.  For instance, the precision for Naive Bayes is notably low at 0.02, while Decision Tree shows a comparatively better precision of 0.24 for negative sentiment detection, as seen across different classifiers.  ![Precision scores for different classifiers on various sentiment classes](image1).

Recall values for negative sentiment reveal a different perspective. Naive Bayes achieves a high recall of 0.62, suggesting it captures a large portion of actual negative sentiments, although it also has low precision. Logistic Regression and CDME also show high recall at 0.56, indicating their ability to identify negative instances. In contrast, SVM and BERT Multilingual have a recall of 0.00, indicating they fail to capture any negative sentiments effectively.  ![Recall scores for different classifiers on various sentiment classes](image2).

Considering the F-score, which balances precision and recall, Decision Tree again shows a relatively better F-score of 0.21 for negative sentiment.  Random Forest and Logistic Regression have slightly lower F-scores of 0.18 and 0.13 respectively.  Naive Bayes, despite high recall, has a very low F-score of 0.01 due to its poor precision.  SVM and BERT Multilingual continue to show an F-score of 0.00, confirming their poor performance in negative sentiment detection.  ![F-scores for different classifiers on various sentiment classes](image5).

Decision Tree classifier demonstrates consistently better performance for negative sentiment detection compared to other classifiers across precision, recall, and F-score metrics.

Comparing DS-DST and DS-Picklist, it's evident that accessing a full ontology significantly boosts performance in dialogue state tracking. When a full ontology is available, DS-Picklist consistently demonstrates superior performance compared to DS-DST [6].  This improvement is quantified by the joint accuracy, where DS-Picklist achieves 53.30% on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, outperforming DS-DST's 51.21% in the same setting, as shown below.

![DS-Picklist outperforms DS-DST in joint accuracy on MultiWOZ 2.1](image4)

The advantage of DS-Picklist becomes clearer when examining slot-level accuracy, particularly for categorical slots.  Slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` see substantial accuracy gains [3].  These slots benefit from the candidate-value lists inherent in the ontology-based approach of DS-Picklist, as their values are often diverse and not easily extracted directly from the dialogue context [3]. The table below provides a detailed view of slot-level accuracies, highlighting the improvements of DS-DST and DS-Picklist over DS-Span across various slots.

![Slot-level accuracy comparison between DS-Span, DS-DST and DS-Picklist on MultiWOZ 2.1 test set](image5)

In summary, DS-Picklist generally achieves higher joint and slot accuracy than DS-DST, especially for categorical slots, by leveraging a full ontology and candidate-value lists.

The experimental results reveal that both DS-DST and DS-Picklist models outperform DS-Span, particularly in slots where values are not easily extracted from the dialog context [2].  Specifically, slots like hotel-type, attraction-type, attraction-name, hotel-internet, and hotel-parking benefit significantly from DS-DST and DS-Picklist approaches because their values are often varied and not directly present in the conversation [2]. These models, especially DS-Picklist, can predict values from candidate lists, enhancing accuracy.  You can observe the slot-level accuracy in detail from the table, showing performance improvements across various slots for DS-DST and DS-Picklist compared to DS-Span. ![Table showing slot-level accuracy comparison of DS-Span, DS-DST and DS-Picklist models](image1).  Error analysis further supports this, indicating that DS-DST and DS-Picklist effectively reduce errors for slots such as attraction-type, hotel-internet, and hotel-parking, where DS-Span struggles to find ground-truth values through span matching [3].  When considering overall performance on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, DS-Picklist exhibits a higher joint accuracy of 53.30% compared to DS-DST's 51.21% [5, Image2].  This improvement is further highlighted when comparing against other models, where DS-Picklist consistently shows superior performance [Image3].  While DS-Picklist generally outperforms DS-DST due to its access to a full ontology, which is not always available in real-world scenarios, both models represent a significant advancement over span-based methods like DS-Span, especially for categorical slots and slots with predefined value lists [5].

In summary, DS-Picklist generally performs better than DS-DST on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, with notable advantages in specific slots like hotel-type and attraction-type due to its utilization of a full ontology.

The DS-Picklist model leverages a full ontology, which allows it to further enhance dialogue state tracking (DST) performance beyond DS-DST, particularly when predicting values from candidate lists [1].  In comparison to DS-Span, both DS-DST and DS-Picklist exhibit significantly improved accuracy [4]. This enhancement is attributed to their ability to handle slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` more effectively. These slots often contain values with varied expressions that are not easily extracted from the dialog context using span-based methods like DS-Span. Instead, DS-DST and DS-Picklist can predict these values directly from candidate-value lists [4]. For instance, consider scenarios where users respond with implicit confirmations like 'pool' instead of explicitly stating 'swimming pool', or when system requests regarding internet or parking are met with implicit 'yes' or 'no' from the user; in such cases, DS-Span may struggle to extract the ground-truth values, whereas DS-DST and DS-Picklist are better equipped to handle these nuances due to their categorical approach and access to ontologies, as illustrated in dialogue examples. ![Example dialogues showing DS-Span, DS-DST and DS-Picklist performance](image2)

The performance differences are also evident in joint accuracy metrics.  DS-Picklist achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30%, outperforming not only BERT-DST and BERT-DST-Picklist but also the strong ToD-BERT model [2, 4, 5]. This is highlighted in evaluations on datasets like MultiWOZ 2.1, where DS-models consistently surpass BERT-DST and ToD-BERT, suggesting that the improvements stem from strong interactions between slots and dialog context [2]. The advantage of DS-Picklist over DS-DST and DS-Span is further quantified in slot-level accuracy, particularly for slots that are better treated as categorical [6].  As shown in the error analysis, DS-DST and DS-Picklist dramatically reduce errors for slots like `attraction-type`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking`, indicating that for these slot types, a categorical approach is more beneficial than span-based methods [6].  Conversely, time-related slots like `taxi-leave at` and `train-arrive by`, which are span-based even in DS-DST, do not perform as well in DS-Span and DS-DST, but DS-Picklist, with ontology access, can further reduce error rates by predicting values from candidate lists, although improvements might be less dramatic for span-based slots. ![Top-10 slots with high ratio of unfound ground-truth values by DS-Span and performance of DS-DST and DS-Picklist](image3)

In summary, DS-Picklist generally outperforms both DS-DST and DS-Span in joint accuracy and demonstrates improved slot accuracy, especially for categorical slots, by leveraging a full ontology and strong interactions between dialog context and domain-slot pairs.

DeClarE exhibits varied performance across different datasets depending on its configuration.  On Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, DeClarE significantly outperforms simpler models like LSTM-text and CNN-text, achieving higher macro F1-scores [6, 7].
