The consolidated operating profit showed a favorable change from 2020 to 2021, as seen in the annual comparison chart ![Annual consolidated operating profit increased from 2020 to 2021](image1).  This positive trend is also reflected in the fourth quarter performance ![Fourth quarter consolidated operating profit also increased from 2020 to 2021](image5).  Further details from supplemental data indicate a rise in consolidated operating profit to $6,878 million in 2021 from $4,553 million in 2020, and for Machinery, Energy & Transportation, it increased to $6,363 million in 2021 from $4,321 million in 2020 [image3].  Likewise, the net cash provided by operating activities experienced growth; consolidated operating cash flow for 2021 reached $7.20 billion, a $871 million increase compared to 2020 [5].  According to supplemental consolidating data, net cash from operating activities for Machinery, Energy & Transportation grew to $7,177 million in 2021 from $4,054 million in 2020, and for the consolidated entity, it totaled $7,198 million in 2021 compared to $6,327 million in 2020 ![Net cash from operating activities increased for both consolidated and ME&T segments in 2021 compared to 2020](image2).  In conclusion, both consolidated and Machinery, Energy & Transportation segments demonstrated enhanced financial results regarding operating profit and net cash provided by operating activities when comparing 2020 to 2021.

The company experienced an increase in gross unrecognized tax benefits from 2019 to 2020, rising from $1,423 million to $1,829 million, as detailed in the table illustrating the changes in unrecognized tax benefits over the years ![Gross unrecognized tax benefits increased in 2020 compared to 2019](image3). This increase suggests a growing amount of tax positions taken by the company that do not meet the recognition threshold, potentially indicating more uncertainty in their tax positions or a more aggressive approach to tax planning in 2020 compared to the previous year. While the gross unrecognized tax benefits increased, the company also projected a potential decrease of $39 million in these liabilities within the next twelve months due to audit settlements and statute of limitations expiring [10].

Conversely, common share repurchases saw a decrease in aggregate cost, falling from $5,500 million in 2019 to $4,250 million in 2020, and the number of shares repurchased also declined from 22 million to 14 million, as shown in the summary of share repurchases ![Common share repurchases decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image1).  Despite the reduction in the scale of repurchases, the average price per share increased significantly from $245.97 to $300.58 [image1], and even higher to $334.54 during the fourth quarter of 2020 [2]. This share repurchase program is part of the company's strategy to optimize capital structure and enhance shareholder returns [5].

In summary, the company's financial position in 2020 was marked by an increase in gross unrecognized tax benefits, suggesting heightened tax uncertainties, alongside a reduced volume of common share repurchases at a higher average price per share, reflecting adjustments in capital allocation strategies.

The fourth quarter of 2021 witnessed a notable surge in sales and revenues, climbing by 23 percent compared to the same period in 2020 [10]. This impressive growth was largely propelled by an increase in sales volume, which itself was driven by heightened end-user demand for both equipment and services [10].  ![Sales volume significantly contributed to the increase in consolidated sales and revenues.](image5)  Dealers' inventory adjustments also played a significant role; in the fourth quarter of 2020, dealers reduced their inventories more substantially compared to the fourth quarter of 2021 [2, 5, 9]. This shift in dealer inventory strategy further contributed to the increased sales volume in 2021.  Favorable price realization also positively influenced the sales figures [5, 8].

Moreover, the operating profit for the fourth quarter of 2021 saw a 17 percent increase from the previous year [7].  ![Consolidated operating profit increased in the fourth quarter of 2021 compared to the same period in 2020.](image2) This improvement in operating profit was achieved despite facing headwinds such as increased manufacturing costs and higher selling, general, and administrative (SG&A) and research and development (R&D) expenses [7]. These increased costs were offset by the robust sales volume, favorable pricing, and gains from restructuring activities, including the sale of a facility [7]. Segment-specific factors also contributed to the profit changes; for instance, Financial Products experienced a profit increase due to favorable impacts from returned equipment and reduced credit loss provisions [3]. However, it's important to note that the operating profit margin slightly decreased, moving from 12.3 percent in the fourth quarter of 2020 to 11.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 2021 [1].

In summary, the increase in both sales volume and operating profit in the fourth quarter of 2021 was primarily driven by higher end-user demand and changes in dealer inventories, alongside favorable price realization, although operating profit margin experienced a slight decrease.

The regulatory landscape for financial entities underwent several changes, as reflected in the updates to capital requirements and accounting standards. For instance, the adoption of CECL (Current Expected Credit Losses) accounting standard impacted capital calculations with a five-year transition period [3, 6]. Furthermore, adjustments to the Volcker Rule removed certain capital deduction requirements for banking organizations [5]. The implementation of the Basel 3 Final Rule also introduced a stress capital buffer (SCB) calculated based on stress test results, replacing the static capital conservation buffer [7]. The comprehensive capital analysis and review (CCAR) program was integrated with these buffer requirements [7].
Reflecting these changes, the Total Capital Ratio under the Standardized Approach saw an increase from 14.8% in 2019 to 16.1% in 2020, while under the Advanced Approaches it increased from 14.7% to 16.6% ![Total capital ratios increased under both standardized and advanced approaches](image2). Similarly, the Regulatory Long-term Debt Minimum percentage also experienced an increase, moving from 11.5% in 2019 to 13.3% in 2020 ![Regulatory long-term debt percentage increased from 2019 to 2020](image3). This indicates a strengthening of the financial entity's capital and long-term debt positions in accordance with evolving regulatory standards. In summary, both the Total Capital Ratios and Long-term Debt Percentages for the financial entity increased from December 31, 2019, to December 31, 2020, under the Basel 3 standards.

Chevron's equity and cash flow in 2021 were significantly shaped by both cash dividends and treasury stock transactions.  The company distributed \$10,179 million in cash dividends to its common stockholders, which directly reduced retained earnings, a component of stockholders' equity [image3].  This is reflected as a cash outflow in the financing activities section of the cash flow statement [image4].

![Cash dividends decreased retained earnings and represented a cash outflow.](image3)

Conversely, treasury stock transactions had a mixed effect.  Although there were purchases of treasury shares amounting to \$1,383 million and issuances of treasury shares of \$1,040 million, the net effect of treasury stock transactions, shown as \$315 million in the equity statement, ultimately increased Chevron Corporation Stockholders’ Equity [image3].  In terms of cash flow, these transactions resulted in a net cash inflow of \$38 million from financing activities [image4], representing the net effect of share issuances and repurchases.

![Treasury stock transactions had a net positive impact on equity and resulted in a net cash inflow.](image4)

In 2021, cash dividends decreased equity and represented a cash outflow, while treasury stock transactions slightly increased equity and resulted in a net cash inflow for Chevron.

HSBC's workforce exhibits a gender distribution where women slightly outnumber men overall, representing $52\%$ of all employees [image2].  However, this balance shifts significantly at the senior leadership level, where men constitute a larger majority.  In 2020, women held $30\%$ of senior leadership positions, a figure that HSBC aimed to achieve by that year [3, 6].  This is a notable disparity compared to the overall employee gender balance, as visualized in the provided data ![Senior leadership positions are predominantly held by men while women are slightly more in overall employees](image2).

The company acknowledges this gap and its commitment to improving gender diversity in senior roles is evident through their initiatives and targets.  They have set a goal to increase female representation in senior leadership to $35\%$ by 2025, building upon the $30\%$ achieved in 2020 [3, 5, 6, 7].  The gender pay gap data also reflects this structural imbalance, with a $48\%$ median aggregate gender pay gap in the UK, driven by the higher proportion of men in senior, higher-paying positions [1].  This disparity is further illustrated in the breakdown of gender representation across different segments of leadership within HSBC, indicating varying levels of female representation in senior roles depending on the specific area, as shown in ![Gender distribution across different leadership levels within HSBC showing varied female representation](image1).

Despite the existing imbalance, HSBC emphasizes its dedication to fostering a more diverse and inclusive workforce, viewing diversity as a source of strength [3]. The company is actively implementing programs and setting targets to enhance gender balance in leadership, aiming to create a more equitable representation at all levels [5, 10].

In conclusion, while women form a slight majority in HSBC's overall employee base, they are significantly underrepresented in senior leadership roles, although the company is actively working towards achieving greater gender balance at these higher levels.

Wealth and Personal Banking (WPB) was established in the second quarter of 2020 through the integration of Retail Banking, Wealth Management, and Global Private Banking sectors [2].  The financial year 2020 presented challenges for HSBC, as reflected in the overall adjusted results, with a notable decrease in profit before tax ![Adjusted results showing profit before tax decrease from 2019 to 2020](image2). Examining the management view of adjusted revenue, it is evident that key components of WPB, such as Retail Banking and Wealth Management, experienced revenue declines in 2020 compared to the previous year ![Management view of adjusted revenue showing revenue decrease in Retail Banking and Wealth Management from 2019 to 2020](image3).  This decrease in revenue within WPB segments suggests a corresponding impact on the group's overall profitability.

In 2020, Wealth and Personal Banking contributed to a decrease in HSBC's group adjusted profit before tax, mirroring the broader financial challenges faced by the institution.

Lovisa’s growth strategy is heavily reliant on expanding its store network internationally, aiming to boost earnings by opening new stores both within Australia and in overseas markets [1]. This international expansion is a key driver for the company's future growth [5].  Lovisa strategically assesses new regions, leveraging local industry contacts to build knowledge and secure multiple store locations to establish a strong presence upon market entry [8].  This approach is facilitated by Lovisa's efficient store model, which allows for quick and low-cost store setups, typically within 14 days, aiding rapid international roll-out [10].  The tangible outcome of this international expansion strategy is clearly reflected in the growth of store counts across various international territories between 2016 and 2020, with notable increases in regions like the USA, UK and France ![Store counts in various international regions from 2016 to 2020, showing significant growth in several areas](image2).  This international expansion is a core component of Lovisa’s business strategy, focusing on leveraging existing international territories and venturing into new ones, including targeted roll-outs in key markets like the USA, France, and the UK ![Lovisa's Growth pillar emphasizing International Expansion as a key strategy](image5).  Consequently, Lovisa's international store expansion strategy has demonstrably increased its store footprint in new territories between 2016 and 2020.

The adoption of AASB 16 Leases from 1 July 2019 marked a significant shift in lease accounting, introducing a unified on-balance sheet approach for lessees [2, 10]. Consequently, the Group recognized right-of-use assets and lease liabilities, reflecting their entitlement to utilize underlying assets and their commitment to lease payments respectively [10].  ![A summary of the accounting treatment change under AASB 16](image1).  For leases previously categorized as operating leases, the transition involved measuring lease liabilities at the present value of remaining lease payments, discounted at the Group’s incremental borrowing rate as of 1 July 2019 [8].  The consolidated financial statement demonstrates the recognition of lease liability upon initial application of AASB 16 in 2020, depicting an adjusted balance at 1 July 2019 and a detailed breakdown of lease liability components throughout the period, leading to a balance at 28 June 2020, categorized into current and non-current portions ![The balance of lease liabilities in 2020 after AASB 16 adoption](image2).  The financial transition to AASB 16 in 2020 primarily resulted in the recognition of significant lease liabilities on the balance sheet, while the employee benefit liabilities were not directly impacted by this transition, as they pertain to obligations from employee services [1].

The financial impacts of the transition to AASB 16 in 2020 were primarily the recognition of substantial lease liabilities on the balance sheet, with no direct impact on employee benefit liabilities.

The fair value allocations for both ClickSoftware and Salesforce.org acquisitions include common elements such as cash and cash equivalents, goodwill, and intangible assets, alongside liabilities like accounts payable and unearned revenue, and deferred tax considerations.  Both allocations aim to capture the net assets acquired in these business combinations.  However, the scale of these allocations differs significantly. For ClickSoftware, the goodwill is substantially larger at $1,132 million, and the net assets acquired amount to $1,386 million, as presented in the fair value breakdown ![Fair value allocation for ClickSoftware, showing significant goodwill and net assets](image5). This contrasts with Salesforce.org, where goodwill is recorded at $164 million and net assets acquired are $134 million, as shown in its fair value allocation ![Fair value allocation for Salesforce.org, with smaller goodwill and net assets figures](image2).  A key component of intangible assets for ClickSoftware is further detailed, highlighting developed technology and customer relationships with specific fair values and useful lives ![Breakdown of intangible assets for ClickSoftware acquisition, specifying fair value and useful life for developed technology and customer relationships](image1).  This detailed breakdown is not explicitly provided for Salesforce.org in the given quotes.  The fair value allocations reflect the different natures and sizes of these acquisitions, with ClickSoftware representing a much larger business combination.

In summary, while both acquisitions involve similar categories in their fair value allocation, the magnitudes, particularly of goodwill and net assets acquired, are markedly different, indicating a significantly larger scale for the ClickSoftware acquisition compared to Salesforce.org.

In 2020, there was a decrease in PepsiCo Beverages North America (PBNA)’s operating profit when considering both Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and non-GAAP measures compared to 2019.  This is visually represented, showing a decrease in reported percentage change for PBNA [image5]. The GAAP measure witnessed a larger decrease of (11)%, while the non-GAAP measure experienced a smaller decrease of (8)% [image5]. The distinction arises from "items affecting comparability," which are factored into GAAP but excluded from non-GAAP measures [9].  These items, specifically for PBNA in 2020, included restructuring, merger and integration charges, alongside core charges, totaling $47 and $66 respectively [image4].  In 2019, the items affecting comparability for PBNA were primarily restructuring and merger and integration charges, amounting to $51 [image4]. It's also important to note that in 2020, PBNA recognized a pre-tax impairment charge of $41 million related to a coconut water brand, which could have further influenced the GAAP measure [5].  Therefore, both GAAP and non-GAAP measures for PBNA decreased from 2019 to 2020, with the difference primarily due to the exclusion of certain charges in the non-GAAP calculation, and potentially influenced by factors like impairment charges.

![The table shows the items affecting comparability for different segments including PBNA, for both 2020 and 2019, differentiating between GAAP and Non-GAAP measures.](image4)

In summary, both the reported GAAP and the core non-GAAP operating profit measures for PBNA decreased from 2019 to 2020, influenced by factors such as restructuring, merger and integration charges, core charges, and potentially impairment charges, with non-GAAP measures excluding certain items affecting comparability.

Net cash from operating activities saw a decrease of $0.278 billion from 2019 to 2020, moving from $10,090 million to $9,812 million, as shown in the statement of cash flow activities ![Net cash from operating activities decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image2).  In contrast, net cash used in investing activities decreased by $0.719 billion, shifting from $1,873 million used in 2019 to $1,154 million used in 2020 [9].  However, net cash used in financing activities increased by $0.435 billion, from $8,061 million in 2019 to $8,496 million in 2020, impacting the overall cash flow negatively in this area [4]. Despite these mixed changes in cash flows, the combined effect resulted in an increase in cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash by $0.420 billion from 2019 to 2020, as the balance moved from $6,865 million to $7,285 million, which can be seen in the financing activities section of the cash flow statement ![Cash balance increased from 2019 to 2020](image3).  The changes in operating, investing, and financing activities contributed to a net increase in the overall cash balance at the end of 2020 compared to 2019.

The company's assets, as depicted, encompass a range from cash and accounts receivable to property, plant, and equipment [image1]. Depreciation for these assets, including property, plant, and equipment, is calculated using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives [2].  Notably, solar energy systems in service have an estimated useful life spanning 30 to 35 years [image4].  In contrast, machinery, equipment, vehicles, and office furniture are depreciated over a shorter period, ranging from 2 to 12 years [image5].

The estimated useful life for solar energy systems in service is significantly longer than that of machinery and equipment.

Toyota's executive remuneration system is carefully structured to reflect both business performance and shareholder value.  The annual total remuneration is determined by a formula that takes into account the consolidated operating income and the volatility of Toyota's share price, ensuring a direct link between executive pay and company-wide financial performance [1].  This approach is visually outlined, showing that the evaluation method uses consolidated operating income and share price volatility as key indicators [3, 10].  ![Toyota evaluates performance using operating income and share price volatility](image1).  Furthermore, the company explicitly uses business performance indicators and corporate value indicators for shareholders to evaluate Toyota's overall efforts, which also plays a role in assessing executive performance [5, 8].  ![Toyota uses business performance and shareholder value indicators for evaluation](image5).  This system ensures that executive compensation is not only tied to individual performance but is also significantly influenced by the broader business outcomes and shareholder interests [2].  Therefore, Toyota's executive remuneration evaluation directly reflects their business performance and shareholder value indicators.

Caterpillar's impressive revenue surge in 2021 was significantly propelled by an upswing in sales volume alongside favorable price adjustments [8]. This is clearly illustrated in the consolidated sales figures, showcasing a substantial overall increase [6].  Specifically, the breakdown reveals that sales volume contributed a noteworthy  $\S7,563$ million, while price realization added  $\S932$ million to the revenue growth ![Sales volume and price realization were key contributors to the revenue increase.](image2).

This robust growth was not uniform across all sectors, with some segments demonstrating more pronounced improvements than others.  Notably, Construction Industries experienced a remarkable sales surge, climbing by 31 percent, translating to an increase of  $\S5.188$ billion [4].  Similarly, Energy & Transportation also showed significant gains, with sales rising by 16 percent, equating to a  $\S2.817$ billion increase [7].  Examining the regional performance, North America and Latin America stood out with substantial percentage increases in external sales, demonstrating strong market demand and effective inventory management ![North America and Latin America showed significant percentage increase in external sales.](image1).

The granular data further emphasizes these points, detailing the contributions of sales volume and price realization across different segments. Construction Industries, for instance, saw a  $\S4,063$ million increase from sales volume and  $\S732$ million from price realization, while Energy & Transportation benefited from a  $\S1,683$ million volume increase and  $\S101$ million from price realization [image3]. These figures underscore the pivotal role of both increased demand and strategic pricing in Caterpillar's financial success in 2021.

In conclusion, the revenue increase for Caterpillar in 2021 was substantially driven by both higher sales volume and favorable price realization, with Construction Industries and Energy & Transportation segments exhibiting the most significant revenue improvements.

Bank of America operates through different business segments, including Global Wealth and Investment Management (GWIM) and Consumer Banking [2]. GWIM encompasses Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management and Bank of America Private Bank, offering wealth management solutions [1, 2]. In 2020, GWIM experienced a decrease in revenue to $18.6 billion, down from $19.5 billion in 2019, and a decrease in net income to $3.1 billion from $4.3 billion in the previous year ![GWIM's revenue and net income saw a decrease from 2019 to 2020.](image3). This decline in GWIM revenue can be further broken down, with both Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management and Bank of America Private Bank showing reduced revenues in 2020 compared to 2019, as seen with Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management’s revenue decreasing to $15.3 billion from $16.1 billion, and Bank of America Private Bank's revenue decreasing to $3.3 billion from $3.4 billion ![Both Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management and Bank of America Private Bank experienced revenue declines in 2020 compared to 2019.](image2).

Conversely, Consumer Banking also faced financial headwinds in 2020; its net income significantly decreased by $6.5 billion, reaching $6.5 billion, primarily due to reduced revenue and increased credit loss provisions [8].  This reduction in revenue within Consumer Banking is further evidenced by a decrease in net interest income by $3.5 billion and a decrease in noninterest income by $1.9 billion [8].

In summary, both Consumer Banking and Global Wealth & Investment Management segments experienced a decline in revenue and net income in 2020 compared to 2019, with Consumer Banking facing a more significant decrease in net income.

Danaher Corporation's comprehensive income experienced a significant increase between 2018 and 2020. In 2018, the comprehensive income was \$2,005 million, as shown in the stockholders' equity statement ![Stockholders' equity in 2018 was $2,005 million](image2). By 2019, this figure rose to \$2,731 million [1], reflecting a notable growth.  The upward trend continued into 2020, with comprehensive income reaching approximately \$6.2 billion ![Comprehensive income increased to $6,215 million in 2020](image1). This substantial increase of approximately \$3.6 billion in 2020 compared to 2019 was primarily attributed to several factors [1]. A significant gain from foreign currency translation adjustments in 2020, contrasting with a loss in 2019, played a major role. Additionally, higher net earnings and a reduced loss from cash flow hedge adjustments in 2020, compared to the previous year, contributed to this growth.  These positive impacts were partially offset by increased losses from pension and postretirement plan benefit adjustments in 2020 when compared to 2019 [1]. Overall, Danaher Corporation saw a considerable positive change in its comprehensive income from 2018 to 2020.

Responding to the urgent needs of the pandemic, a considerable amount was allocated to COVID relief initiatives, as evidenced by projects aimed at preventive and curative healthcare across India.  This includes significant expenditure for nationwide programs and specific support in states like Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh, exemplified by initiatives in Mumbai and Lucknow, and broader national level efforts.  Many of these COVID relief projects, such as those providing community kitchens and direct aid, were implemented directly without intermediary agencies. In contrast, rural development projects, while also widespread across states like Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra, and encompassing activities from dairy support to financial literacy, show a different pattern in implementation.  A substantial portion of rural development projects, particularly in areas like financial literacy and dairy support, were implemented directly.

![COVID relief projects were largely implemented without agencies, focusing on immediate healthcare needs.](image4)

![Rural development projects, while diverse, often utilized direct implementation for initiatives like financial literacy.](image5)

While both categories of projects span multiple states, rural development projects, especially in financial literacy, received a larger total allocation compared to the more immediate, though substantial, COVID relief efforts.  A key difference lies in the implementation mode, with COVID relief projects leaning towards implementation through agencies, while rural development showed a stronger preference for direct implementation, particularly in large-scale initiatives.  The modes of implementation reflect the nature of the projects, with rapid relief efforts potentially utilizing existing agency networks, while long-term development goals may benefit from direct oversight and execution.

In summary, while both COVID Relief and Rural Development projects were implemented across various Indian states, Rural Development projects received larger funding and showed a higher tendency for direct implementation compared to COVID Relief projects which were often executed through implementing agencies.

Changes in actuarial assumptions are critical in determining the defined benefit obligation, which represents the present value of future benefit entitlements [2]. These assumptions encompass factors such as discount rates, expected compensation increases, and pension progression [2]. The sensitivity of the defined benefit obligation to these assumptions is regularly assessed [1].  ![The table shows that a decrease in the discount rate increases the defined benefit obligation, and an increase in discount rate decreases it; similarly, changes in compensation increase and pension progression also affect the defined benefit obligation.](image1). Actuarial gains and losses, arising from revisions in these assumptions, also contribute to fluctuations in the defined benefit obligation [8].  ![This table indicates total actuarial losses of €22 million in 2021, contrasting with actuarial gains of €67 million in 2020, reflecting the impact of assumption changes.](image3).  For example, the discount rate, a key actuarial assumption, saw a slight increase from 1.5% in 2020 to 1.7% in 2021 [4].  ![This table shows the discount rates in 2020 and 2021, with a breakdown by currency.](image4).

In summary, changes in actuarial assumptions resulted in actuarial losses in 2021 compared to gains in 2020, significantly impacting the defined benefit obligation, but their direct impact on plan assets is not detailed in the provided quotes.

From 2019 to 2020, there was a decrease in the External TLAC as a percentage of Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) [image5]. This ratio moved from 49.9% in 2019 to 47.7% in 2020 [image5].  The composition of RWA experienced shifts across various risk categories during this period [image3]. Credit risk RWA saw an increase, driven primarily by derivatives exposures, investment securities, lending commitments, and equity investments [5, image3]. Market risk RWA also increased, mainly due to higher market volatility affecting Regulatory VaR [6, image3]. In contrast, operational risk RWA decreased, reflecting a decline in litigation-related losses [9, image3]. Despite the overall increase in both standardized and advanced Credit and Market Risk RWA [5, 6, image3], and a decrease in Operational Risk RWA [9, image3], the External TLAC as a percentage of RWA decreased, suggesting that while RWA increased, External TLAC did not increase at the same rate, leading to a lower ratio.

![External TLAC as a percentage of RWA decreased from 49.9% to 47.7% between 2019 and 2020.](image5)

In summary, while Credit and Market risk RWAs increased, and Operational risk RWA decreased, the External TLAC as a percentage of RWA saw a reduction from 2019 to 2020.

McDonald's experienced a varied revenue landscape between its U.S. and International Operated Markets from 2019 to 2020.  Total revenues for International Operated Markets saw a significant decrease, a trend visually represented in revenue breakdowns ![International Operated Markets experienced a revenue decrease](image5).  This decline is further specified in text as a $17\%$ decrease in total revenues for International Operated Markets and a more pronounced $19\%$ drop in Company-operated sales, contrasting with a smaller $14\%$ decrease in franchised revenues within the same segment, as highlighted in revenue breakdowns ![Revenue changes across different segments](image7). These figures underscore the considerable impact of external factors on international operations.

Conversely, the U.S. market demonstrated more resilience.  While not experiencing growth, the revenue decline in the U.S. was less severe compared to the International Operated Markets. Total revenues in the U.S. decreased by $2\%$, with a $4\%$ decrease in Company-operated sales and a $2\%$ decrease in franchised revenues, as detailed in revenue breakdowns ![Revenue changes across different segments](image7). This relative stability in the U.S. market, despite overall challenges, is also reflected in margin changes ![Restaurant margin changes across segments](image4), where the U.S. segments show less drastic decreases compared to international markets.

The disparities in performance can be attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, which significantly hampered the International Operated Markets due to "temporary restaurant closures and limited operations" [3], particularly in key European markets such as "the U.K., France, Germany, Italy and Spain" [3, 4].  These operational disruptions directly translated to sales and revenue declines in these regions [5, 10].  In contrast, the U.S. market, while also affected, showed "positive sales performance" [1, 10], potentially aided by strategic initiatives such as "marketing, through incentives to franchisees, to accelerate recovery and drive growth, including the free Thank You Meals" [1, 2].  These actions suggest a proactive approach in the U.S. to mitigate negative impacts and stimulate sales, contrasting with the more challenging operational environment faced by the International Operated Markets.

In summary, from 2019 to 2020, McDonald's U.S. segment experienced a minor revenue decrease, while the International Operated Markets segment faced a substantial decline, largely influenced by the COVID-19 pandemic and differing market conditions and strategic responses.

The sale of Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM) significantly altered its assets under management in 2021, as evidenced by a substantial outflow of $587.1 billion due to the sale ![WFAM assets under management dramatically decreased due to the sale in 2021](image2).  This sale, finalized on November 1, 2021, resulted in net gains for Wells Fargo [6].  Prior to the sale, WFAM contributed to Wells Fargo's fee income through managing a diverse portfolio of assets [2, 8].  However, despite the considerable change in AUM from WFAM, the period-end total assets of Wells Fargo only experienced a modest decrease from 2020 to 2021 [7]. In fact, average total assets actually increased in 2021 compared to 2020, from $675,250 million to $743,089 million, a 10% increase [image5]. This suggests that while the WFAM sale reduced AUM, it did not lead to a proportional decrease in overall total assets on the balance sheet. The modest decrease in period-end total assets is attributed to the timing of cash deployment [7], and other factors such as portfolio rebalancing and managing under the asset cap also influenced balance sheet changes, as seen in the fluctuations of available-for-sale and held-to-maturity debt securities ![Comparison of Available-for-sale and Held-to-maturity debt securities between Dec 31, 2021 and Dec 31, 2020](image1).  Therefore, while the WFAM sale caused a significant decrease in AUM, its direct impact on the overall balance sheet data, specifically total assets, appears to be muted by other concurrent financial activities and strategic decisions within Wells Fargo during 2021.

The changes in 'Total WFAM assets under management' led to a significant decrease in AUM for Wells Fargo in 2021, but its direct impact on the overall balance sheet data was offset by other financial activities, resulting in only a modest period-end decrease in total assets.

Lovisa's international store expansion strategy has been a key driver of growth, focusing on establishing a global footprint through company-owned and franchised stores [4].  This expansion is underpinned by a strategy to remain nimble and opportunistic, continuously evaluating new markets and leveraging local networks to build knowledge when entering new regions [3].  A core element of their approach involves securing a portfolio of stores to quickly establish an operating footprint in new markets, exemplified by the roll-out in the USA, France, and UK, and the investigation of other Northern Hemisphere markets [image4].  This strategic direction is visually represented in the focus on "International expansion" as a primary "Growth pillar" [image4].

The period from 2016 to 2020 demonstrates a significant acceleration in Lovisa's international presence.  Looking at store numbers, we can see substantial increases in key international markets. For example, the United Kingdom grew from 3 stores in 2016 to 42 in 2020, France from 2 to 21, and the USA from a single store to 48 in the same timeframe [image5]. This growth highlights the successful execution of their international roll-out strategy, as mentioned as a key achievement in image4, with net 47 stores opened outside Australia in a single year, including significant numbers in the UK, France, and USA.

Despite this rapid expansion, Lovisa faces challenges inherent in the competitive fast fashion jewellery sector [7].  These include competition, economic conditions, and the need to secure appropriately sized sites in good locations [image4].  However, Lovisa mitigates these risks by focusing on securing quality retail store sites in high pedestrian traffic locations, typically within AA, A, or B grade shopping centers [9].  Their refined global store model, targeting a 50 square meter floor space and a standardized layout, facilitates rapid and cost-effective store roll-outs, averaging just 14 days for fit-out [9].  This efficient store model and focus on prime locations is crucial for overcoming barriers to entry and establishing a strong international presence.

Ultimately, Lovisa's international store expansion strategy between 2016 and 2020 has been characterized by rapid growth in key international markets, driven by a nimble and opportunistic approach to new market entry and an efficient store roll-out model, while navigating challenges typical of the competitive retail landscape.

The financial year 2020 witnessed a decrease in net interest income (NII) by 9.5% compared to 2019, bringing the total to $\S27.6\mathsf{b n}$ [8]. This reduction was largely attributed to lower average market interest rates in major currencies during 2020 when compared to the previous year [8]. While interest income saw a significant decrease from $\S54.695\mathsf{b n}$ in 2019 to $\S41.756\mathsf{b n}$ in 2020, interest expense also reduced from $\S24.233\mathsf{b n}$ to $\S14.178\mathsf{b n}$ over the same period. ![Net interest income decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image2). Despite the benefit of reduced interest expenses, the more substantial decline in interest income resulted in a lower NII. This decrease in NII directly impacted the net operating income, which fell from $\S53.342\mathsf{b n}$ in 2019 to $\S41.612\mathsf{b n}$ in 2020. ![Net operating income decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image5). Consequently, the overall profitability of the organization was affected, as seen by the drop in basic earnings per share from $0.30$ in 2019 to $0.19$ in 2020, and a decrease in return on average ordinary shareholders’ equity. ![Profitability ratios declined in 2020 compared to 2019](image1).  The changes in net interest income and interest expense from 2019 to 2020 led to a reduction in net operating income and a decline in the overall profitability of the organization.

From 2020 to 2021, net investment income experienced a decrease.  As shown in the financial data, net investment income decreased from $5,039 million in 2020 to $4,807 million in 2021.  This decline is in part due to a significant decrease in interest and other investment income, which dropped by 44.4% compared to 2020, primarily because of lower income from short-term investments and fixed maturity securities, a consequence of prevailing low interest rates [2].  ![Net investment income decreased from 2020 to 2021](image2)  However, this decrease was partially offset by an increase in dividend income which rose by 3.5% due to dividends from investments like Berkshire Hathaway Energy preferred stock [9].

Conversely, railroad operating earnings witnessed a substantial increase during the same period.  According to the provided data, railroad operating earnings increased from $7,152 million in 2020 to $8,811 million in 2021.  This positive change was driven by an 11.6% increase in railroad operating revenues, reflecting higher volumes and average revenue per car/unit, as the economy continued to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic disruptions [7].  While railroad operating expenses also increased by 10.2% due to higher volumes and fuel prices, this was counteracted by productivity improvements, leading to an overall growth in operating earnings [4].  ![Railroad operating earnings increased from 2020 to 2021](image1)

In summary, net investment income decreased while railroad operating earnings increased from 2020 to 2021, influenced by factors such as interest rates, investment performance, pandemic recovery, and operational efficiencies.

McDonald's operates a vast network of restaurants globally, primarily through franchising, as evidenced by the fact that franchised restaurants constituted 93% of their total restaurants in 2020 [9].  The company's financial health, reflected in its balance sheet, shows the progression of its assets and liabilities over time.  ![Shareholders' equity decreased from 2019 to 2020.](image2)  Looking at the restaurant counts, we can see the breakdown between different types of franchises and company-operated restaurants across the years.  ![The number of conventional franchised restaurants increased from 2018 to 2020.](image1) In 2020, McDonald's systemwide restaurants totaled 39,198 [9].  To find the 2018 number, we sum the categories from image1 for 2018: 27,507 (Conventional franchised) + 6,574 (Developmental licensed) + 2,742 (Company-operated), which totals 36,823 restaurants in 2018. In 2020, the company saw a notable increase in both lease assets and inventories compared to 2019. Roche's operating businesses are divided into two main divisions: Pharmaceuticals and Diagnostics [7].  Within the Diagnostics division, a significant structural change occurred in 2021 as part of a transformation initiative [10]. Before 2021, the Diagnostics division was structured into business areas like Centralised and Point of Care Solutions, Molecular Diagnostics, Tissue Diagnostics, and Diabetes Care. However, this structure was replaced with a customer-centric approach, organizing sales into areas such as Core Lab, Molecular Lab, Point of Care, Diabetes Care, and Pathology Lab [10].  ![The Diagnostics Division transitioned from a business area structure to a customer area structure in 2021](image3).  The Pharmaceuticals division includes Roche Pharmaceuticals and Chugai, with Genentech now integrated into Roche Pharmaceuticals [1].  Key executives leading these divisions are part of the Corporate Executive Committee.  ![The Corporate Executive Committee includes leaders for both Pharmaceuticals and Diagnostics divisions](image4).  For example, Bill Anderson is the CEO of Roche Pharmaceuticals, and Dr. Thomas Schinecker is the CEO of Roche Diagnostics, both reporting to the CEO of Roche Group, Dr. Severin Schwan [image1]. The structure of the Diagnostics division shifted from business areas to customer areas in 2021, and key executives like Bill Anderson and Dr. Thomas Schinecker manage the Pharmaceuticals and Diagnostics divisions respectively.

The weighted-average grant date fair value of shares granted for stock options has seen an increase from $43 in 2018 to $54 in 2020, while for restricted shares, it rose from $229 in 2018 to $303 in 2020, reflecting an upward trend in valuation over these years, as detailed in the financial data. ![The table shows the weighted-average grant date fair value of shares granted for stock options and restricted shares from 2018 to 2020](image5). This evolving cost structure, marked by increasing operating and other costs of revenues, alongside substantial R&D investments within general and administrative expenses, indicates a financial management approach focused on growth and future competitiveness, potentially at the expense of short-term profitability.

IBM's financial landscape between 2019 and 2020 reveals shifts in key areas, notably in noncurrent assets and debt management.  Noncurrent assets saw an increase, rising to $116,806 million in 2020 from $113,767 million in the prior year, as depicted in financial statements ![Noncurrent assets and long-term debt increased slightly in 2020 compared to 2019](image2).  Interestingly, while long-term debt experienced a marginal increase to $54,355 million from $54,102 million over the same period also shown in ![Noncurrent assets and long-term debt increased slightly in 2020 compared to 2019](image2), total company debt actually decreased.  This reduction in total debt is highlighted by a decrease of $1,361 million, bringing the total down to $61,538 million in 2020 from $62,899 million in 2019 ![Total company debt and Global Financing debt decreased in 2020, while non-Global Financing debt increased](image4), suggesting a strategic management of debt maturities and retirements [9].

Looking at cash flow dynamics, operating activities became a stronger source of cash, generating $18,197 million in 2020 compared to $14,770 million in 2019, as shown in the cash flow statement ![Operating cash flow increased, while financing cash flow became negative in 2020 compared to 2019](image3).  Conversely, financing activities transitioned from a cash source of $9,042 million in 2019 to a use of cash amounting to $9,721 million in 2020 ![Operating cash flow increased, while financing cash flow became negative in 2020 compared to 2019](image3), a shift partly attributed to reduced cash inflow from non-operating finance receivables [8]. Despite a slight decrease in total equity [7], the Global Financing segment maintained a consistent return on equity at 25.8% in both years ![Global Financing return on equity remained constant at 25.8% in both 2019 and 2020](image1), indicating stable performance in this area.

In conclusion, IBM's financial standing in 2020 was characterized by increased noncurrent assets and a reduction in total debt alongside improved operating cash flow, reflecting strategic financial management despite a slight decrease in overall equity.

In 2020, there was a notable shift in consumer financial behavior, particularly in credit card usage.  Total credit card purchase volumes experienced a significant decline of $26.3 billion [6], as visualized in the data showing a decrease to $251,599 from $277,852 in purchase volumes ![Credit card purchase volume decreased in 2020](image2). This decrease was further reflected in the outstanding credit card portfolio, which dropped by $18.9 billion [4].

Interestingly, debit card purchase volumes increased by $23.8 billion [6], rising to $384,503 from $360,672 ![Debit card purchase volume increased in 2020](image2), suggesting a shift in consumer payment preferences. Simultaneously, home equity production also saw a downturn, decreasing by $3.0 billion [5]. Specifically within consumer banking, home equity figures fell from $9,755 to $6,930 ![Home equity production decreased in Consumer Banking in 2020](image4).  This trend was mirrored in outstanding home equity portfolio balances, which decreased by $5.9 billion [9].

These shifts indicate a more cautious consumer behavior in 2020, likely influenced by economic uncertainties and the impact of COVID-19, leading to reduced credit card spending and home equity borrowing, alongside an increased reliance on debit cards.

Commodity prices are indeed a critical value driver for BHP, significantly influencing their financial outcomes, encompassing cash flows and asset valuations [5]. The fluctuations in these prices directly translate to changes in profitability across different segments.

![Impact of commodity price changes on profit after tax and underlying EBITDA](image1)

For Nickel West in FY2021, the Underlying EBITDA saw a substantial increase of US\$296 million, reaching US\$259 million. This surge was primarily propelled by elevated nickel prices and increased sales volumes [1].  Positive investor sentiment and a robust rebound in end-use demand across diverse geographical areas further bolstered nickel prices during this period [10]. However, this positive impact was partially moderated by unfavorable exchange rate movements and the increased expenses associated with purchasing third-party concentrate due to the higher nickel price [1].

![Financial data for Coal operations in FY2021 and FY2020](image2)

Conversely, Coal experienced a downturn in Underlying EBITDA, decreasing by US\$1.3 billion to US\$288 million. This decline was significantly influenced by lower price impacts, net of price-linked costs, amounting to US\$0.7 billion. Reduced sales volumes further contributed to this decrease, diminishing Underlying EBITDA by US\$168 million [2]. The prices BHP achieves for commodities like nickel and coal are therefore fundamental drivers of the company's financial health, with market dynamics and global demand playing a pivotal role in shaping these prices and subsequently BHP's financial performance.

In conclusion, changes in commodity prices significantly affect BHP's financial results, with higher nickel prices boosting EBITDA while lower coal prices reduced it, driven by factors like global demand, market sentiment, and sales volumes.

In 2021, there was a notable decrease in net interest income compared to 2020, primarily due to factors like lower interest rates and reduced loan balances, which reflected soft demand and elevated refinancing activities [3].  This decrease was also influenced by the sale of their student loan portfolio in the first half of 2021, unfavorable hedge ineffectiveness accounting results, and higher securities premium amortization [3].  Conversely, noninterest income experienced a substantial increase in 2021 [7]. This growth was driven by higher unrealized gains on nonmarketable equity securities, increased realized gains from the sales of equity securities, and reduced impairment of equity securities, all benefiting from improved market conditions [7]. Furthermore, gains from the sales of Corporate Trust Services business, the student loan portfolio, and WFAM also contributed to this rise in noninterest income [7].

```
|                        | 2021     | 2020     | $ Change 2021/2020 | % Change 2021/2020 |
|------------------------|----------|----------|----------------------|----------------------|
| **Net interest income** | $(1,541) | $441     | $(1,982)             | NM                   |
| **Noninterest income**| $10,036  | $4,916   | $5,120               | 104%                 |
| **Total revenue**     | $8,495   | $5,357   | $3,138               | 59%                  |
```
![Income statement for 2020 and 2021 showing changes in net interest income, noninterest income and total revenue.](image1)

Although net interest income declined, the significant surge in noninterest income more than compensated for this decrease, resulting in an overall increase in total revenue [9].  Specifically, total revenue saw an increase due to higher net gains from equity securities and mortgage banking income, alongside investment advisory and other asset-based fee income, despite the offsetting effect of lower net interest income [9].  The net effect of these changes was a positive growth in total revenue from 2020 to 2021.

Toyota's Fleet Management System is designed to be highly responsive to fluctuations in customer demand. As waiting customers increase, the system is engineered to dispatch additional units in real-time, ensuring efficient service [image3]. This proactive approach aims to prevent variations in operation intervals, maintaining a consistent and timely service experience.  The system, exemplified by the one used for e-Palettes during the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, operates on the principles of the Toyota Production System (TPS) to ensure effective, efficient, and accurate operation [3]. It remotely monitors vehicles and manages them in a just-in-time manner, adapting to real-time conditions [3].  This is facilitated through infrastructure like the Toyota Smart Center, which provides a variety of services, and the Toyota Big Data Center, which leverages vehicle information [8]. These centers likely play a crucial role in analyzing demand and triggering the dispatch of additional vehicles as needed. The Mobility Services Platform (MSPF) underpins these operations, connecting vehicles and service providers for seamless mobility solutions [2, image5].

Toyota's Fleet Management System responds to an increase in waiting customers by dispatching additional units in real-time.

Intangible assets acquired can be categorized into definite and indefinite lives, with the former being amortized over their estimated useful lives, which can range from one to thirty years [4].  These assets are initially recorded at cost and subsequently reported net of any impairment losses [1]. When a company acquires another business, identifiable intangible assets are recognized at their fair values [7, 10]. For instance, in certain acquisitions, intangible assets of \$36 million were identified, primarily related to purchased technology [9].  The determination of fair value and useful lives is crucial for these assets [5].

![Identifiable intangible assets including developed technology, customer relations and trade name with their fair value and useful life.](image2)

As illustrated, identifiable intangible assets can include items like developed technology, customer relations, and trade names, each with a specific fair value and useful life. In this example, developed technology has a useful life of 9 years [Image2].  These finite-lived intangible assets such as developed technology and trade names, alongside favorable contracts and leases, are amortized [Image5].  Conversely, some intangible assets like Gigafactory Nevada water rights and in-process research and development are considered indefinite-lived [Image5]. The composition of acquired assets, including intangible assets, is part of the overall purchase price allocation in acquisitions [Image1].

The composition of intangible assets acquired includes both finite-lived assets like developed technology, customer relations, trade names, and favorable contracts, and indefinite-lived assets such as water rights and in-process research and development, with the useful life of finite-lived intangible assets ranging from one to thirty years.

For available-for-sale securities in 2022, the cost basis is adjusted to reflect unrealized gains or losses to arrive at the recorded basis, as demonstrated in the provided data ![Image showing the calculation of recorded basis from cost basis and unrealized losses for available-for-sale securities in 2022](image2). These unrealized gains and losses, stemming from fluctuations in market volatility and interest rates, are not recognized in the income statement but are instead reflected within stockholders’ equity, specifically in accumulated other comprehensive income [1, 6].  Although changes in interest rates can cause fluctuations in fair market value, a 100 basis point change would not have a material impact [1].

Unrealized gains and losses on available-for-sale securities affect the recorded basis by adjusting the fair value, however these adjustments are directly reflected in accumulated other comprehensive income within stockholders' equity, rather than impacting the income statement.

Brazil Minerals, Inc. has several mineral projects in Minas Gerais, Brazil.  The Minas Gerais Lithium Project is currently under research exploration, as evidenced by the detailed mapping, systematic sampling, and analysis of pegmatite occurrences being conducted by a dedicated exploratory geology team [4].  For the Diamond Project located in the same state, it holds 10 mining concessions, the highest level of mining title in Brazil, suggesting it is in an advanced stage, possibly pre-mining licensing or even commercial mining [7]. The Titanium Project, also in Minas Gerais, is composed of 5 mineral rights [3], which generally indicates it is in the early stages, likely pre-mining licensing or research exploration.  The Sand Project, situated on the banks of the Jequitinhonha River in Minas Gerais, is described as having measured deposits and estimations, pointing towards a pre-mining or research exploration phase [6].  ![Rio Piracicaba Project is in Pre-Mining Licensing and Bardo de Cocais Project is in Research Exploration](image1). In addition to these, the Rio Piracicaba Project is in the Pre-Mining Licensing stage and the Bardo de Cocais Project is in Research Exploration, both located in the Iron Quadrangle of Minas Gerais. Currently, various mineral projects in Minas Gerais, Brazil, are in different stages ranging from research exploration to pre-mining licensing.

Qualcomm's revenue is segmented into QCT (Qualcomm CDMA Technologies) and QTL (Qualcomm Technology Licensing), alongside QSI and reconciling items. South Korea also contributes significantly, with $2.368 billion in revenue in 2021, slightly less than $2.964 billion in 2020, but comparable to $2.400 billion in 2019 [7]. To determine the interest coverage ratio for fiscal year 2020, we need to consider the earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) and the interest expense.  Based on the financial data provided, specifically from the income statement, we can find these values for the fiscal year ended January 30, 2021, which corresponds to fiscal year 2020. The operating income, which serves as a proxy for EBIT in this context, was $2,391$, and the interest expense was $\$(52)$ [image2].

Dividing the operating income by the interest expense, we get the interest coverage ratio: $2391 / 52 = 45.980769...$. Rounded to three decimal places, the interest coverage ratio for AMCOR's FY 2020 is 45.981.

The interest coverage ratio for AMCOR's FY 2020 is 45.981.

Morgan Stanley's financial reporting includes both GAAP and non-GAAP measures to provide a comprehensive view of their performance [10]. Return on Tangible Common Equity (ROTCE) is one such non-GAAP measure, representing earnings applicable to common shareholders as a percentage of average tangible common equity [2]. In 2020, the unadjusted ROTCE for Morgan Stanley was 15.2%, as depicted in the financial data table ![Financial data table showing unadjusted and adjusted ROTCE for 2020](image4). However, to offer a clearer picture of underlying performance, particularly after the acquisition of E\*TRADE, Morgan Stanley also presents an adjusted ROTCE, excluding integration-related expenses [3].

This adjustment is detailed in the provided financial information, where integration-related expenses are accounted for to arrive at the non-GAAP adjusted figures ![Table showing adjustments for integration-related expenses and adjusted ROTCE](image4). As a result, the non-GAAP adjusted ROTCE for Morgan Stanley in 2020, excluding the impact of E\*TRADE integration expenses, was 15.4% [4]. This compares to the unadjusted ROTCE of 15.2% for the same period [4], indicating a slight increase in profitability when these one-time integration costs are excluded.

In 2020, Morgan Stanley's non-GAAP adjusted ROTCE was 15.4%, slightly higher than the unadjusted ROTCE of 15.2% for the same year.

The corporate document is structured into several key sections to comprehensively cover various aspects of the company's operations and performance. Section 1 is dedicated to the ‘Strategic Report’, which includes reviews from the Chair and the Chief Executive Officer, and incorporates the operating and financial review [4].  This section, as part of the Directors’ Report, offers insights into the company's operations, results, and future expectations, as detailed in subsections 1.2 to 1.18, among others [1].

![Section 1 of the document is the Strategic Report, detailing various aspects of the business.](image3)

Following this, Section 2, titled ‘Governance’, encompasses the ‘Corporate Governance Statement’, ‘Remuneration Report’, and ‘Directors’ Report’ [3, 4].  The ‘Remuneration Report’ within section 2.2, along with the ‘Strategic Report’ in section 1, are highlighted as separate reports specifically approved by the Board, particularly under UK law [4]. Section 2.3.5 further provides details on ‘Key Management Personnel’ [8].

![Section 2 of the document focuses on Governance and related reports like Remuneration and Directors' Reports.](image4)

Section 3 is devoted to the ‘Financial Statements’, including ‘Consolidated Financial Statements’ and notes, such as note 1 on ‘Segment reporting’ and note 33 on ‘Related party transactions’ within section 3.1 [6, 7]. Lastly, Section 4 contains ‘Additional Information’, covering areas like ‘Financial information summary’, ‘Alternative Performance Measures’, and ‘Shareholder information’ [3, image4].  These sections collectively provide a detailed overview of the company's strategic direction, governance framework, financial performance, and supplementary data.

![Section 3 covers the Financial Statements and related notes.](image4)
![Section 4 includes Additional Information such as financial summaries and shareholder details.](image4)

In summary, the main sections are the Strategic Report, Governance, Financial Statements, and Additional Information.

In East Asia & Australia, there was a decrease in cigarette sales volume, while heated tobacco unit sales saw an increase [8]. Specifically, cigarette volume decreased by 9.7%, whereas heated tobacco units increased by 10.4% as shown in ![East Asia & Australia region experienced a decrease in cigarette volume and an increase in heated tobacco units volume in 2020 compared to 2019](image2). This shift was largely influenced by Japan, with lower cigarette shipment volumes and higher heated tobacco unit shipment volumes [8].

Conversely, Latin America & Canada also experienced a decrease in cigarette sales volume, but with a more substantial increase in heated tobacco units compared to East Asia & Australia. Cigarette volume in Latin America & Canada decreased by 11.8%, but heated tobacco units impressively increased by 50.8% as illustrated in ![Latin America & Canada region experienced a decrease in cigarette volume and a large increase in heated tobacco units volume in 2020 compared to 2019](image4).  The decline in cigarette volume in Latin America & Canada was primarily driven by reduced shipments in Argentina and Mexico, although partially offset by Brazil [8]. Several factors contributed to this, including lower market share in Argentina due to consumers switching to cheaper local brands and retail stock issues [5], and in Mexico, excise tax-driven price hikes and pandemic-related consumption changes [1, 5]. In Colombia, the decline was attributed to reduced product availability and lower average daily consumption due to pandemic restrictions [1]. Canada's decrease was linked to the deconsolidation of RBH [5]. Overall, the estimated total market in Latin America & Canada decreased by 2.8% [2].

In summary, both East Asia & Australia and Latin America & Canada saw cigarette sales volume declines between 2019 and 2020; however, Latin America & Canada experienced a larger decrease in cigarette volume and a more significant increase in heated tobacco unit sales compared to East Asia & Australia.

Costco's financial statement for 2021 categorizes long-term liabilities into a few key components, which provides a detailed breakdown of their obligations beyond the current fiscal year. These components include long-term debt excluding the current portion, obligations from long-term operating leases, and other long-term liabilities, offering a comprehensive view of the company's extended financial commitments.  ![This table shows that long-term liabilities are categorized into long-term debt, long-term operating lease liabilities, and other long-term liabilities](image1). The long-term debt itself is further detailed, consisting of senior notes and other debts, reflecting different financial instruments and their respective values [4, 5, 10]. Furthermore, liabilities also arise from asset retirement obligations, especially concerning leasehold improvements, which are accounted for as discounted liabilities and accreted over the lease term [6]. Deferred tax liabilities also contribute to the long-term liabilities, representing tax obligations that are postponed to future periods [7]. The company also self-insures against various risks, leading to significant insurance liabilities that are part of their overall liabilities [1, 9].

In fiscal year 2021, Costco's total long-term liabilities amounted to approximately $11,749 million.

Costco's long-term debt can be found within their balance sheet, specifically under liabilities.  As shown in the balance sheet for fiscal year 2021, the long-term debt, excluding the current portion, amounted to $6,692 million  ![The balance sheet shows long-term debt, excluding current portion, is 6,692 in 2021](image5). Further details about the composition of this long-term debt, including senior notes and other components, are outlined, totaling $7,531 million before accounting for unamortized debt discounts, issuance costs, and the current portion  ![The table details components of long-term debt, totaling 7,531 before deductions in 2021](image4).  It's also mentioned that as of the end of 2021, the long-term debt with fixed interest rates reached  $\Uparrow,531$ million [6].

Therefore, Costco's long-term debt in FY 2021 was $6,692 million.

In comparison, the total net cash consideration in 2018 for the acquisition of IDT was \$2,078 million, and other acquisitions totaled \$95 million, bringing the combined net cash consideration to \$2,173 million for IDT and other acquisitions ![Net cash consideration for IDT and Others in 2018 is 2,173 million](image1). Discount revenue saw a notable increase between 2020 and 2021. Financial figures reveal a 26% surge in discount revenue, climbing from $20,401 million in 2020 to $25,727 million in 2021 ![Discount revenue increased by 26% from 2020 to 2021](image4).  This growth was largely propelled by a 24 percent expansion in worldwide network volumes, which partially reflects a rebound from the negative impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic [5].  Contributing to this increase were both consumer and commercial sectors, with consumer billed business rising by 29 percent [10] and commercial billed business growing by 21 percent [1].  Additionally, the average discount rate played a role in the revenue increase, moving from 2.28 percent in 2020 to 2.30 percent in 2021, influenced by shifts in spending mix that included higher travel and entertainment (T&E) volumes [7].  In conclusion, discount revenue increased from 2020 to 2021 due to increased network volumes, growth in both consumer and commercial spending, and a slightly higher average discount rate, partly driven by post-pandemic recovery.

Danaher Corporation's total stockholders' equity saw a notable increase between 2018 and 2020, rising from $30,282 million to $39,777 million [image2].  This growth was partly fueled by the issuance of Mandatory Convertible Preferred Stock (MCPS). In 2019, the company issued \$1,600 million of MCPS, followed by another \$1,668 million in 2020 [image1]. These issuances directly boosted the preferred stock component of stockholders' equity, which is evident in the balance sheet changes [image2].  The proceeds from the 2020 MCPS offering, amounting to approximately \$1.67 billion, were intended for general corporate purposes [2].

Cash flow from financing activities also played a crucial role. In 2019, these activities provided a substantial \$16,589 million, primarily due to proceeds from public offerings of both common and preferred stock, and long-term borrowings [image5].  Although in 2020, the cash flow from financing activities was considerably lower at \$1,006 million, it still contributed positively to the company's financial position [image5]. Despite the significant cash inflow from financing in 2019, the total stockholders' equity remained the same as in 2018 [image1, image2]. This could be attributed to factors such as the exchange offer for Envista Holdings Corporation common stock, which reduced retained earnings [image1]. However, by 2020, with continued MCPS issuance and positive financing cash flow, alongside increased retained earnings, the total stockholders' equity experienced a significant increase [image1].

In conclusion, the issuance of mandatory convertible preferred stock and positive cash flow from financing activities were contributing factors to the increase in Danaher Corporation's total stockholders' equity between 2018 and 2020, particularly driving the significant growth observed in 2020.

The U.S. downstream segment experienced a significant turnaround in earnings between 2020 and 2021.  The earnings shifted from a loss of $571 million to a profit of $2,389 million [image1], a notable increase. This positive change was primarily driven by several factors within the downstream operations. Higher margins on refined product sales played a crucial role, contributing an increase of $1.6 billion. Additionally, earnings from CPChem, a 50 percent-owned entity, rose by $1.0 billion, further boosting the segment's profitability [10]. Increased sales volumes also added $470 million to earnings. While operating expenses did increase by $150 million, these were more than offset by the gains from the aforementioned factors [10]. The overall income increase across the company, partly attributed to these improved downstream margins [1, 2], translated to a substantial improvement in the U.S. downstream segment's financial performance.

![U.S. downstream earnings shifted from a loss to a profit between 2020 and 2021.](image1)

In summary, the U.S. downstream segment's earnings dramatically improved from a loss in 2020 to a profit in 2021, primarily due to higher margins on refined products, increased earnings from CPChem, and greater sales volumes.

The company's long-term incentive schemes use EBIT growth as a key performance indicator to determine the exercisable percentage of incentives [10].  For instance, one set of performance options specifies that if the EBIT growth is less than the threshold, no incentives are exercisable,  ![Nil exercisable percentage for less than threshold EBIT growth](image3). However, as the EBIT growth increases, the exercisable percentage also rises; for example, a 24% compound growth in EBIT results in 10% of incentives being exercisable, escalating to 100% exercisable when the compound growth reaches 26% in this scenario ![EBIT growth percentage corresponds to the incentive exercisable percentage](image3). Another set of performance conditions outlines a different scale where a 17.5% compound growth yields a 40% exercisable percentage, reaching 100% exercisable at a 25% compound growth rate ![Another EBIT growth percentage corresponds to a different incentive exercisable percentage](image4).  In summary, higher EBIT growth over the performance period directly correlates with a greater percentage of exercisable incentives.

Chevron Corporation experienced a significant shift in both net income and comprehensive income from 2020 to 2021. Net income dramatically increased from a loss of $5,561 million to a profit of $15,689 million [Image 5], reflecting a substantial financial turnaround. This positive change is visually represented in the consolidated statement of income.

![Net income significantly increased in 2021 compared to 2020](image5)

This remarkable increase in net income was primarily fueled by several key factors across Chevron's operations.  Notably, U.S. income before tax saw a considerable rise due to higher upstream realizations, improved downstream margins, and the absence of impairments and write-offs that had impacted the 2020 figures [4]. Similarly, international upstream earnings benefited from higher realizations and the non-recurrence of 2020 impairments and severance charges [6].  Furthermore, U.S. downstream operations reported higher earnings driven by increased margins on refined product sales and enhanced contributions from equity affiliates [8].

In parallel, comprehensive income attributable to Chevron Corporation also saw a major positive change, moving from a loss of $6,165 million in 2020 to a profit of $17,348 million in 2021 [Image 4]. This is evident when observing the components of comprehensive income.

![Comprehensive income also significantly increased in 2021 compared to 2020](image4)

The increase in comprehensive income, beyond the net income improvement, was additionally influenced by a positive swing in other comprehensive income components.  Specifically, there was a favorable change within defined benefit plans, contributing to the overall increase in comprehensive income [Image 4].

In conclusion, Chevron's financial performance markedly improved from 2020 to 2021, with both net income and comprehensive income transitioning from substantial losses to significant profits, driven by higher realizations across upstream operations, improved downstream performance, and positive changes in other comprehensive income components.

HDFC Bank provides parental leave benefits to its employees, illustrating a commitment to work-life balance. ![Parental leave data for male and female employees](image5).  The parental leave entitlement data reveals that while a larger number of male employees (98,347) are entitled to parental leave compared to female employees (21,746), the actual availing of leave is more balanced, with 1,025 female employees and 2,023 male employees utilizing this benefit.  Notably, the return to work rate after parental leave is impressively high for both genders, with 94% of women and 96% of men returning to their roles and remaining employed after 12 months, suggesting a supportive work environment [1]. This might be linked to initiatives aimed at fostering inclusion and diversity, such as the ‘Careers 2.0’ program designed to bring women professionals back to work after career breaks [6], and broader efforts to address unconscious biases within the organization [9].  These initiatives, alongside policies promoting flexible work arrangements [10], reflect the bank's broader goal of achieving 25% representation of women in its workforce by FY25 [6]. HDFC Bank's parental leave policy is available to both male and female employees, but entitlement and usage patterns reveal subtle differences that may reflect ongoing efforts to enhance gender diversity and inclusivity in practice.

Caterpillar's Machinery, Energy & Transportation sector experienced notable shifts in both sales and operating profit between the fourth quarters of 2020 and 2021. The firm calculates risk-based capital ratios using both a Standardized Approach with prescribed risk weights, and an Advanced Approach which uses models [1, 3].  For risk-based capital, comparing 2020 to 2019 under the Standardized Approach, all ratios have decreased. Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio decreased from 16.4% to 13.2%, Tier 1 capital ratio decreased from 18.6% to 14.7%, and Total capital ratio decreased from 21.0% to 16.7%.

![Standardized Approach ratios for risk-based capital decreased in 2020 compared to 2019.](image4)

![Standardized Approach ratios for risk-based capital in 2020.](image1)

Conversely, under the Advanced Approach, the risk-based capital ratios have slightly increased from 2019 to 2020. Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased from 16.9% to 17.7%, Tier 1 capital ratio increased from 19.2% to 19.8%, and Total capital ratio increased from 21.5% to 21.8% [image1, image4]. This increase in Common Equity Tier 1 capital is primarily due to increased retained earnings and the E*TRADE acquisition [10].  Market volatility and the E*TRADE acquisition also contributed to an increase in credit risk RWA under both approaches [6, 9].

For leverage-based capital, the Tier 1 leverage ratio saw a slight increase from 8.3% in 2019 to 8.4% in 2020, and the SLR increased from 6.4% to 7.4% [image5, image6].

![Tier 1 leverage ratio and SLR increased in 2020 compared to 2019.](image5)

![Tier 1 leverage ratio and SLR in 2019.](image6)

In summary, risk-based capital ratios showed a decrease under the Standardized Approach and a slight increase under the Advanced Approach, while leverage-based capital ratios increased from 2019 to 2020.

In 2021, Inditex's store distribution was segmented across different regions, including Spain, Rest of Europe, Americas, and Rest of the World, with a total of 6,477 stores, encompassing both company-managed and franchised locations ![Distribution of Inditex stores by region in 2021](image3). This expansion occurred even as Inditex was actively engaged in store optimization, a strategy that included absorbing stores deemed to be at the end of their useful life, particularly those in younger formats [1, 4].  This optimization process in 2021 involved a significant number of store closures, specifically 578 units, while still managing to open new stores in 40 markets [4].
