The economic conditions for different racial and ethnic groups reveal nuanced trends. While Hispanic households experienced stagnation in median income since the Great Recession [1], and about half reported their income not keeping pace with the cost of living in both 2014 and 2015 [7, 8], views on family income relative to cost of living remained consistent for Hispanics between these years [7].  However, a comparison among racial groups in relation to income falling behind the cost of living from 2014 to 2015 highlights a change for White households ![Comparison of income falling behind cost of living in 2014 and 2015 for Hispanic, White, and Black groups](image4).

Interestingly, while Hispanic and Black households showed no change in the percentage reporting their income falling behind the cost of living between 2014 and 2015, White households experienced a decrease. In 2014, 56% of White households felt their income was not keeping up with living costs, which decreased to 50% in 2015 ![Comparison of income falling behind cost of living in 2014 and 2015 for Hispanic, White, and Black groups](image4). This indicates a 6 percentage point drop for White households, suggesting an improvement in their perceived financial situation relative to the cost of living [10].

The White group experienced the most significant drop, with a 6% decrease in the percentage of households claiming their income was falling behind the cost of living.

Americans generally agree on several measures related to elections [8].  For instance, a significant majority supports the idea of requiring electronic voting machines to have a paper backup of ballots, highlighting a consensus across different demographics and political affiliations.  This is further illustrated in survey data showing strong support for this measure across age groups and party lines, as seen in the detailed breakdowns. ![Breakdown of support for automatic voter registration and removing people from registration lists across age groups and political affiliations](image1).  Notably,  82% of adults favor the implementation of paper backups for electronic voting [2].  Other popular proposals include making early in-person voting accessible for at least two weeks before Election Day and mandating government-issued photo ID for voting [2]. While automatic voter registration also garners majority support, it is slightly less favored compared to other proposals [5].  Conversely, removing individuals from voter registration lists for inactivity is the only policy that faces majority opposition [6].  Examining trends over time, support for some proposals like automatic voter registration has shifted among Republicans, while remaining stable among Democrats [7].  However, the consistently highest level of public endorsement is observed for requiring paper backups for electronic voting machines, as demonstrated by various surveys conducted over time. ![Trends in support for various election proposals over time](image2).

Overall, the election-related proposal with the highest level of public support is requiring electronic voting machines to print a paper backup of the ballot.

Hispanic Republicans and Hispanic Democrats hold contrasting views regarding the Republican Party's concern for Hispanics [3].  While a substantial percentage of Hispanic Republicans believe the Republican Party cares, this sentiment is not shared by the majority of Hispanic Democrats.  ![Image showing percentage of different groups who think Republican Party cares about Hispanics "Very/Extremely well"](image2) As shown, a significantly higher percentage of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (43%) believe the statement "the Republican Party really cares about Hispanics" describes their views very or extremely well, compared to only 4% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners.  This disparity is further highlighted when considering those who feel the statement describes their views "somewhat well." ![Image showing percentage of different groups who think Republican Party cares about Hispanics "Somewhat well" and "Not at all well"](image3)  A larger proportion of Hispanic Republicans perceive the Republican Party as caring at least somewhat, yet even among them, a considerable number express lukewarm or negative views [3].  In stark contrast, a strong majority across the ideological spectrum within Hispanic Democrats, whether conservative, moderate, or liberal, do not believe the Republican Party cares about Hispanics [2].  Overall, a majority of Hispanics express skepticism, with a significant portion stating that the statement "the Republican Party really cares about Hispanics" does not describe their views well [9].  ![Image showing percentage of different groups who think Republican Party does not care about Hispanics "Not at all well"](image4) This negative perception is particularly pronounced among Hispanic Democrats, while even some Hispanic Republicans harbor doubts [10].  In conclusion, Hispanic Republicans are significantly more inclined to believe that the Republican Party cares about Hispanics compared to Hispanic Democrats, though even within the Republican demographic, there is not a universally strong conviction.

Americans' evaluations of the U.S. COVID-19 response are significantly shaped by their level of education [6].  Those with postgraduate degrees are notably more critical, with approximately two-thirds expressing that the U.S. has performed poorly, a view shared by around six-in-ten college graduates [5]. In stark contrast, this negative assessment is held by only about four-in-ten individuals with a high school degree or less [5].  This pattern is visually represented, demonstrating a clear trend: as education levels increase, so does the proportion of individuals rating the U.S. response as only fair or poor ![Individuals with postgraduate degrees are more likely to rate the U.S. COVID-19 response as only fair or poor compared to those with lower education levels.](image2).  The data further illustrates this disparity, showing that 66% of postgraduates rate the response negatively, compared to just 43% of those with a high school education or less ![A higher percentage of individuals with postgraduate degrees rate the U.S. COVID-19 response as only fair or poor compared to those with lower education levels, with a clear declining trend in negative ratings as education level decreases.](image3).  Another visual representation reinforces this, revealing a similar pattern where negative ratings are higher among the more educated and lower among the less educated ![Negative ratings of the U.S. COVID-19 response are more prevalent among individuals with postgraduate degrees and college graduates compared to those with some college or high school education or less.](image4).  It's evident that higher education is associated with a more critical perspective on the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.

In conclusion, evaluations of the U.S. COVID-19 response become more critical as individuals' levels of education increase.

Hamilton County, Nebraska, experienced significant population changes between 1870 and 2000. Initially, the county saw a dramatic population surge in the late 1800s [5].  This population boom is clearly illustrated in the provided census data, showing a rise from a mere 130 residents in 1870 to a peak of 14,096 in 1890 ![Population of Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000](image3). This explosion was largely fueled by the Transcontinental Railroad Act and the Homestead Act of 1862, which transformed Nebraska into an agricultural powerhouse and encouraged westward migration [9]. The railroad facilitated transportation and trade, while the Homestead Act offered free land, attracting settlers to the region [9].

Following this peak in 1890, Hamilton County's population began a slow decline [5], as evidenced by the census data ![Population of Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000](image3).  While many small towns in the Midwest and Great Plains typically reached their population peak between 1900 and 1940 [3], some communities within Hamilton County demonstrated more recent population gains, defying the general trend of small town decline [2].  However, the overarching trend reflects a decrease from the late 19th century apex, influenced by factors like farm consolidation and changing agricultural practices [2, 4].

In conclusion, Hamilton County's population initially exploded due to railroad expansion and homesteading in the late 19th century, reaching its peak in 1890, followed by a general decline throughout the 20th century, although some towns showed recent growth against the backdrop of broader rural population trends.

Partisan opinions regarding President Obama's foreign policy toughness are notably divided [10].  A large majority of Republicans, specifically 84%, express the sentiment that Obama's approach to foreign policy is not sufficiently tough ![Breakdown of opinions on Obama's foreign policy toughness by party affiliation](image2). This view is echoed by a significant majority of independents, with 61% sharing the opinion that Obama is 'not tough enough' [2].

Conversely, Democrats hold a different perspective; the majority, at 58%, believe Obama's approach is 'about right' [8]. However, it's important to note that within the Democratic party, there's a split: conservative and moderate Democrats are more inclined (45%) to say Obama is 'not tough enough' compared to liberal Democrats (26%) [8].  Overall public sentiment also leans towards perceiving Obama as 'not tough enough' on foreign policy, with 58% holding this view [5, 6, 7].

In conclusion, partisan views are significantly different, with Republicans and a majority of independents believing Obama was 'not tough enough' on foreign policy, while Democrats are more inclined to think his approach was 'about right'.

Americans show a notably strong preference for limiting robots and computers to roles that are hazardous or detrimental to health, with a significant  $85\%$  in favor of this concept [5, 7]. While Democrats and Republicans differ significantly in their support for universal basic income and national service programs, support for restricting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs is consistently high across party lines [3, 6].  ![Support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is high across party lines, exceeding support for other policies like universal basic income and national service programs](image2).  This suggests that limiting automation in this way is seen as a particularly agreeable and broadly supported approach compared to other, more debated policy interventions.

Americans express varying levels of confidence in President Biden's ability to navigate international matters, with a notable difference when it comes to China. While a majority of Americans have confidence in Biden to handle world affairs generally, this percentage decreases specifically concerning China [1].  In fact, Americans demonstrate less faith in Biden's capabilities to effectively deal with China than with other foreign policy challenges [2, 4, 7, 10].

This disparity is evident when comparing confidence levels across different foreign policy domains.  While around half of Americans are confident in Biden's approach to China, a significantly larger percentage express confidence in his ability to improve relationships with allies, handle terrorism threats, address global climate change, make sound decisions on military force, and manage international trade [3].  This comparison is visually represented, highlighting that dealing with China is the area where Americans express the least confidence in President Biden compared to improving relationships with allies, handling terrorism, climate change, trade, and military force ![Americans have less confidence in Biden to handle China compared to other foreign policy issues](image3).  Specifically, while 53% are confident in Biden regarding China, higher percentages are seen for other areas [3].

Furthermore, a significant partisan divide exists regarding confidence in Biden's China policy.  Democrats overwhelmingly express confidence, while Republicans show considerably less, revealing a stark contrast in partisan perspectives [5, 8]. There are also demographic variations in confidence levels, with women and minority groups exhibiting more confidence in Biden's China approach than men and White adults, respectively [9].

In conclusion, Americans exhibit less confidence in President Biden's ability to effectively handle the complexities of US-China relations compared to other prominent foreign policy issues.

In 2016, there was a noticeable partisan divide among voters regarding political leaders cooperating with the newly elected president, Donald Trump.  A significant majority of Trump voters, 83%, believed Democratic leaders should collaborate with him, even if it meant disappointing their own supporters [1].  However, this view was not shared by Clinton voters, with only 35% agreeing [1].  In fact, a larger portion of Clinton voters, 63%, preferred Democrats to stand firm against Trump on key issues, even if it led to less progress in Washington [1]. This partisan gap was more pronounced in 2016 compared to the situation in 2008 following Obama's election [2].

![Comparison of voter opinions on cooperation with newly elected presidents in 2008 and 2016](image2)

Looking back to 2008, as Barack Obama prepared to take office, opinions were different.  A large majority of Obama's voters, 78%, thought Democratic leaders should work with Republicans, even at the risk of disappointing their own base [5].  Similarly, a comparable percentage of McCain's voters, 76%, held the same view [5].  Even among McCain voters, a majority, 58%, felt Republican leaders should make an effort to cooperate with Obama [8].  This contrasted with the sentiment among Democratic voters in 2016, where a larger percentage favored standing up to Trump [6].  Overall, in November 2008, Republicans were more inclined towards their leaders working with Obama, with nearly 59% supporting cooperation [9].  This demonstrates a notable shift in voter attitudes between 2008 and 2016 concerning political cooperation with the newly elected president [7].

Voter opinions regarding political leaders working with newly elected presidents showed a greater partisan divide and less support for cooperation in 2016 compared to 2008.

Opinions on national defense spending reveal interesting differences between Americans and Germans from 2017 to 2019. In the United States, there's been a notable shift in perspective regarding European allies' defense budgets [10].  In 2017, a significant 45% of Americans believed that these allies should increase their defense spending, but by 2019, this view had changed, with half of Americans then suggesting that spending levels should remain the same [10]. This shift is further illustrated when considering the views of different political affiliations in the U.S.

![Views on allies increasing defense spending among Republicans and Democrats in the US from 2017 to 2019](image2)

As shown, within the Republican party, the percentage favoring increased defense spending by European allies decreased from 59% in 2017 to 48% in 2019 [image2].  This trend indicates a softening in the American stance on pushing for increased defense spending from European partners [8].  Interestingly, when directly asked about whether European allies *should* increase defense spending in 2019, 35% of Americans still favored an increase, while a larger proportion, 50%, preferred spending to remain at the same level ![Americans' and Germans' opinions on defense spending changes in 2019](image5).

In contrast, Germans present a more divided perspective on their *own* national defense spending [7].  The German public is split between those who believe in increasing defense budgets and those who prefer to maintain the current levels [7].  In 2019, when asked if Germany *should* increase defense spending, only 25% agreed, while a larger 41% preferred to keep spending the same ![Americans' and Germans' opinions on defense spending changes in 2019](image5).  This internal division in Germany marks a change from 2017 when more Germans were content with existing spending levels [7].

Over the period of 2017 to 2019, American sentiment shifted towards maintaining rather than increasing European allies' defense spending, while Germans remained divided on their own defense spending with a slight preference for maintaining current levels.

Public concern about terrorism saw a significant increase, while economic worries decreased between December 2014 and December 2015.  As indicated, the proportion of the public citing terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most pressing issue rose dramatically from just 4% to 29% over the year [8]. This surge made terrorism the most important problem for many Americans, a stark contrast to the previous year [9].

![Image4 shows that in December 2014, terrorism was a relatively minor concern compared to economic issues.](image4)

Conversely, focus on economic problems diminished notably.  The percentage of Americans mentioning economic issues as the nation's top concern fell from 34% in December 2014 to 23% in the following year [1]. This shift highlights a change in public priorities, with terrorism taking precedence over economic anxieties.

In summary, from December 2014 to December 2015, public concern over terrorism increased sharply, while concern over economic issues decreased.

Following the election, opinions diverged regarding whether Donald Trump would prioritize the needs of his supporters over all Americans [6].  A notable contrast emerges when examining the perspectives of Trump and Clinton voters.  An overwhelming majority of Trump's voters believed he would give equal priority to all Americans [2].  In stark contrast, a significant majority of Clinton's voters anticipated that he would prioritize his supporters [2].  This difference is visually represented in survey data, where we can see the stark contrast in percentages between Trump and Clinton voters regarding Trump's prioritization. ![Survey data reveals the percentage breakdown of voters' opinions on Trump prioritizing needs, highlighting the divide between Trump and Clinton voters](image4).  Ultimately, Trump voters and Clinton voters held opposing views on whether Trump would prioritize his supporters or all Americans.

As people spend more generations in the U.S., their perception of how strangers view their ethnicity changes [9].  Immigrant self-identified Hispanics believe that strangers would identify them as Hispanic or Latino at a rate of 78%. This perception decreases to two-thirds for second-generation Hispanics and further declines to 46% for third or higher generation Hispanics [9].  This shift in external perception is mirrored in self-identification of race. ![This image indicates the racial makeup of Hispanics and non-Hispanics, broken down by generation, showcasing a shift from Hispanic to White identification across generations within Hispanics.](image5) While a large proportion of Hispanics, across all generations, identify as Hispanic or Latino, the percentage identifying as White increases from the foreign-born generation to the third or higher generation.

In summary, racial identification among self-identified Hispanics shifts across generations, with later generations less likely to be perceived as Hispanic by strangers and more likely to identify as White compared to earlier generations.

Black professionals in STEM fields express higher rates of perceived racial discrimination at work compared to their counterparts from other racial and ethnic backgrounds [7].  Notably, a significant 62% of Black STEM employees report experiencing discrimination because of their race or ethnicity [7].  This contrasts sharply with the experiences of other groups in STEM, such as Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and Whites (just 13%) [2, 7].  ![This image highlights the varying percentages of White, Hispanic, Asian, and Black STEM workers who report experiencing discrimination at work, and their differing opinions on fair treatment in hiring and promotions.](image3).  Furthermore, Black STEM workers are considerably more inclined to perceive discrimination as a primary driver behind the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM professions [3].  Specifically, 72% of Black individuals in STEM believe that discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major contributing factor [4, 10]. This perspective differs markedly from that of White and Asian STEM workers, with only about 27% and 28% respectively sharing this view [10].  In comparison to White STEM professionals, Black STEM employees also exhibit less assurance in the equitable treatment of Black individuals within their workplaces, particularly in hiring and promotion processes [5].  While a majority of White STEM workers perceive fair treatment for Black employees in hiring (78%) and promotions (75%), only 43% and 37% of Black STEM workers concur, respectively [5].  In summary, perceptions of workplace discrimination and fairness diverge significantly among racial and ethnic groups in STEM, with Black STEM professionals reporting the highest incidence of perceived discrimination and expressing the least confidence in equitable treatment.

Voter evaluations after the 2016 election reveal a noteworthy trend concerning Donald Trump's grades compared to previous winning candidates.  Assessments of Trump's conduct during the campaign were notably harsh, marking the lowest grades received by a victorious candidate in nearly three decades [8].  Indeed, voters assigned Trump lower grades than any other winning candidate in recent history [10].  This is visually represented in a comparative chart spanning elections from 1988 to 2016, where Trump's grade stands as the lowest among winning candidates. ![Bar chart comparing voter grades of winning candidates from 1988 to 2016, with Trump's grade being the lowest](image2).  In summary, Donald Trump's voter grades in 2016 were the lowest in comparison to other winning candidates since 1988.

Americans widely acknowledge the potential for the U.S. to gain knowledge from other nations in managing the coronavirus spread [5]. This sentiment is particularly strong among liberal Democrats, with a significant 67% believing the U.S. can learn a great deal, contrasting with 25% of conservative Republicans [2].  It is observed that individuals who believe in the U.S.'s capacity to learn from abroad are more inclined to rate other countries' handling of the pandemic positively [3, 6].

Notably, Germany and South Korea receive high praise from Americans for their COVID-19 responses [9].  This positive perception is even more pronounced among those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries, as shown in the increased percentage difference for Germany and South Korea when comparing those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries versus those who don't ![Germany and South Korea are perceived much more positively by those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries](image3).  In contrast, countries like China, Italy, the UK and even the US itself show a smaller or negative difference, suggesting less consensus or even a negative perception among those who believe the U.S. can learn from abroad ![Comparison of country handling perceptions based on belief in US learning potential](image3).

Therefore, based on the provided information, Germany and South Korea are the countries from which the highest percentage of respondents believe the U.S. can learn.

Partisan lines deeply divide opinions on presidential conduct [9].  Democrats overwhelmingly express disapproval of Trump's behavior in office, with a large majority stating they dislike his conduct [1, 6].  Their views are largely consistent, with only a small fraction expressing mixed feelings or liking his behavior [1].

![Image5 shows that among Democrats and Democrat-leaning individuals, 85% express dislike for Trump's conduct.](image5)

Republicans, while generally more supportive, present a more nuanced picture.  A significant portion of Republicans have mixed feelings about Trump's conduct, and a notable percentage even dislike it [6, 7].  Conservative Republicans are more inclined to approve of his conduct compared to moderate or liberal Republicans, indicating internal divisions within the party itself [2].  However, as shown, even among Republicans, "like" is not the majority sentiment regarding Trump's conduct.

![Image5 visually breaks down the sentiments, showing that only 38% of Republicans/lean Republican like Trump's conduct, while 45% have mixed feelings.](image5)

In conclusion, Republicans and Democrats hold starkly contrasting views on Trump's conduct as president, reflecting a deep partisan divide.

Americans are significantly divided along political lines regarding the government's role in supporting workers displaced by automation.  Democrats are substantially more inclined to believe that the government has a responsibility to care for these workers, even if it necessitates higher taxes for others [1].  This perspective is visually reinforced by survey data showing a stark contrast:  a significantly larger percentage of Democrats believe the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers compared to Republicans ![Democrats are far more likely to support government intervention for displaced workers than Republicans](image5).  Conversely, Republicans predominantly believe that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even in the face of widespread job automation [1].  This partisan divide extends to support for specific government programs aimed at aiding displaced workers; for example, Democrats are much more in favor of universal basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans [5].  These differences are clearly illustrated in survey results highlighting the partisan gap in support for a guaranteed basic income and a national service program ![Significant partisan differences exist in support for government programs for displaced workers](image3).

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly dictates opinions on whether the government should be responsible for supporting workers displaced by automation, with Democrats being significantly more supportive of government intervention than Republicans.

Republican identifiers strongly support expanding the border wall, with a large majority favoring it [2].  This view is echoed, although with less intensity, by Republican-leaning independents, among whom a substantial majority still supports the expansion [2].  ![This image displays the percentage of people who favor or oppose substantially expanding the border wall along the US-Mexico border, broken down by political affiliation.](image4) In stark contrast, Democrats and those who lean Democratic overwhelmingly oppose the expansion of the border wall [4]. Initially, there was broad public satisfaction with the performance of public health officials in managing the coronavirus outbreak, but this sentiment has shifted notably [4].  Specifically, views on public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have diverged along party lines [9].  As shown in the graph, positive ratings from Republicans for public health officials have experienced a sharp decrease, falling from 84% to 53% since March [3, 7].  ![This image shows the trend of public health officials' approval ratings over time, separated by party affiliation, indicating a decline among Republicans.](image5)  This contrasts with Democrats, whose views have remained largely consistent, with approximately 72% currently holding positive views, a figure similar to the 74% observed in March [3, 7].  The current landscape reveals a significant partisan gap in the assessment of public health officials' handling of the coronavirus, with 72% of Democrats expressing approval compared to only 53% of Republicans [9].  ![This image compares current approval ratings for various entities, including public health officials, between Democrats and Republicans, highlighting the partisan difference.](image2)

In conclusion, Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to view the COVID-19 response of public health officials positively.

Compared to the general population, older adults adopt technology at a lower rate [4].  Although cell phone use is common among seniors, with 77% owning one, it's still less than the 91% of all Americans who own cell phones [3].  Smartphones, in particular, are not widely adopted by seniors; only 18% of seniors use smartphones, a figure significantly below the national adoption rate of 55% [1, 6]. This disparity in smartphone adoption is visually represented, highlighting the difference between all adults and those aged 65 and over. ![Smartphone adoption is significantly lower among adults 65+ compared to all adults](image1).  Furthermore, when considering broader technology usage, including internet and broadband, a clear gap exists between seniors and all adults, as illustrated in the following comparison. ![Technology adoption, including cell phones, internet, and broadband, is lower among adults 65+ compared to all adults](image3).  In conclusion, technology adoption rates are generally lower among adults aged 65 and older compared to all adults.

Caltrain's current peak service operates with 5-car trains, running 5 trains per hour, which amounts to 25 train cars during peak hours [10].  To enhance service and capacity, several scenarios have been considered, as outlined in service improvement plans ![Scenario Peak service Peak hour train cars
Today 5x5 25
Metrolink used cars 6x5 30
Electrification 6x6 36
Longer platforms 6x8 48
Increase frequency (wW/HSR) 8x8 64](image5).  If Caltrain were to utilize Metrolink used cars, the service could operate with 6 trains per hour using 5-car trains, totaling 30 cars [9].  Electrification could further increase this to 6 trains per hour with 6-car trains, resulting in 36 peak hour train cars. Expanding platforms to accommodate longer trains allows for 6 trains per hour with 8-car trains, bringing the total to 48 cars [5].  The most ambitious scenario, increasing frequency in conjunction with High-Speed Rail (HSR), envisions 8 trains per hour with 8-car trains, reaching a peak of 64 train cars [2].  These scenarios demonstrate a clear progression in peak hour train car requirements as Caltrain service undergoes improvements.  The requirement for peak hour train cars increases with each service improvement scenario for Caltrain.

Therefore, ethical standards ratings for Trump administration officials are lower than those of previous administrations.

Views of China among Americans have become increasingly negative over time [1, 9]. Americans' perception of the United States as the world's leading economic power has seen a shift, with a decrease in confidence recently [2].  ![This image shows the percentage of people who believe the U.S. or China is the world's leading economic power from 2008 to 2020, illustrating a trend over time.](image1)  In March, 59% of Americans held this view, but this has declined to 52% more recently [2]. Mobile advertising in Vietnam shows a strong inclination towards mobile applications, evidenced by the fact that a significant portion of ad impressions occur within this environment [6]. Americans and Germans hold contrasting perspectives regarding the world's leading economic power. While half of Americans identify the U.S. as the foremost economic power, with about a third considering China, Germans predominantly lean towards China, with roughly half holding this view compared to a smaller percentage who believe it is the U.S. [1].  This divergence is highlighted by the statistic that half of Americans perceive their nation as the top economic power, while Germans are more inclined to name China [2].  ![This image probably lists the potential candidates for the world's leading economic power, which includes the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image3).  Despite these differing views on economic leadership, Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China, whereas Americans are almost equally divided in their preference between Germany and China [7]. To summarize, Americans are more inclined to view the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, while Germans are more likely to consider China as the leader [1, 2].

Mechanization dramatically changed farming practices in the United States, leading to significant consolidation and impacting rural communities [1].  This shift in farming scale is reflected in the changing number of farms over time. In 1880, the number of farms stood at 2,039, but by 1950, this number had decreased to 1,453 ![The table indicates a decrease in the number of farms from 2,039 in 1880 to 1,453 in 1950.](image3). This decline is consistent with broader trends observed in regions like Hamilton County, where farm numbers began to decrease after the turn of the 20th century [1].  In summary, the number of farms in the U.S. decreased from 1880 to 1950.

Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to perceive a lack of ethical standards in both major parties [4].  For example, among those holding a college degree, a significant portion, $31\%$, believe that "high ethical standards" is not descriptive of either the Republican or Democratic Party [1].  This skepticism is further highlighted when compared to those with less education, as fewer individuals with some college experience $(26\%)$ or a high school degree or less $(20\%)$ share this view [10].

![Image2 shows that as education level increases from 'HS or less' to 'College grad+', the percentage of people who think neither party has ethical standards also increases.](image2)

Moreover, political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping these perceptions. Independents are notably more likely to express that neither party upholds "high ethical standards" compared to those who identify with a party [5].  Interestingly, while majorities within both Republican and Democratic parties tend to describe their own party as having high ethical standards, partisans are somewhat less positive in these assessments than they might be expected to be [3]. This indicates a nuanced understanding of ethical standards within political groups, with independents exhibiting greater skepticism and even partisans showing some level of critical assessment.

Public perception of ethical standards differs notably across educational attainment and political affiliation, with higher education and independent status associated with increased skepticism towards both parties.

Thus, tablets and e-readers are at least as common as smartphones among seniors.

Age is a significant factor impacting technology adoption among seniors [7]. The STEM workforce has become more diverse over the past 25 years, mirroring the increasing diversity in the overall workforce [2]. Initially, public approval for public health officials was high, but it has since decreased [9]. This decline, however, is not uniform across all political groups.  Specifically, there has been a sharp decrease in positive ratings among Republicans.  In late March, a large majority of Republicans, 84%, viewed public health officials positively, but this number has fallen dramatically to just 53% by August [2].  This represents a significant 31-point drop [1, 8]. Democrats, on the other hand, have maintained a largely consistent positive view, with around 74% approval in March and 72% in August [1, 2].

![Approval ratings for public health officials, state and local officials, and Donald Trump, showing a decline in approval for public health officials and state officials between March and August, with partisan breakdowns.](image3)

This partisan divergence is clearly visible in the current ratings.  As of August, there is a substantial gap between Democrats and Republicans in their assessment of public health officials, with 72% of Democrats and only 53% of Republicans expressing positive views [6].  This partisan gap is also evident when comparing overall approval ratings with those of political figures like Donald Trump, where partisan lines are deeply entrenched [7].  The differing trends in approval ratings among Republicans and Democrats reveal a significant polarization in how public health officials are perceived [4].

![Current approval ratings for hospitals, public health officials, local officials, state officials, and Donald Trump, broken down by Democrat and Republican leanings, highlighting the partisan divide in views on public health officials.](image4)

In conclusion, approval ratings for public health officials experienced a significant decrease among Republicans from March to August, while remaining relatively stable among Democrats, leading to a pronounced partisan gap in their views.

Hispanics consistently demonstrated greater optimism about their financial prospects compared to the general public from 2004 to 2015 [10].  This trend is evident in the increasing percentage of Hispanics who anticipated improvements in their family finances, as depicted in the graphical representation ![Line graph showing Hispanic optimism exceeding general public optimism](image2).  Notably, the rise in financial optimism among Latinos outpaced that of the general population between 2008 and 2015 [2].  While the broader American public's financial outlook remained below 2004 levels, Hispanic perceptions of their financial situations actually became more positive during this period [5].  In summary, Hispanic financial expectations were more optimistic than the general public's and experienced a more significant increase between 2004 and 2015.

Older adults who use the internet overwhelmingly recognize the importance of online access, with a large majority, 79%, affirming that individuals without internet face a significant disadvantage due to missed information [1, 6].  This perspective is highlighted in survey data where a substantial portion of internet users express strong agreement with this view.

![A bar chart comparing the agreement levels between internet users and non-users, showing a much higher agreement among internet users.](image3)

Conversely, seniors who do not use the internet hold more varied opinions on this matter [7].  While approximately half of non-users acknowledge the disadvantage of lacking internet access, a notable 35% disagree, with 18% strongly disagreeing [4, 10]. This indicates a divide in perception among non-internet users regarding the essential nature of online access in today's information landscape.  In essence, internet users are far more convinced of the disadvantages of lacking internet access compared to non-users.

Many Americans anticipate a shift in China's global influence following the coronavirus outbreak. Specifically, half of the surveyed Americans believe that China will experience a decline in its influence on the world stage [4, 9].  This perspective is further underscored by the fact that 50% of respondents explicitly stated their belief that China's global stature will diminish in the long term due to the pandemic [3].  This contrasts with views on other global powers, as fewer Americans believe the same fate awaits the U.S. or the European Union [9].  However, not all Americans share this view; roughly one-in-five Americans actually foresee an increase in China's global influence, while about a third anticipate its global standing to remain largely unchanged after the crisis ![Breakdown of American perceptions regarding China's future global influence into "About the same influence" and "More influence" categories](image4).  It's important to consider that negative sentiments towards China have been on an upward trend. Unfavorable opinions have reached their highest point since 2005, with 66% of Americans expressing negative views [3]. This negative trend in sentiment is captured in historical data illustrating the increasing "A great deal/a fair amount" of unfavorable views towards China over recent years ![Trend showing increasing unfavorable views of China from 2013 to 2020](image2).  Furthermore, partisan divisions play a significant role in shaping these perceptions. Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to believe that China’s international clout will diminish as a consequence of the coronavirus outbreak [1].

In conclusion, the survey reveals that a significant portion of Americans believe China's influence in world affairs will decrease after the pandemic, though there are divided opinions influenced by political affiliation and existing negative sentiments.

Public sentiment regarding the nation's direction has fluctuated significantly over the years.  Examining trends from 1990 to 2019 reveals notable shifts in public satisfaction.  As depicted in ![a graph illustrating satisfaction trends from 1990 to 2019](image4), dissatisfaction generally outweighs satisfaction throughout this period, with dissatisfaction reaching 70% and satisfaction at 26% recently.  For an extended duration, exceeding a decade, public satisfaction has remained subdued, with no more than approximately a third of Americans expressing contentment with the country's trajectory [2]. Currently, this sentiment persists, with satisfaction levels standing at just 26%, a decrease from 33% in September [2].  The trend of public satisfaction over presidential terms, from G.H.W. Bush to Trump, further illustrates these variations ![a line chart showing satisfaction trends under different presidents from 1990 to 2019](image2).  Currently, public dissatisfaction with the nation's state is elevated, reaching its highest point in the past year and experiencing a 9 percentage point increase since September [4].  Overall, public satisfaction with the state of the nation has generally remained low with periods of fluctuation between 1990 and 2019.

European Venture Funds have demonstrated a notable positive shift in their performance trajectory. After their emergence in the 1990s, these funds navigated through a period of market turbulence following the capital surge of 1999-2001 [4]. However, starting around 2004, the underlying conditions for a flourishing venture capital landscape in Europe began to strengthen consistently [5].  Post-bubble vintage funds, specifically those initiated around 2004-2005, are showcasing considerably improved performance and have reached a turning point, indicating a positive momentum [1]. This positive development underscores the increasing potential of a maturing European venture capital sector [10]. ![The NAV of European venture funds shows a positive trend, especially for vintages after the market bubble.](image4)

The assembly of NAV for European venture funds by vintage year indicates an improving trend, particularly for vintages after the bubble burst.

Following Trump's election, there is a notable divergence in opinion on the future of race relations depending on vote choice [1]. ![Bar chart comparing expectations of race relations for different voter groups in 2016 and 2008.](image1)

Conversely, the overwhelming majority of Clinton voters, 84%, believe that race relations will deteriorate under Trump's presidency [9]. This starkly contrasts with the optimism expressed by Trump voters, with nearly half expecting better race relations [1]. Overall, voters are largely pessimistic, with 46% anticipating worse race relations and only 25% expecting improvement [8].  In conclusion, Trump voters are significantly more optimistic about race relations under Trump compared to Clinton voters who are largely pessimistic.

Since 2018, views toward China have become increasingly negative among Americans [7].  This shift is evident in the increased percentage of individuals expressing "cold" feelings towards China, rising from $46\%$ in 2018 to $67\%$ in 2021 [6].  Notably, those with "very cold" feelings, rating China below 25 on a feeling thermometer, have approximately doubled since 2018 [5]. ![This image shows the percentage of people with very cold, somewhat cold and total cold feelings towards China, broken down by different demographics and political affiliations.](image4).  While this negative trend is observed across both Republicans and Democrats, a partisan gap has emerged and widened [1].  A significantly larger proportion of Republicans now express "very cold" feelings towards China compared to Democrats; $62\%$ of Republicans reported such feelings, a 31-point increase since 2018, while for Democrats, the figure is $38\%$, a 21-point increase over the same period [1].  Examining the feeling thermometer ratings further illustrates this divergence, showing the changes in sentiment from 2018 to 2021 across different political affiliations ![This image compares feeling thermometer ratings for China in 2018 and 2021 across total population, Republicans/Lean Republicans, and Democrats/Lean Democrats.](image5).  In conclusion, negative perceptions of China have risen across the U.S. population from 2018 to 2021, with a more pronounced increase and a larger proportion of negative sentiment observed among Republicans compared to Democrats.

Reports from the Pew Research Center reveal that while women's representation in STEM fields has remained around half overall, significant variations exist across different STEM jobs [1].  For instance, fields like sales engineering and mechanical engineering show very low female representation, contrasting sharply with health-related occupations such as speech language pathology and dental hygiene, where women are the majority [1].  Experiences of gender disparity are notably more pronounced for women within STEM, particularly in computer-related roles and within workplaces dominated by men [2, 4].

Experiences of gender-related discrimination at work differ significantly across education levels for women in STEM. ![Women with postgraduate degrees in STEM are more likely to experience gender discrimination compared to those with less education.](image1)  Specifically, women in computer jobs report higher rates of discrimination compared to women in STEM overall, with a large percentage reporting pay inequities and feeling treated as incompetent due to their gender [6].  This perception of gender discrimination is also acknowledged as a major issue within the technology industry, more so by women in computer jobs than men [7].  A large disparity exists in the reported experiences of gender discrimination in computer occupations, with a significant majority of women reporting such experiences compared to a much smaller percentage of men [8]. ![A large gap exists between men and women in computer jobs concerning experiences of gender discrimination, sexual harassment, and other workplace inequities.](image5)

Workplace environments characterized by a male majority further amplify these disparities, as women in such settings are more likely to feel the need to consistently prove their competence to gain respect [9].  These challenges are not uniform, as women in STEM jobs, particularly those in computer roles, in majority-male workplaces, or with advanced degrees, are more likely to encounter workplace inequities [10].  Discrimination and sexual harassment are perceived as more common, and gender is often seen as a hindrance rather than an advantage to career advancement [10].  Workplace fairness perceptions also differ, showing that while a majority of employed individuals feel women are treated fairly in recruitment and hiring, this perception decreases when considering opportunities for promotion and advancement, especially within STEM fields. ![Perceptions of fairness in recruitment and promotion opportunities for women vary across STEM and non-STEM jobs, and between men and women.](image2)  In STEM workplaces with a higher proportion of men, women report even greater experiences of gender discrimination and related issues. ![Women in STEM jobs within male-dominated workplaces report higher instances of gender discrimination, sexual harassment, and feeling that their gender hinders their career success.](image3)

In STEM fields, computer-related majors, which often see women facing significant gender disparities and discrimination, do not consistently ensure equitable opportunities and experiences despite potentially high pay.

Men are more inclined than women to perceive negative behaviors on social media, noting a higher frequency of bullying and deception [2, 5]. Specifically, men are about twice as likely as women to report seeing deceptive behavior more often [5].  This aligns with findings that men slightly more often encounter mean or bullying content, while women are somewhat more likely to witness kindness and support [8].  ![Men and women differ in their perceptions of online behavior, with men more frequently observing negative actions like bullying and deception, while both genders equally perceive a mix of online behaviors.](image2) Despite these differences in negativity perception, both genders report seeing a mix of supportive and bullying behaviors online.

Beyond the perception of behavior, certain content types are frequently encountered by social media users.  Overly dramatic or exaggerated posts, and people making accusations without complete information are commonly seen [10].  In fact, around 58% of users frequently encounter overly dramatic posts, and 59% frequently see accusations made without all the facts [10].  These types of posts, alongside content that evokes anger, are frequently experienced on social media platforms [4]. ![Social media users frequently encounter content that is overly dramatic or exaggerated and content where people make accusations without knowing all the facts.](image5)

In conclusion, men are more likely to perceive negative online behaviors such as bullying and deception compared to women, and both genders frequently encounter content characterized by drama, exaggeration, and unfounded accusations on social media.

Perceptions regarding the news media's influence on presidential elections have shifted notably, with a growing sentiment that they wield excessive influence [9]. Currently, a majority, 57% of voters, believe news organizations have too much influence, marking the highest point since 2000 [7, 9].  This contrasts sharply with the period after George W. Bush's reelection, where only 45% of Bush voters felt similarly [2, 5].  Notably, even among Clinton voters, half perceive the press as overly influential, almost double the percentage of Obama voters in 2012 (29%) and considerably more than in 2008 (18%) [3, 10].  ![The percentage of people who think the press has too much influence on presidential elections is increasing from 1992 to 2016.](image1)  In conclusion, the view that news organizations have too much influence on presidential elections has become more widespread over time.

Initially, perceptions of Trump's economic policies were varied, but opinions have become more defined over time [3]. Generally, a majority acknowledges the necessity of American involvement in resolving global issues, with over half believing that global problems would worsen without the United States' engagement [10]. This sentiment is echoed across party lines, as comparable majorities of both Republicans and Democrats agree that the absence of U.S. efforts would lead to a deterioration of world issues [8]. However, divergences emerge when examining the specifics of this involvement, particularly among Democrats, where liberal factions express considerable skepticism about the efficacy of U.S. intervention, with a substantial portion suggesting that American efforts often exacerbate existing problems [2].

![Democrats are more inclined to believe that U.S. efforts to solve international problems often worsen situations, while Republicans and Independents generally hold the opposite view, thinking the world would be worse without U.S. involvement.](image5)

This partisan divide is further illustrated in attitudes toward military intervention, where Republicans are significantly more inclined to support sending U.S. ground troops to regions like Iraq and Syria, while Democrats largely oppose such actions [5].  Moreover, perceptions of global threats, such as Islamic extremism, reveal partisan variations, although concern around such threats is generally high across all affiliations [1].

![The perceived threat of Islamic extremism, both globally and within the U.S., shows a partisan trend over time, with Republicans generally expressing higher levels of concern compared to Democrats and Independents.](image1)

In conclusion, while there's a general consensus on the necessity of U.S. involvement in global affairs, significant partisan differences exist regarding the effectiveness and approach of this involvement.

Women employed in computer jobs are considerably more inclined than men in similar roles to perceive gender discrimination as a significant issue within the technology sector [1].  This disparity in perception is grounded in the reality that women in computer professions are substantially more prone to encountering workplace discrimination compared to their male colleagues [2].  In fact, a striking 74% of women in computer jobs report having faced gender-based discrimination, contrasting sharply with only 16% of men in the same field [5, 8].

![Women in computer jobs report significantly higher rates of gender-related discrimination in various forms compared to men in the same field, including general discrimination, sexual harassment, feeling the need to prove themselves, and perceptions of fairness in hiring and promotion](image2)

This difference extends beyond general discrimination to encompass various specific experiences, such as perceptions of fairness in career advancement; a significant gap exists in the belief that women are treated equitably in opportunities for promotion and advancement, with only 43% of women in computer jobs agreeing, compared to a much higher 77% of men [7, 10].  This highlights a considerable divergence in lived experiences and perceptions of gender-related workplace dynamics within computer professions.

In conclusion, women in computer jobs experience gender-related discrimination at a significantly higher rate than men in the same field.

Many older adults face specific physical or health issues that present obstacles to adopting and utilizing new technologies [6, 8].  A significant portion of seniors report conditions that directly impact their ability to engage with digital devices. For instance,  23% of older adults indicate they have a physical condition that makes reading difficult, while 29% report disabilities or chronic diseases that limit their participation in daily activities, both of which can hinder technology use ![Percentage of adults aged 65+ reporting physical conditions impacting their activities and reading](image1).  These physical challenges contribute to a noticeable gap in technology adoption. Seniors facing such conditions are less likely to be online (49% vs. 66%), have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%), or own cell phones (69% vs. 82%) compared to their healthier counterparts [3, 9].  Interestingly, the difference in technology adoption is less pronounced for devices like tablets and e-readers [10].  Looking at smartphone and cell phone ownership across different age groups within seniors further illustrates this point, with adoption rates decreasing notably in older age brackets, potentially reflecting increased physical limitations with age ![Cell phone and smartphone ownership among adults aged 65+ by age group](image2).  Physical health conditions significantly reduce technology use among older adults compared to those without such challenges.

Rock music and Pop music exhibit contrasting patterns in their streaming consumption, reflecting different market dynamics. Rock music is notably driven by its catalog [6]. This is evident in the composition of its total music activity, where streams constitute a significant 82% share ![Streams are a substantial component of Rock music consumption.](image1).  In contrast, Pop music, primarily fueled by current releases [6], sees a smaller proportion of its overall activity derived from streams ![Streams contribute less to Pop music consumption compared to Rock.](image1). This disparity indicates that Rock music's consumption is heavily reliant on its extensive back catalog, whereas Pop music thrives on the popularity of contemporary hits.  The dominance of Rock in album sales and Pop's strength in song sales [9] further highlight this distinction, suggesting catalog music's enduring appeal in albums and current music's prominence in song sales and streams.  Therefore, the market dynamics of Rock are shaped by its rich historical catalog, while Pop's market is propelled by the continuous demand for new and trending songs. The catalog share of streams is higher for Rock compared to Pop, indicating Rock's market is sustained by older music while Pop's market is driven by current hits.

Many Americans attribute the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak to a multitude of factors, with a significant portion pointing to the inadequacy of timely testing. This view is visually supported by survey data, highlighting that 49% of respondents identify this as a major reason ![Survey results showing 49% of people consider not enough timely testing as a major reason for the continued COVID-19 outbreak](image2). Americans identify several key factors contributing to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with the most prominent concern being the lack of adherence to public health guidelines.  A significant majority, specifically three-quarters of Americans, point to "not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines" as a major factor in the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak [2]. This issue surpasses all other reasons explored in a recent survey, highlighting its perceived importance among the public [2].  This is further visually represented in survey results, clearly indicating that 75% of respondents consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing a major reason for the prolonged outbreak ![75% of total respondents cited not enough social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason](image1). Even across different political affiliations, insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing remains a top concern; it is identified as a major reason by 57% of Republicans and a much larger 90% of Democrats [7].  The survey data illustrates this partisan divide and overall consensus regarding the impact of insufficient adherence to guidelines on the outbreak's continuation ![Breakdown of responses by political affiliation regarding reasons for outbreak continuation](image4).  Therefore, the most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is the insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines.

Specifically, the proportion of Americans viewing cyber attacks from China as a very serious problem increased by 7 percentage points [10], and similarly, concern over China's human rights policies also rose by 7 percentage points [9].

Americans with Hispanic ancestry display varying levels of self-identification as Hispanic or Non-Hispanic, which is significantly influenced by their proximity to their immigrant roots [9].  This is visually represented, demonstrating a clear trend across generations. ![The graph illustrates that among U.S. adults with Hispanic ancestry, the smallest percentage of Non-Hispanic self-identification is observed in the foreign-born generation, with a value of 3%.](image5).  The smallest bar in the graph represents 3%.

Childhood experiences with Hispanic cultural celebrations tend to lessen across immigrant generations [5, 9].  As shown in the data, the frequency of "often" attending these celebrations among self-identified Hispanics is highest for the foreign-born, followed by the second generation, and lowest for the third or higher generations, as illustrated in the graph ![Frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations across generations](image4).  Specifically, a majority ($59\%$) of immigrant self-identified Hispanics recall frequent childhood attendance [2]. This percentage reduces to about half ($49\%$) for second-generation Hispanics and further to a smaller proportion ($35\%$) for those in the third or higher generations [7].  Conversely, only a small percentage ($9\%$) of Americans with Hispanic ancestry who do not identify as Hispanic report frequent attendance, with most ($60\%$) reporting it never occurred [8].  This generational decline in participation in cultural celebrations mirrors a broader trend of Hispanic identity evolving over generations [9, 6].  In conclusion, the frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases with each subsequent immigrant generation.

The presence of women in STEM careers shows significant variation depending on the level of education attained [2, 5].  We can see that among all employed individuals, women make up 41% of the workforce ![Women's representation in STEM jobs across different education levels, compared to overall employed women](image3). However, when focusing specifically on STEM roles, the percentage of women shifts across different education levels.  For example, in STEM jobs held by those with some college education, women constitute 55%, which is actually higher than their overall representation in the employed population ![Women's representation in STEM jobs across different education levels, compared to overall employed women](image3). In contrast, as education levels rise, women's representation in STEM tends to decrease; for STEM professionals holding professional or doctoral degrees, only 41% are women [9, image3]. This indicates that the proportion of women in STEM jobs is not uniform across educational backgrounds and does not directly mirror their representation in the overall workforce. In conclusion, women's representation in STEM jobs fluctuates with education level and is not consistently proportional to their overall employment representation.

Representation of women within STEM fields is not uniform; it differs significantly across various job categories [2].  While women constitute half of the STEM workforce overall [3, 4], this broad statistic obscures the considerable disparities present among specific STEM job clusters [4]. For instance, in healthcare professions, women are markedly overrepresented, making up a large majority of practitioners and technicians [1, 3].  ![Women dominate health-related jobs but are significantly underrepresented in engineering and computer jobs](image3). Conversely, fields like computer science and engineering exhibit a pronounced underrepresentation of women [1, 4]. In fact, engineering occupations have the lowest proportion of women, at just 14% [8].  Even within computer occupations, despite being a high-growth area in STEM, women's representation has unfortunately declined from 32% in 1990 to 25% currently [6]. This uneven distribution highlights that while STEM as a whole might appear gender-balanced, the reality within individual job clusters reveals a more nuanced picture of female representation [9]. The representation of women in STEM job clusters varies substantially.

Overall, experiences of discrimination and perceptions of workplace fairness in STEM are markedly different for black employees compared to white employees.

In summary, large multimodal models generally exhibit a relatively better performance in the 'Human & Social Science' category when compared to their overall performance across all categories.

Pre-training of word embeddings has a notable positive impact on translation quality, particularly when evaluated using BLEU scores.  For language pairs involving low-resource languages, pre-training can lead to substantial improvements, as seen in the case of translations from Galician to English where gains of up to 11 BLEU points are observed [1]. This is especially beneficial for bootstrapping models that are on the verge of producing reasonable translations [1]. Qualitative analysis further reveals that pre-training aids in capturing rarer vocabulary and generating grammatically superior sentences, successfully translating names and multi-word phrases that might otherwise be missed in low-resource scenarios [2].

This improvement is not limited to low-resource languages; pre-training generally enhances translation accuracy across the vocabulary, especially for words that appear infrequently in the training data [8].  As depicted in ![Pre-training improves BLEU score across different language pairs, with varying degrees of improvement.](image3), comparing standard and pre-trained models across several language pairs (Es-PT, FR-PT, It-PT, Ru-PT, HE-PT) demonstrates a consistent increase in BLEU scores when pre-training is employed.  The extent of the gain is often related to the initial performance of the system; systems with lower baseline BLEU scores tend to experience larger improvements from pre-training [4, 9].  For example, language pairs like Russian-Portuguese (Ru-PT) and Hebrew-Portuguese (HE-PT), which initially have lower BLEU scores, show more significant gains compared to pairs with higher starting scores like Spanish-Portuguese (Es-PT) or French-Portuguese (FR-PT) [9, image3].  Moreover, the similarity between languages in a pair also plays a role, with more similar pairs sometimes showing greater gains from pre-training [10].  However, it's crucial to note that a moderately effective baseline system is often necessary for pre-training to exert its beneficial effects [4].  The trend of BLEU score improvement with pre-training is consistently observed across different language pairs, reinforcing its value in neural machine translation [6, image4].

Pre-training enhances BLEU scores across various language pairs, with the magnitude of improvement often depending on factors like resource availability and baseline translation quality.

Human evaluations involved multiple annotators to ensure the reliability of the assessments [4].  When judging the quality and relevance of model responses, several aspects were considered, including elements like image and language quality, relevance to the prompt, task fulfillment, and the presence of objectionable content as depicted in ![evaluation metrics](image1). To understand the contribution of source text in COMET models, researchers trained two versions of the DA RR Ranker model, contrasting one using only the reference translation against another utilizing both reference and source texts [9]. The results, shown in the table, reveal the impact of incorporating source information.

| Metric                     | en-cs | en-de | en-fi | en-tr | cs-en | de-en | fi-en | tr-en |
| :------------------------- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| COMET-RANK (ref. only)     | 0.660 | 0.764 | 0.630 | 0.539 | 0.249 | 0.390 | 0.159 | 0.128 |
| COMET-RANK                 | 0.711 | 0.799 | 0.671 | 0.563 | 0.356 | 0.542 | 0.278 | 0.260 |
| Δr                         | 0.051 | 0.035 | 0.041 | 0.024 | 0.107 | 0.155 | 0.119 | 0.132 |

![Table comparing COMET-RANK performance with and without reference on different language pairs](image2)

As seen in the table, for language pairs where English is the source, such as en-cs, en-de, en-fi, and en-tr, the inclusion of both source and reference texts in the COMET-RANK metric (compared to using reference only) leads to an increase in performance, indicated by the positive Δr values [Image2].  The extent of this improvement varies across different language pairs, from a Δr of 0.024 for en-tr to 0.051 for en-cs [Image2]. This suggests that while reference translations are fundamental, the incorporation of source text further refines the metric's accuracy, though the degree of this refinement is not uniform across all language pairs involving English.

In conclusion, including reference translations is crucial for COMET-RANK, and adding source text generally enhances its performance for language pairs involving English, with the magnitude of improvement varying across different language pairs.

There are three primary methods for refining language models using feedback: training-time correction, generation-time correction, and post-hoc correction [3]. Training-time correction occurs during the model's learning phase, often employing human feedback, reward models, or automated feedback to optimize model parameters [4, 7]. Generation-time correction, conversely, uses automated feedback to guide the model towards error correction as it produces outputs [6]. Strategies here include Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding, as illustrated in ![two typical strategies of generation-time correction are Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding](image3). Post-hoc correction, however, refines model outputs after they are fully generated, without altering the model's parameters, and this can incorporate diverse feedback mechanisms, including self-correction, external feedback, and multi-agent debate [1, 8].  A wide array of post-hoc correction techniques are detailed, spanning from Self-Refine and Reflexion to methods incorporating external tools and knowledge, as shown in  ![Post-hoc correction methods including Self-Refine, Clinical SV, Reflexion, IterRefinement, Auto-Post-Editing, RCI, SelFee, SelfCheckGPT, LLM Self Defense, Re, CodeRL, FLIRT, REFINER, RLAF, Yan et al., Baldur, CRITIC, FacTool, MAF, RARR, LLM-Augmenter, Self-Checker, REFEED, Olausson et al., Self-Edit, Self-Debug, Self-Evolve, Logic-LM, Self-Critique, ALGO, Charalambous et al., Self-Correction, Multiagent Debate, LM vs LM, ICL-AIF, PRD, MADRA, and ReConcile](image1).  Post-hoc correction appears to be the most represented strategy in this survey based on the number of listed methods.

The single-task model, as depicted in Figure 1a, utilizes a sequence-to-sequence architecture with attention, comprising an encoder, an attention mechanism, and a decoder [5].  ![Figure 1a illustrates a single-task model with one encoder, one attention, and one decoder.](image4) In contrast, the multitask model, shown in Figure 1b, employs a shared encoder for multiple tasks but distinguishes itself by using separate attention mechanisms and decoders for each task [2]. ![Figure 1b demonstrates a multitask model with a shared encoder but separate attentions and decoders for each task.](image4)  Each decoder in the multitask model independently attends to the encoder states, unlike in the single-task model where there is only one attention mechanism linking the encoder and decoder. The key difference lies in the presence of multiple, independent attention mechanisms in the multitask model compared to the single attention mechanism in the single-task model, allowing each task to focus on different aspects of the encoded input.  Therefore, the multitask model in Figure 1b differs from the single-task model in Figure 1a by having separate attention mechanisms for each decoder, while the single-task model has only one.

The RAR pipeline, designed to enhance the perception capabilities of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), especially in scenarios requiring fine-grained recognition, incorporates several key components working in concert [2, 9]. At its core is a **multimodal retriever**, which is crucial for efficiently accessing and utilizing a vast amount of information external to the MLLM's immediate context [8]. This retriever functions by creating multimodal embeddings for both images and text, effectively building a searchable memory bank of categories [1, 8].

![The multimodal retriever creates embeddings and uses them for retrieval.](image3)

This retrieval process is optimized for speed using an index system based on the HNSW algorithm, which significantly reduces the dimensionality of embeddings to accelerate the search for relevant information within the memory [7].  Following retrieval, the top-k most similar category labels are then passed to the MLLMs along with the input image embedding [1, 4]. To guide the MLLMs in leveraging this retrieved information, a **ranking prompt** is employed to merge the input image with the retrieved category information, directing the MLLM to rank these categories based on similarity [5].

![An example of a ranking prompt showing how retrieved categories are sorted and presented to the MLLM.](image4)

For object detection tasks, the RAR pipeline includes **pre-processing steps** like cropping and blurring to focus the MLLM's attention on the objects of interest within an image, particularly when objects are small or not centrally located [3].

![Pre-processing steps for object detection include cropping and blurring to highlight relevant objects.](image5)

Ultimately, the RAR pipeline uses a multimodal retriever to access external knowledge, and then employs MLLMs to rank the retrieved categories, thereby refining the prediction process for enhanced accuracy in perception tasks [4, 10]. In summary, the main components of the RAR pipeline are the multimodal retriever, the memory for storing embeddings, the ranking process using MLLMs, prompts to guide ranking, and pre-processing steps for object detection, all working together to improve the accuracy and efficiency of visual recognition tasks.

The process of causal inference is structured around a series of methodical steps, beginning with initial preparations and culminating in the final evaluation.  These steps are crucial for dissecting and understanding causal relationships within complex scenarios [1].  The initial phase involves four key preparation steps that lay the groundwork for formal causal reasoning.

![The preparation phase consists of extracting the causal graph, determining the query type, formalizing the query, and gathering relevant data.](image5)

Following these preparatory stages, the process transitions into the formal solution phase, which is composed of two critical steps.  These steps involve deducing the estimand using causal inference techniques and subsequently evaluating it to derive the answer [1].

![The solution phase involves deducing the estimand using causal inference and calculating the estimand to get the final answer.](image5)

In total, the authors divided causal inference into six key steps.

For the FewNERD dataset, LLM reranking demonstrates a nuanced impact on micro-F1 performance depending on the confidence level of the initial predictions.  Examining the performance trends, we observe that LLM reranking enhances results specifically for samples initially categorized as hard, which are represented by lower confidence scores. Conversely, for samples with higher confidence scores, indicative of easier examples, the application of LLM reranking tends to diminish the micro-F1 performance. This pattern is visualized in the performance plot where blue lines, representing LLM-based reranking, show an upward trend in micro-F1 for the left side of the graph (hard samples) and a downward trend or stagnation on the right side (easy samples) compared to the red lines that represent performance without reranking. ![The micro-F1 performance for FewNERD dataset increases in hard samples and decreases in easy samples when applying LLM reranking](image5). This observation is consistent with findings that LLMs are more proficient at handling difficult samples but may underperform on easier ones compared to SLMs [9].  Therefore, LLM reranking in the FewNERD dataset improves micro-F1 performance for hard samples but can degrade it for easy samples.

The number of iterations significantly influences the F1 score in both entity and relation extraction tasks. For entity extraction, optimal performance is achieved at the second iteration of coreference propagation [1].  Similarly, relation extraction also peaks in performance at the second iteration of relation propagation [8]. This iterative process allows for the refinement of span representations by propagating confidences through dynamically constructed span graphs [9]. The impact of the number of iterations on F1 score can be visualized, showing that both entity and relation extraction F1 scores achieve their best results at two iterations. ![The figure illustrates that both entity and relation extraction F1 scores are affected by the number of iterations, peaking at two iterations for both.](image1)  The dynamic span graph framework uses these iterations to propagate global contextual information, leading to improved performance [7].

In summary, the F1 score in both entity and relation extraction tasks is optimized when the model is run for two iterations.

Distant supervision methods utilize various data sources, and the precision of these sources is an important factor in their effectiveness. As noted in the study, researchers experimented with both novel distant supervision methods and traditional Knowledge Base (KB) supervision [6]. To evaluate the reliability of each source, they annotated 100 examples from each to estimate their precision [6].  The analysis revealed that head word supervision achieves a precision rate of approximately 80.4%, which is comparable to the precision of types derived from entity linking [8].  Entity linking, including definitions, shows a precision of 77.7%, while entity linking alone has a precision of 77.6%, as shown in ![Precision rates for different supervision sources are presented.](image3). These figures highlight the generally high accuracy of distant supervision signals, although there are error sources such as parser errors and idiomatic expressions that can affect precision [8]. In conclusion, head words and entity linking exhibit comparable and relatively high precision rates for distant supervision.

The model incorporating supervised learning, imitation learning with 1000 episodes, and reinforcement learning (SL + IL 1000 + RL) demonstrates a superior task success rate compared to other models as interactive learning sessions progress [1].  This is visually depicted in the learning curves, where the blue line representing SL + IL 1000 + RL consistently achieves the highest task success rate over time. ![The SL + IL 1000 + RL model achieves the highest task success rate over time compared to other models](image2).  In contrast, the supervised learning baseline (SL Baseline) shows the lowest performance, indicating challenges in adapting to new dialogue states during user interactions [6].  Applying reinforcement learning (RL) on top of supervised learning (SL + RL) improves the success rate, but not as effectively as when imitation learning is included [1].  The enhanced performance of SL + IL 1000 + RL suggests that imitation learning effectively adapts the supervised training model to the dialogue state distribution during user interactions, and subsequent RL optimization further refines the policy [1].  The task success rate of the SL + IL 1000 + RL model is consistently higher than other models over interactive learning sessions.
