The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from others through its expansive breadth and considerable depth, aiming to offer a more rigorous evaluation of large multimodal models.  In terms of breadth, MMMU covers an extensive range of disciplines, subjects, and subfields, spanning six disciplines including Art, Business, Health & Medicine, Science, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering, encompassing over 183 subfields [2]. This broad coverage ensures the benchmark is not limited to common sense knowledge but delves into college-level expertise across 30 diverse subjects [5, 10].  This is visually summarized, showcasing the comprehensive disciplines covered by MMMU ![MMMU covers diverse disciplines like Engineering, Art & Design, Business, Science, Humanities & Social Science, and Medicine.](image1). The benchmark also incorporates a wide array of 30 image formats, moving beyond typical image types to include diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, medical images, and more [5].  This breadth is further substantiated by the sheer number of questions and image types included in the benchmark, as shown in the statistics ![MMMU benchmark statistics including total questions, disciplines, subjects, subfields and image types.](image2).

Regarding depth, MMMU moves beyond benchmarks focused on basic perception by demanding expert-level reasoning and subject-specific knowledge [4, 6].  It requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge, contrasting with previous benchmarks that often rely on commonsense or simple reasoning [5]. Many questions necessitate recalling domain-specific knowledge and performing step-by-step reasoning to arrive at solutions [10]. This depth aspect is visualized in comparison to other benchmarks, positioning MMMU as requiring deeper reasoning and knowledge ![MMMU benchmark's depth and breadth compared to other benchmarks, showing MMMU is higher in both axes.](image3).

The implications of MMMU's breadth and depth for evaluating LMMs are significant. It is designed to measure essential skills like perception, knowledge, and reasoning in LMMs, providing a holistic evaluation [1, 4]. By presenting challenges that require both expert-level visual perception and deliberate reasoning, MMMU effectively tests the advanced multimodal analysis and domain-specific knowledge integration capabilities of these models [6]. While benchmarks previously focused on basic perception, MMMU pushes models to demonstrate expert-level skills across diverse and complex problems [4, 10].  The benchmark underscores the ongoing progress and remaining challenges in multimodal understanding, indicating that while models like GPT-4V show promise, there is still substantial room for improvement, especially in domains requiring complex visual inputs and heavy reasoning [8].

In conclusion, the MMMU benchmark, with its extensive breadth across disciplines and depth in expert-level reasoning, offers a more challenging and comprehensive evaluation of large multimodal models compared to existing benchmarks, highlighting areas for further advancement in LMM capabilities.

DYGIE employs a token representation layer that utilizes a bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) over the input tokens [6]. This sentence-level BiLSTM processes the input tokens, which are created by concatenating character representations, GLoVe word embeddings, and ELMo embeddings, to generate output token representations by stacking the forward and backward LSTM hidden states [6].  ![Sentence-level BiLSTM is used for token representations in the DYGIE model](image1) The sentence-level BiLSTM in the DYGIE model serves to create token representations from the input tokens.

Based on experimental results on different datasets, DSC loss consistently outperforms other methods, achieving state-of-the-art performance [1, 7]. For instance, when comparing different loss functions on various datasets, DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 score [7].  Even on tasks like paraphrase identification, where accuracy is key, DSC shows competitive performance, although it is not specifically designed for accuracy-oriented tasks [6, 10]. The effectiveness of DSC loss is particularly evident in imbalanced datasets, where it significantly outperforms Dice Loss (DL) and Focal Loss (FL) [7].

![Table showing F1 scores for BERT with different losses and data settings, highlighting BERT+DSC achieving the highest F1 score.](image3)

In scenarios with varying data imbalances, DSC loss maintains robustness, consistently performing better than FL and DL [1, 7].  As illustrated in the experimental results, especially in the context of varying data compositions, DSC loss, when combined with BERT, yields the highest F1 score [image3]. Therefore, based on the provided experimental results, DSC loss is the data augmentation method that resulted in the highest F1-score for the BERT model.

The system architecture begins by processing user input in natural language [8]. To achieve this, a bidirectional LSTM, referred to as the utterance-level LSTM, is employed to encode the user's spoken or written words into a continuous vector representation [6].  This process is visualized in the system diagram, where the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder takes "User utterance" and outputs "User utterance encoding at turn k" ![The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder transforms user input into a continuous vector representation within the dialogue system](image1). This encoded user utterance, along with the encoding of the previous system action, then serves as input to the dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains the dialogue state [8]. The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder effectively transforms the raw natural language input into a format that the downstream components of the dialogue system can process [6].

The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder's function is to convert user natural language input into a continuous vector representation for further processing by the dialogue system.

The model predicts tokens by considering different mention types, including references to existing entities [4]. When rendering an entity, the model first picks a fact and its parent entity, then selects a relation to follow, ultimately choosing an entity to render [4].  This process is illustrated when the model needs to generate "Nintendo" after "published by" [4]. In such cases, depicted in  ![Illustration of entity and relation selection process](image3), the model chooses from existing entities, selects "Super Mario Land" as the parent entity, and then follows the "PUBLISHER" relation to arrive at "Nintendo" as the entity to render.  A concrete example from the annotation, as seen in ![Example annotation of KGLM process](image5), shows "Nintendo" being rendered as the entity associated with the "Publisher" relation in the context of "published by".  Therefore, when rendering in the context of 'published by', the model selects an entity by identifying a parent entity and following the 'Publisher' relation from its knowledge graph.

The iterative layer processing in the tree traversal method is implemented using a `for` loop that runs for each layer of the tree, as shown in Algorithm 1.  This loop structure ensures the algorithm proceeds from the root layer down to the specified depth, refining the search at each level. The traversal continues for a predefined number of layers, denoted as `tree.num_layers` in the pseudocode, which directly corresponds to step 5, generating sets $S_{1}, S_{2}, ..., S_{d}$ as it progresses through each layer.

```
for layer in range(tree.num_layers) do
    top_k < |]
    for node in Scurrent do
        score = dot_product(query, node)
        top_k.append((node, score) )
    end for
    Stayer < Sorted(top_k)[:k].nodes
    Scurrent = Stayer
end for
```

This loop from Algorithm 1 in the appendix corresponds to step 5 of the tree traversal method. ![Algorithm 1 outlines the loop structure for recursive layer processing.](image1)

Perplexity is used as a sanity check for retrieve and refine models, where improvement in perplexity suggests model enhancement [1]. However, perplexity may not always align with human judgment of generated sequences, especially in retrieval-based dialogue systems, as a retrieval pointing to a valid but different response can lead to poor perplexity scores [5]. Despite these limitations, various retrieval methods have been evaluated for their impact on perplexity when used with Seq2Seq models.  The results, as shown in ![Table showing perplexity values for different retrieval methods including None, Random label, Memory Network, True label’s neighbor and True label](image2), indicate that using the true label as a retrieval method yields the best perplexity score, significantly lower than other methods. While surprisingly, the choice of no retrieval, random labels, or Memory Network retriever shows little difference in perplexity [2], the true label and its neighbor notably improve it.  This evaluation is conducted using methods like Memory Network retrieval and comparing against scenarios with no retrieval or random retrievals [3].

The retrieval method that demonstrates the best performance in terms of perplexity when used with a Seq2Seq model is the true label.

The QACheck system architecture, as depicted, starts with a Claim Verifier to assess the sufficiency of existing information, followed by a Question Generator when more information is needed. Subsequently, a Question-Answering Model provides answers and evidence, and a Validator checks the usefulness of the generated question-answer pair [1].  ![The diagram illustrates the process flow in QACheck system modules, starting from Claim Verifier, going through Question Generator, Question Answering, and Validator, finally reaching Reasoner.](image3) This iterative process continues until the Claim Verifier determines sufficient context is available.  The system is composed of five modules including a claim verifier, question generator, question-answering module, QA validator and a reasoner [6]. The final module, termed the Reasoner, is then invoked to determine the veracity of the claim using the accumulated context and provide a final label [1].

The final step is Reasoner.

The MIMIC-IT dataset is designed to enhance vision-language models' (VLMs) capabilities in perception, reasoning, and planning, particularly for interactive tasks involving complex visual scenes [8]. This dataset incorporates egocentric views from scenarios like IEP and E4D to facilitate understanding and planning in indoor environments and to develop AR assistant functionalities [1]. The process of creating MIMIC-IT involves an automatic pipeline called Syphus, which is visualized in a structured manner ![Syphus is an automated pipeline used to generate MIMIC-IT dataset.](image5).  Within this pipeline, "Planning" is a key branch, addressing tasks like Indoor Event Planning (IEP) [6] and applications for first-person augmented reality (AR) headsets derived from Ego4D scenarios [10].  These planning tasks are exemplified by questions that require context-aware responses, such as suggesting recreational activities within a room (IEP) or determining the next steps in a real-life situation (E4D) ![Example questions related to IEP and E4D scenarios.](image1).

The task on the top of the planning branch is to enable virtual assistants to strategize and provide context-aware guidance in indoor event planning and augmented reality applications.

Even single-character attacks can severely degrade the performance of BERT models, dropping accuracy significantly [7]. For instance, a single character swap can reduce the accuracy of a BERT model from 90.3% to 64.1% [10]. However, employing word recognition models as a defense can effectively restore much of this lost accuracy [6, 9]. Different backoff strategies within these word recognition models offer varying levels of protection against such attacks.

The "Pass-through" variation of BERT demonstrates notable resilience against adversarial attacks.  ![The "Pass-through" BERT model shows the highest accuracy under 1-char and 2-char attacks compared to standard BERT and BERT+ATD.](image1) As shown in the table, under 1-char attacks, the accuracy of standard BERT drops to 60.0%, while the "Pass-through" variation maintains a higher accuracy of 84.5% [image1].  This trend continues with 2-char attacks, where standard BERT's accuracy plummets to 31.0%, but "Pass-through" sustains 81.5% accuracy [image1].  Compared to other defense mechanisms like Adversarial Training (ATD), "Pass-through" backoff shows superior performance in preserving accuracy under both 1-char and 2-char attacks [image1].

The effectiveness of the "Pass-through" backoff is further highlighted when compared across different attack types and model architectures. ![Pass-through and Neutral backoff strategies demonstrate superior performance in maintaining accuracy across various attack types for BERT models.](image3)  The table illustrates that "Pass-through" and "Neutral" backoff consistently achieve higher accuracy than other defenses like ATD, not only under 'all' attack settings but also specifically for swap, drop, and add attacks [image3]. These backoff methods leverage word recognition to correct errors introduced by adversarial attacks, thereby maintaining the model's performance [4].  While the "Neutral" backoff model can be effective, it may slightly hurt performance in no-attack scenarios by incorrectly modifying correctly spelled words [6].  Despite this minor drawback, both "Pass-through" and "Neutral" backoff strategies significantly enhance BERT's robustness against character-level adversarial attacks [6, 9].

In scenarios with 1-char and 2-char attacks, the Pass-through variation of the BERT model exhibits the best performance.

The DS-DST model employs a dual strategy to determine the matching between candidate values and the dialogue context [6]. It begins by utilizing BERT to encode both the dialogue context and domain-slot pairs, allowing for contextualized representations that are conditioned by domain-slot information [3].  For categorical slots, the model operates by selecting the most fitting values from predefined picklists, relying on the contextual representation to guide this selection [3]. In contrast, for non-categorical slots, it employs a two-way linear mapping to identify text spans directly within the dialogue context [3]. This approach is visually represented in ![The image illustrates how the model considers a candidate-value list and recent dialog context to predict spans.](image3), showcasing the model's focus on finding relevant spans in the context for value matching. Ultimately, DS-DST determines the matching by employing distinct methods tailored to categorical and non-categorical slots, leveraging contextual understanding derived from BERT.

Various DNA repair mechanisms are essential for maintaining the integrity of our genome, counteracting the constant mutations that arise from both internal cellular processes and external factors [1, 3]. These systems are critical because without them, the stability of our genetic information would be impossible to maintain [3].  Figure 11, as mentioned in the text, outlines several key nuclear DNA repair pathways [8].

One of the most frequent pathways is base excision repair (BER), which handles single-strand point mutations [5]. Another important mechanism is nucleotide excision repair (NER), known for its broad specificity in excising DNA lesions, including UV-induced damage [4].  Direct reversal repair offers a straightforward approach, directly fixing certain types of damage like pyrimidine dimers without needing to cut the DNA strand [9].

Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects mismatched base pairs that occur during DNA replication [6]. Recombination repair is crucial for dealing with double-strand breaks, the most severe type of DNA damage [10].  These diverse repair mechanisms, including transcription-coupled repair (TCR) in addition to the ones mentioned, work in concert to ensure genomic stability [8].

![This image shows various types of DNA damage and corresponding DNA repair mechanisms.](image3)

In conclusion, Figure 11 demonstrates base excision repair (BER), nucleotide excision repair (NER), direct reversal repair, mismatch repair, transcription-coupled repair (TCR), and recombination repair as the DNA repair mechanisms [8].

Large Language Models encounter challenges with logical inconsistencies, but techniques like post-processing are being explored to mitigate these issues [2]. Post-processing is a method that ensures the absence of logical conflicts in generated answers by automatically creating logically consistent candidates and selecting one as the final output [9].  This approach, while effective in eliminating logical inconsistency, might impact the overall quality of the generated content [6].  The impact of post-processing on Logical Inconsistency (LI) can be observed in the performance of models like Vicuna-13B-PT and Llama2-13B-PT across datasets such as MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank.

The table below illustrates the LI scores when post-processing is applied across different hops for various models on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.  ![Post-processing consistently results in 0% Logical Inconsistency across different hops for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.](image1) As shown, using post-processing results in a Logical Inconsistency (LI) of 0% across different hops for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank.

Similarly, another table details the LI scores with post-processing across different iterations. ![Post-processing consistently results in 0% Logical Inconsistency across different iterations for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.](image2)  Again, the results indicate that post-processing consistently achieves a 0% Logical Inconsistency for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank across different iterations.

In summary, post-processing effectively reduces Logical Inconsistency to 0% for both Vicuna-13B-PT and Llama2-13B-PT models across MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.

The LOGIC-LM model tackles logical reasoning problems by breaking them down into a structured three-stage process [2]. Initially, in the Problem Formulation stage, a Large Language Model (LLM) takes a natural language problem and converts it into a symbolic representation, identifying key elements and relationships [2, 1]. This is a crucial step where the LLM's strength in natural language understanding is utilized to precisely represent the problem in a structured format [2].  Following this, the Symbolic Reasoning stage employs a deterministic symbolic solver to perform logical inference on the symbolic problem formulation, ensuring faithful reasoning through established algorithms [1, 2].  Finally, the Result Interpretation stage involves translating the symbolic answer back into natural language, often using an LLM or rule-based interpreter, making the solution understandable in the original context [1, 2]. This entire process is visualized in ![LOGIC-LM follows a problem formulation and reasoning paradigm to solve problems](image4), showing how a natural language problem is transformed into a symbolic formulation, processed by a solver, and then interpreted back into a natural language answer. By integrating LLMs for translation and symbolic solvers for reasoning, LOGIC-LM effectively combines the strengths of both approaches to solve logical problems [2, 6].  The LOGIC-LM model solves problems by translating natural language into symbolic language, reasoning with a symbolic solver, and then interpreting the symbolic result back into natural language.

Compared to WIKI HOP, MED HOP exhibits distinct characteristics in terms of document and candidate statistics.  MED HOP samples tend to have a consistent number of candidates, with most samples having 9 candidates [9], whereas WIKI HOP samples have varied number of candidates, ranging from 2 to 79 [4].  The document sub-sampling process in MED HOP leads to a maximum of 64 documents per sample [7].  Looking at the specifics, WIKI HOP has a minimum of 2 candidates and a maximum of 79, with an average of 19.8 and a median of 14 candidates per sample, while MED HOP has a narrower range of 2 to 9 candidates, averaging 8.9 with a median of 9 [4].

![The number of candidates and documents are generally higher in WikiHop than MedHop, but MedHop has a higher maximum number of documents and tokens per document.](image4)

Regarding documents, WIKI HOP samples contain between 3 and 63 documents, with an average of approximately 13.7 and a median of 11 documents.  In contrast, MED HOP samples range from 5 to 64 documents, averaging around 836.4 with a median of 29 documents [4].  The number of query types is also different; WIKI HOP has 277 query types while MED HOP has only one, "interacts with" [1]. In summary, MED HOP datasets are characterized by a consistent number of candidates and a larger number of documents per sample compared to WIKI HOP.

The creation of the MLQA dataset involves a structured process initiated by pinpointing sentences across different languages on Wikipedia that share similar meanings [6].  These sentences are then used to extract relevant paragraphs from articles covering the same subject matter in each language [5]. This initial phase is visually depicted in the pipeline diagram ![The first step of the MLQA annotation pipeline is extracting parallel sentences.](image4).  Following this, crowd-workers are tasked with creating questions and identifying answer spans within the English paragraphs, ensuring the answer is located within the parallel source sentence [3]. Finally, professional translators translate these questions and annotate the corresponding answer spans in the target languages [9]. The first step in the MLQA annotation pipeline is the automatic extraction of paragraphs containing parallel sentences from multilingual articles.

The challenges in training models like Chameleon are multifaceted, particularly regarding stability during the training process [2].  It was observed that standard architectures like LLaMa exhibited complex divergences due to slow norm growth, especially when dealing with multiple modalities [3]. Addressing these stability issues required architectural innovations, such as query-key normalization and adjustments in layer norm placement [2].  Figure 6 illustrates training loss curves, where the impact of normalization strategies can be seen. ![Figure 6 shows training loss curves with and without norm reordering, highlighting the impact of normalization on stability.](image3)  Specifically, the subplot depicting training without norm reordering clearly demonstrates a loss spike, indicating instability.  This is further supported by findings that without QK-Norm, training can diverge after a certain percentage of an epoch [8].  Thus, only one subplot is related to obvious loss spikies.

Evaluating the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) is crucial to understand their capabilities and limitations [1]. The CAUSAL Chain-of-Thought (CAUSALCoT) approach has been developed to enhance the performance of GPT-4, a state-of-the-art LLM [7].  As shown in the comparative analysis, the causal reasoning task in CL ADDER is generally challenging for various models; however, CAUSALCoT notably improves performance, achieving a $70.40\%$ accuracy rate [6].

![CAUSALCoT significantly outperforms vanilla GPT-4 and other models across various metrics including overall accuracy and performance on different question rungs.](image1)

This improvement is substantial, outperforming vanilla GPT-4 by 8.37 points on CL ADDER [5, 6].  Interestingly, while original GPT-4 performs best on common sensical data and worse on nonsensical data, CAUSALCoT consistently enhances reasoning across all levels, showing a significant improvement in handling anti-common sensical data [3, 4].  The CAUSALCoT approach positively impacts GPT-4's performance across different evaluation metrics by enhancing its reasoning abilities, particularly on challenging and unseen data.

DYGIE has demonstrated state-of-the-art performance across a variety of datasets and tasks [6]. The removal of the R-GCN component significantly impacts the model's performance.  As evidenced, when R-GCN is removed in conjunction with GloVe embeddings, there is a notable decrease in performance, specifically an 8.0 point drop [3]. This highlights the crucial role of the R-GCN component in enhancing model accuracy beyond systems like Coref-GRU, even without context access, by leveraging relationships between mentions [3].  The table illustrates the performance difference between models with and without R-GCN, showing a clear decline when R-GCN is absent, especially when comparing "GloVe with R-GCN" and "GloVe w/o R-GCN" in both masked and unmasked settings. ![Table showing model performance with different settings including GloVe w/o R-GCN and No R-GCN](image3).  Furthermore, the model's reliance on multi-hop inference for tasks is emphasized, as models lacking R-GCN perform considerably worse than those with it, demonstrating that R-GCN is vital for capturing dependencies beyond local contexts [2]. Removing R-GCN deprives the model of inductive biases essential for multi-hop reasoning, leading to a drop in its effectiveness [6].  Therefore, removing R-GCN negatively affects the model's performance in both unmasked and masked settings.

The Bidirectional Attention Flow model (BiDAF) and FastQA are two extractive question answering models that have been evaluated on the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets [8].  Across both datasets, BiDAF generally demonstrates stronger performance compared to FastQA [3]. This might be attributed to BiDAF's architecture, which employs iterative latent interactions, potentially crucial for tasks where information is spread across multiple documents [3, 9].  The performance metrics in standard settings for both models on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets can be visualized in ![Performance comparison of BiDAF and FastQA models in standard and gold chain settings on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets](image2).

Both models are able to maintain or even enhance their performance when answers are masked, suggesting they effectively utilize the textual context surrounding candidate answers [4]. However, there are differences in how they behave between WIKIHOP and MEDHOP. In MEDHOP, where drug mentions are normalized, performance decreases with masking, whereas in WIKIHOP's open-domain setting, masking actually aids the models in selecting candidate spans [4].  Despite their relative strengths compared to baseline models, both BiDAF and FastQA still have significant room for improvement to reach human-level performance [4, 5].  The table in ![Performance of different models including BiDAF and FastQA on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets](image4) provides a detailed comparison of their test set performance against other models.

In summary, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA on both WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets, although both models still lag behind human performance and show limitations in selecting relevant information from large document sets.

ProgramFC (N=5) demonstrates a notable performance on the HOVER (4-hop) dataset, achieving a score of 66.75 in the gold setting and 57.74 in the open setting, as detailed in the provided performance metrics ![Performance metrics of ProgramFC and baseline models on the HOVER and FEVEROUS-S datasets](image2). When compared to other models on the same dataset, ProgramFC (N=5) generally outperforms baselines in both gold and open settings for 4-hop claims ![Performance metrics of ProgramFC and baseline models on the HOVER and FEVEROUS-S datasets](image2).  Notably, DeBERTaV3-NLI, another strong baseline, achieves a score of 60.49 in the gold setting and 56.00 in the open setting on HOVER (4-hop), indicating ProgramFC's superior performance, especially considering that ProgramFC becomes increasingly effective as the reasoning depth increases [10]. This outperformance suggests that decomposing complex claims into simpler steps facilitates more accurate reasoning compared to one-step prediction methods, especially for complex claims [2]. The HOVER dataset is inherently challenging, with most models achieving scores only slightly above random guessing, which underscores the significance of ProgramFC's results in this difficult context [9]. ProgramFC (N=5) exhibits a strong performance edge over other models on the HOVER (4-hop) dataset in both Gold and Open settings.

The filter-then-rerank framework is designed to integrate both SLMs and LLMs, leveraging the strengths of each [9]. Supervised SLMs act as filters to make initial predictions, and for samples deemed difficult, LLMs rerank the top predictions from SLMs [7].  Looking at the performance on the TACREV dataset with a 50-shot configuration, the filter-then-rerank method achieves a score of 70.8(2.3) when using an SLM reranker and 70.8(1.6) with an LLM reranker, as detailed in the performance comparison table ![Performance of filter-then-rerank method on TACREV dataset](image3).  Therefore, the filter-then-rerank method without ensemble reaches approximately 70.8 F1 score on the 50-shot TACREV dataset.

The survey compiles existing research in Table 1 and Table 2, building upon a defined taxonomy [1]. This compilation includes research categorized by correction strategies, detailing aspects like feedback source and learning methods [4]. The focus of this survey is primarily on automated correction strategies in large language models, emphasizing recent work from 2022 and 2023, while also acknowledging earlier roots in NLP [6].  The methodologies of correction are categorized into training-time, generation-time, and post-hoc correction depending on when the correction process occurs [8]. Training-time correction, as illustrated, uses various feedback forms like human input, reward models, and automated feedback to refine models during training ![Training time correction uses different forms of feedback to optimize models](image1). Generation-time correction employs strategies like generate-then-rank and feedback-guided decoding to refine outputs during generation ![Generation-time correction strategies include generate-then-rank and feedback-guided decoding](image2). The survey aims to offer a comprehensive resource in the rapidly evolving field of self-correcting language models [9].

The model architecture incorporates both word-level and character-level embeddings to effectively capture different aspects of linguistic information. As described in the text, a hierarchical Conditional Random Field (CRF) model is structured with distinct components: a character-level neural network, and a word-level neural network [1].  This character-level network, whether an RNN or CNN, is specifically designed to capture subword information, which includes morphological variations and capitalization patterns [1]. The word-level network then processes word representations to produce context-sensitive hidden representations [1].  The architecture, such as the one detailed by Lample et al., concatenates character and word representations to create a comprehensive input for the word-level Bi-LSTM, which models contextual dependencies within sentences [5].  The use of character-level features becomes particularly relevant when considering cross-lingual applications, as their absence can lead to reduced tagging accuracy because surface forms are not available when only using bilingual word embeddings [7]. This integrated approach allows the model to leverage both the broader context provided by word embeddings and the finer details captured by character embeddings.  ![The model uses both embeddings to capture subword information like morphology and capitalization, which might be missed by word-level embeddings alone, and also surface form information that is not available in bilingual word embeddings.](image5)

The model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings to capture a wider range of linguistic features, enhancing its accuracy and robustness.

In object detection datasets, a crucial pre-processing step is applied to refine images before they are analyzed for zero-shot recognition. This methodology includes cropping image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates and subsequently blurring the areas surrounding these regions [4].  This pre-processing approach, as depicted in ![Pre-processing involves cropping bounding boxes and blurring surrounding areas to focus on objects](image2), is designed to direct the Multimodal Large Language Models' (MLLMs) focus specifically toward the objects of interest within the image [4]. By employing blurring on non-target areas and cropping to the object within bounding boxes, the pre-processing step effectively guides the MLLMs to concentrate on the relevant objects, thereby enhancing object identification in zero-shot recognition systems [4]. Pre-processing contributes to the zero-shot recognition system by focusing the MLLM's attention on the object of interest.

The open-domain setting poses a significant challenge for question-answering models, particularly for single-hop models, as it requires effective information retrieval alongside reading comprehension [8, 10].  This difficulty is highlighted by the performance of various models in open-domain evaluations, where scores are generally lower compared to settings with pre-selected paragraphs.  For instance, single-paragraph BERT, a model effective in distractor settings [6], sees a considerable drop in F1 score in open-domain scenarios [8].

![Table comparing F1 scores of different models in distractor and open settings, showing Cognitive Graph achieving the highest Open F1 score.](image4)

Among the models evaluated, Cognitive Graph achieves the highest Open F1 score of 48.87, as shown in the performance comparison table [image4].  This score, while representing the best performance among the listed models in the open-domain setting, is still lower than the scores achieved in distractor settings, for example, DecompRC reaches 69.63 F1 in the distractor setting [image4, 6]. This difference underscores the added complexity of open-domain QA, where retrieving relevant evidence is crucial but often challenging due to limitations in methods like TF-IDF, especially for multi-hop questions [10].

![Table showing F1 scores for single-paragraph BERT in different settings, highlighting the performance in open-domain with varying paragraph inputs.](image5)

The significance of Cognitive Graph achieving the highest Open F1 score lies in demonstrating a relatively better capability in handling the complexities of open-domain question answering compared to other models; however, it also underscores the ongoing challenges and the need for advancements in both retrieval and reasoning components for open-domain QA systems [8, 10].

Cognitive Graph achieves the highest Open F1 score, demonstrating superior performance in challenging open-domain question answering, although the overall open-domain performance remains a significant challenge compared to distractor settings.

The SnapNTell dataset is explicitly designed to address the limitations of existing VQA datasets by focusing on entity-centric knowledge and detailed responses [4, 10].  This dataset distinguishes itself by encompassing a wide array of categorized entities, each paired with representative images, ensuring that the question-answer pairs necessitate knowledge-intensive responses [5, 7].  The quality of these pairs is rigorously maintained, achieving a 98% accuracy rate and a substantial agreement among evaluators [2].  Compared to datasets like ViQuAE, SnapNTell significantly expands the scope of entities and question types, moving beyond simple queries to those requiring deeper understanding and specific entity knowledge [3, 10].

The quality of different models was assessed through human evaluations on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Judges were asked to rate system turns in dialogues on a scale from 1 (frustrating) to 5 (optimal) [2]. The evaluation involved comparing three models: SL, SL model with imitation learning (IL), and SL and IL followed by reinforcement learning (RL) [2].  The results, shown in ![Table of human evaluation scores, comparing SL, SL+IL, and SL+IL+RL models](image3), indicate that incorporating interactive learning, particularly with imitation and reinforcement learning, enhances the model's quality as perceived by human judges [2, 7].  Specifically, the model with SL, IL, and RL achieved the highest mean score of 4.603, outperforming the SL+IL model (4.378) and the baseline SL model (3.987) based on human ratings [image3]. Thus, models incorporating interactive learning methods achieve higher scores in human evaluations compared to the baseline supervised learning model.

The performance of the discriminator is evaluated on a negative set not used during adversarial training, and its accuracy reflects its performance [3]. Initially, generated samples may increase accuracy, but as training progresses, the accuracy decreases, indicating the discriminator weakening as the generator learns to produce more accurate true positive samples [3]. The study of diachronic semantic shifts has significantly advanced, especially after 2011, due to the increasing availability of large datasets and progress in computational semantics [2]. Word embeddings became a prevalent method for representing data in this field [2].  The release of the Google Books Ngrams corpus was a crucial event, fostering the development of 'culturomics' and enabling the examination of word usage variations across different eras [9].  Research in **2017** explored temporal word analogies, further refining the methods for identifying lexical replacement using diachronic word embeddings. ![The year temporal word analogies were explored](image1). In **2016**, investigations highlighted the effectiveness of SGNS models in analyzing semantic shifts, establishing their advantage over other distributional models [7]. ![The year SGNS model superiority was shown](image2).  The application of these computational methods was also validated across diverse datasets like Amazon Movie Reviews and Twitter, demonstrating their robustness in detecting semantic shifts even within shorter timeframes [10].

In summary, the key milestones in tracing diachronic semantic shifts between 2010 and 2017 are marked by the growing use of word embeddings, the influential Google Books Ngrams corpus, and significant research leveraging prediction-based models and varied datasets to effectively identify semantic changes over time.

Reasoning programs can significantly improve the retrieval of relevant evidence from knowledge sources in open-domain settings [9].  Iterative step-by-step retrieval, as implemented in ProgramFC, surpasses the traditional one-step BM25 retrieval method, demonstrating enhanced performance across various datasets. ![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval in recall across different datasets.](image3) This improvement is particularly noticeable in complex scenarios, such as HOVER 4-hop, where ProgramFC achieves a substantial 37.1% increase in recall [10]. This advantage arises because the iterative nature of ProgramFC’s retrieval process uncovers information that might be missed in the initial claim but becomes crucial during the reasoning stages [10].

ProgramFC demonstrates superior retrieval recall compared to one-step retrieval across different tasks, especially for complex reasoning scenarios.

To create the SnapNTell dataset, a meticulous filtering process was employed to ensure the quality and relevance of the entities included. Initially, a broad spectrum of entities across 22 primary categories was compiled [1, 2]. This initial list underwent a crucial filtering stage where each entity was verified against Wikipedia, and those lacking valid pages were removed, ensuring a baseline level of notability and information availability [1, 6].  Subsequently, a further filter was applied based on the availability of images; entities without a sufficient number of images from the Google Image Search API were also excluded, guaranteeing a visually rich dataset [1, 6].  ![This image shows a diagram illustrating the process of obtaining images for the dataset, starting from a Google image query and ending with human filtering to ensure Creative Commons licenses.](image1) This multi-stage filtering refined the dataset to 7,568 entities, focusing on those with substantial real-world presence and visual representation [1].  ![This image is a table showing the statistics of the entity dataset filtering process, listing "1st Wiki filtering", "2nd Google filtering", and "3rd Wiki filtering" as distinct stages.](image3)  The filtering process involved initial Wikipedia verification, followed by Google Image Search image availability checks, and potentially a third Wikipedia filtering for ambiguous entity names.

The main steps in the filtering process are Wikipedia verification, Google Image Search availability check, and ambiguous entity name removal.

Data imbalance is a prevalent issue in NLP, particularly in tasks like machine reading comprehension [9]. Even in comparison to other reading comprehension datasets like SQuAD 1.1 and SQuAD 2.0, which have ratios of 55.9 and 82.0 respectively as depicted in ![Table showing datasets and their negative to positive ratios](image2), QUOREF's ratio remains substantially greater. In conclusion, the QUOREF dataset has a significantly larger negative to positive instance ratio compared to other datasets mentioned.

The SPECTER model's performance is notably affected by the inclusion or exclusion of specific metadata fields during input processing. Removing the abstract as a textual input and relying solely on the title leads to a considerable decline in overall performance, as seen in the ablation study [10].  This observation is further supported by the performance metrics illustrated in the table, where the removal of the abstract results in a decrease in the average metric score. ![Removing the abstract from SPECTER's input text causes a significant drop in performance across tasks](image4). Surprisingly, incorporating authors as additional input, alongside the title and abstract, negatively impacts the model's performance [10]. This could be attributed to the sparsity of author names within the corpus, which complicates the model's ability to infer document relatedness effectively, and potential suboptimal tokenization of author names [10].  In contrast, adding venue information as input causes a slight decrease in performance across most tasks, except for document classification, where a marginal improvement is observed [10].  The performance variations across different feature sets highlights the sensitivity of the SPECTER model to input feature selection, and suggests that carefully choosing relevant metadata is crucial for optimizing its effectiveness. In summary, the inclusion or exclusion of metadata features such as abstracts, authors, and venues significantly modulates the performance of the SPECTER model across various tasks.

For slots like 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by', which are time-related, span-based methods like DS-DST and DS-Span struggle because the ground truth values are often not explicitly mentioned as spans in the dialogue context [10].  This is highlighted in error analysis where these slots are identified as problematic for span matching approaches [10]. In contrast, DS-Picklist, which leverages candidate-value lists, demonstrates a significant advantage in predicting these slot values because it's not solely reliant on span extraction [10].

The performance disparity is evident when examining slot-level accuracy, particularly for 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by'.  ![Table showing slot-level accuracy comparison for DS-DST and DS-Picklist, highlighting 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by' performance](image4). As depicted in the table, DS-DST achieves 0.00% accuracy for 'taxi-leave at' and 9.60% for 'train-arrive by', while DS-Picklist significantly improves these figures to 43.84% and 79.20% respectively for the same slots. This substantial difference underscores that DS-Picklist, by using a full ontology, can better handle slots where values are not directly extractable from dialogue spans.

In summary, DS-Picklist outperforms DS-DST for 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by' slots due to its ability to utilize candidate-value lists when span matching fails to capture the ground truth values from the dialogue context.

The Grammarly's Yahoo Answers Formality Corpus (GYAFC) is derived from Yahoo Answers, a question-answering forum known for its vast collection of informal sentences [3, 7]. To ensure data uniformity, sentences that are questions, contain URLs, or are too short or too long are removed [3]. The corpus consists of different domains, and formality levels can vary significantly across these domains [3]. To address this variation, the GYAFC dataset focuses on two specific domains, Entertainment & Music and Family & Relationships, which are identified as containing the most informal sentences [3].

![The table shows that across all of Yahoo Answers, there are 40 million sentences, of which 24 million are informal and 16 million are formal. In the Entertainment & Music domain, out of 3.8 million sentences, 2.7 million are informal and 700K are formal. For Family & Relationships, out of 7.8 million sentences, 5.6 million are informal and 1.8 million are formal.](image4)

These two domains, Entertainment & Music and Family & Relationships, were selected because they exhibit the highest concentration of informal sentences within the Yahoo Answers corpus [3]. The distribution of informal and formal entries in Yahoo Answers varies across different domains, with Entertainment & Music and Family & Relationships containing a higher proportion of informal content compared to the overall Yahoo Answers distribution.

Initially, the BERT model achieved a peak test accuracy of $77\%$ on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT), a result surprisingly close to the average human baseline [1, 5].  However, this seemingly strong performance is misleading as it's attributed to BERT's exploitation of dataset-specific statistical cues rather than genuine argument comprehension [1, 6].  In fact, examining different input configurations reveals that considering only warrants (W) allows BERT to reach $71\%$ accuracy, with further gains from reasons (R, W) and claims (C, W) accounting for the remaining percentage points [2, 6].

![BERT's test performance varies across different configurations, showing different accuracy levels for BERT and its configurations with warrants (W), reasons and warrants (R, W), and claims and warrants (C, W).](image1)

The table illustrates how BERT's test performance changes when different input components are used. To eliminate these spurious cues, an adversarial dataset was constructed [3].  When models, including BERT, are trained and evaluated on this adversarial dataset, the performance significantly drops.  Specifically, BERT's peak performance reduces to $53\%$ on this dataset, with mean and median accuracies around $50\%$ [3, 7].

![BERT's test performance on the adversarial dataset is substantially lower and consistently near random accuracy across different configurations, indicating the removal of exploitable cues.](image4)

This drastic reduction in performance on the adversarial dataset demonstrates that BERT's initial high accuracy was not indicative of true argument understanding but rather a result of learning and exploiting statistical biases within the original dataset [7, 9].  Thus, BERT's test performance varies significantly across different configurations and dataset types, highlighting its reliance on spurious cues for achieving high accuracy on the original ARCT dataset.

The performance metrics of GPT-4 and ChatGPT show interesting variations when evaluated under general and specific question settings.  It's observed that models generally perform better on specific questions compared to general ones [9]. This is because specific questions offer clearer guidance, directing the models towards the relevant knowledge needed for answering [9].  For instance, in citation evaluation, GPT-4 achieves a higher Alignment score of 92.0 under specific settings compared to 90.9 in general settings, and ChatGPT also shows improvement from 82.7 to 84.5 in Alignment when moving from general to specific questions as seen in the table ![Comparison of Citation and Text Evaluation Metrics for General and Specific Settings](image5).

Looking at detailed metrics, both GPT-4 and ChatGPT exhibit enhanced Correctness, Precision, Recall, and F1-scores under specific question settings in citation evaluation.  GPT-4's F1-score increases from 35.6 to 39.4, while ChatGPT's F1-score rises from 32.9 to 37.2 in specific settings.  The alignment scores also reflect this trend, with ChatGPT achieving an alignment score of 84.5 in human evaluations, as opposed to lower scores for models like LLaMA-7B and Vicuna-13B, highlighting the superior text-citation alignment capabilities of the OpenAI models ![Human evaluation of alignment scores across different models](image1).  The table below further breaks down the performance metrics, showing that GPT-4 consistently outperforms ChatGPT across most metrics, and both models show improvement in performance metrics like Alignment and Correctness when assessed with specific questions ![Detailed performance metrics including Alignment, Correctness, Precision, Recall, and F1-score for GPT-4 and ChatGPT](image3).

In text quality evaluation, a similar trend is observed. Both GPT-4 and ChatGPT achieve higher scores in metrics like Coherence, Consistency, Fluency, and Relevance when responding to specific questions compared to general questions, as highlighted in the citation and text evaluation metrics table ![Comparison of Citation and Text Evaluation Metrics for General and Specific Settings](image5).  This indicates that the clarity and focus provided by specific questions not only improve citation quality but also enhance the overall quality of the generated text.  Generally, OpenAI models, including GPT-4 and ChatGPT, demonstrate superior text quality compared to models like LLaMA, as they maintain high consistency in text generation [10].  However, it's important to note that there is still room for improvement for all models in achieving higher micro F1 Scores, as none exceed 40, suggesting ongoing challenges in fully leveraging knowledge graphs for attribution [8].

In conclusion, both GPT-4 and ChatGPT demonstrate improved performance in citation and text evaluation when responding to specific questions compared to general questions, indicating that question specificity plays a crucial role in eliciting better quality and more accurate responses from these models.

RAG model evaluations often consider quality scores to assess their performance, and among these scores is answer faithfulness, which reflects the generator’s ability to produce responses that are consistent with the retrieved context [2, 3].  Evaluation frameworks like RAGAS and TruLens explicitly include faithfulness as a metric for assessing generation quality, alongside other metrics such as context relevance and answer relevance, as part of a comprehensive evaluation approach ![RAGAS and TruLens evaluation frameworks include faithfulness as a metric for generation quality](image1).  Furthermore, faithfulness can be assessed using metrics such as Accuracy and potentially other measures related to answer quality like EM and ROUGE scores, depending on the evaluation context and task, highlighting the multifaceted nature of evaluating faithfulness in RAG systems ![Faithfulness is related to metrics like Accuracy, EM and ROUGE scores in RAG evaluation](image2). In conclusion, metrics like Accuracy, EM, and ROUGE are utilized to evaluate the faithfulness aspect in RAG models.

Large language models, especially those trained with multiple modalities, face challenges related to norm growth during training, potentially leading to divergence [2]. To address this, Query-Key Normalization (QK-Norm) is introduced to control the norm growth by applying layer normalization to query and key vectors within the attention mechanism [7]. The effectiveness of QK-Norm is highlighted in the context of Chameleon models, where it plays an essential role in stable training [6].

![Llama-1, Llama-2, and Chameleon models have different configurations, and QK-norm is not applied in Llama-1 and Llama-2 but applied in Chameleon.](image3)

As shown in the architecture comparison, Llama-1 does not employ QK-Norm, unlike Chameleon which utilizes it as a key component.

The single-paragraph BERT model's effectiveness in open-domain questions is notably influenced by the paragraph retrieval process [2].  Even when provided with a substantial number of 500 retrieved paragraphs, the model's performance is limited, achieving an F1 score of 39.12 [2]. However, the F1 score significantly improves to 53.12 when supplemented with additional gold paragraphs, highlighting the crucial role of successful gold paragraph retrieval [2]. This information is also visually summarized, showing the F1 score in the open-domain setting with 500 paragraphs and with added gold paragraphs ![This image displays a table showing F1 scores for different settings, including "Open-domain 500 Paragraphs" with an F1 score of 39.12 and "+ Gold Paragraph" with 53.12.](image4).  In the setting with 500 open-domain paragraphs, the single-paragraph BERT model achieves an F1 score of 39.12.

Deep learning models have greatly advanced sequence labeling, achieving state-of-the-art results through network structures such as LSTM and CNN [2]. It's observed that models employing CNN for word sequence representation typically underperform compared to those using LSTM, which demonstrates LSTM's superior ability to capture global features [3]. However, incorporating character information can notably boost model performance.  The table detailing feature performance reveals that both human-defined features like POS tags and capital indicators enhance NER system performance [5].

![Table 2 shows that the feature combination "+CCNN" achieves the highest F-score.](image2)

Furthermore, automatic feature extractors, such as CNN for character sequences, can lead to even better performance [6].  As shown in Table 2, the "+CCNN" feature combination achieves the highest F-score.

The single-paragraph BERT model processes each paragraph independently to generate scores and answers. It evaluates each paragraph individually, as depicted in the model architecture diagram ![Model architecture showing individual paragraph processing and answer selection](image2). After processing all paragraphs, the model selects the answer from the paragraph that receives the best score [8]. Specifically, the answer is chosen from the paragraph that has the smallest $y_{\mathrm{emptysety}}$ score [10]. In essence, the model selects the answer from the paragraph it deems most likely to contain the correct information.

The baseline performance on MuSiQue and StrategyQA benchmarks for models like PaLM-2L and GPT-4 is relatively low, particularly on MuSiQue which is a challenging multi-hop reasoning task [9]. As shown in ![Performance of various methods on MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets](image3), PaLM-2L achieves 35.5% and GPT-4 scores 38.5% on MuSiQue, while on StrategyQA, the baselines are stronger with PaLM-2L at 82.8% and GPT-4 at 78.3% [9].  Traditional prompting methods like Chain of Thought (CoT) and Take a Deep Breathe (TDB) offer only marginal improvements, especially on StrategyQA, possibly due to the already high baseline performance [9]. Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) enhances performance on both tasks, but the combination of Step-Back prompting with RAG significantly elevates the accuracy to 42.8% on MuSiQue and 86.4% on StrategyQA, outperforming GPT-4 in both scenarios [9]. Step-Back prompting, leveraging abstraction, proves to be a powerful technique, especially when combined with RAG, for complex reasoning tasks like MuSiQue and StrategyQA. In summary, Step-Back prompting combined with RAG significantly improves performance on MuSiQue and StrategyQA compared to baseline models and other prompting methods like CoT, TDB, and RAG alone.

The TRADE model demonstrates remarkable capabilities in zero-shot dialogue state tracking, showcasing its ability to perform effectively in unseen domains [10]. In zero-shot experiments across different domains, the taxi domain stands out by achieving the highest joint goal accuracy, reaching 60.58% [9]. This performance is notably close to the result obtained when training on the entire taxi domain dataset [9].

![Table comparing Trained Single and Zero-Shot Joint Slot accuracy for different domains](image5)

The superior zero-shot performance in the taxi domain is attributed to the similarity of its slot values with those in the train domain [9]. This suggests that knowledge transfer is more effective when domains share common semantic features.  While other zero-shot domains do not reach the same level of joint goal accuracy, they still achieve a slot accuracy ranging from approximately 50% to 65% without relying on any in-domain training samples [9]. In conclusion, the taxi domain achieved the highest zero-shot joint accuracy due to the similarities in slot values with the train domain.

Step-Back Prompting is a technique designed to enhance the reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) by enabling them to abstract high-level concepts and principles from specific instances [6]. In fact, experiments conducted on MMLU Physics demonstrated that Step-Back Prompting notably improves the performance of PaLM-2L models [9]. ![Table showing performance of PaLM-2L and PaLM-2L + Step-Back on MMLU Physics and Chemistry](image4)

RAPTOR employs two distinct querying methods: tree traversal and collapsed tree, to navigate its multi-layered tree structure for information retrieval [4].  The collapsed tree method simplifies search by considering all nodes simultaneously, effectively flattening the tree for comparison [5]. In contrast, the tree traversal method proceeds layer by layer, pruning and selecting relevant nodes at each level [1, 8].

The performance of these methods has been evaluated, revealing that the collapsed tree approach consistently outperforms tree traversal [6]. This superior performance is attributed to the greater flexibility of collapsed tree, which allows it to retrieve information at the most appropriate level of granularity for a given query by searching all nodes at once [6].  Figure 3 visually compares the performance of both tree traversal and collapsed tree methods across varying context lengths, highlighting the F1 score for each method as context length changes. ![Figure 3 shows that Collapsed tree consistently performs better than Tree Traversal across different context lengths](image3).

In summary, the collapsed tree method demonstrates a better F1 score compared to tree traversal across different context lengths.

Logic-LM is a framework developed to enhance logical reasoning in Large Language Models (LLMs) by incorporating symbolic solvers, aiming to overcome the limitations LLMs face with complex logical problems [6]. The performance of Logic-LM, especially when utilizing GPT-4 as its foundation, can be evaluated across several datasets, as detailed in the provided performance comparison ![Performance comparison of Logic-LM, Standard LLMs, and CoT with GPT-4 as the base model](image4).  When examining the results for GPT-4, it's evident that Logic-LM demonstrates superior accuracy compared to both Standard LLMs and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting in four datasets: ProofWriter, FOLIO, LogicalDeduction, and AR-LSAT.  For example, on the ProofWriter dataset, Logic-LM attains an accuracy of 79.66%, outperforming Standard LLMs at 52.67% and CoT at 68.11% [image4].  Similarly, Logic-LM consistently shows better performance than both baselines in the FOLIO, LogicalDeduction, and AR-LSAT datasets [image4].  However, in the ProntoQA dataset, although Logic-LM (83.20%) does surpass Standard LLMs (77.40%), it does not exceed the performance of CoT prompting, which achieves 98.79% [image4]. Consequently, Logic-LM, with GPT-4 as the base model, outperforms both standard LLMs and CoT in four out of the five datasets considered. In conclusion, Logic-LM outperforms both baseline models in four datasets when GPT-4 is used as the base language model.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself by offering a comprehensive evaluation of multimodal understanding and reasoning, specifically tailored for college-level knowledge across diverse disciplines [10].  Unlike previous benchmarks which often concentrate on daily scenarios and common sense, MMMU broadens its scope to encompass 11.5K questions spanning six disciplines and 30 subjects, incorporating 183 subfields, thus achieving a significant breadth of knowledge assessment [2, 10]. The benchmark’s scale is visually represented in the provided statistics, highlighting its extensive question count and diverse subject coverage ![MMMU benchmark encompasses 11550 questions across 6 disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields with 30 image types](image4).

Furthermore, MMMU is designed to test deeper reasoning capabilities, moving beyond simple commonsense or temporal reasoning typical of earlier benchmarks [2]. It challenges models to apply expert-level reasoning and subject-specific knowledge, as illustrated by tasks requiring understanding of "Fourier Transform" or "Equilibrium Theory" [4, 10].  In contrast to benchmarks focused on simpler visual question answering or common visual scenes, MMMU incorporates 30 different image formats, including complex diagrams, charts, and even music sheets, demanding advanced perceptual skills from models [2, 8]. The comparative landscape of benchmarks, including MMMU, in terms of knowledge breadth and reasoning depth, is visualized, positioning MMMU as requiring both extensive knowledge and significant reasoning depth compared to benchmarks like VQA and GQA ![MMMU benchmark emphasizes both breadth of knowledge and depth of reasoning compared to other benchmarks](image5).

In summary, the MMMU benchmark stands out from others due to its larger dataset size, wider variety of image types, and greater emphasis on in-depth, college-level reasoning.

Based on the experimental setup described, different sources of supervision data were utilized to train the model [6]. To evaluate the impact of each source, experiments were conducted by systematically removing one source at a time and observing the resulting performance changes, as detailed in Table 4 [10].  This table, visualized in `![Table 4 shows the performance breakdown for different supervision data sources on the development set, particularly focusing on the Ultra-Fine category](image1)`,  clearly illustrates how removing "Crowd" or "Head" supervision leads to a decrease in the F1 score for the Ultra-Fine category, from 14.6 to 8.4 and 8.5 respectively. Interestingly, removing Entity Linking ("-EL") appears to slightly *increase* the F1 score to 16.0.  These results suggest that while both crowdsourced data and head word supervision are beneficial for predicting ultra-fine labels, entity linking's role may be less straightforward or even slightly detrimental in this context [9].

Excluding crowdsourced data or head word supervision negatively impacts the model's Ultra-Fine category performance, while removing entity linking seems to have a slightly positive or negligible effect.

To effectively prepare for the LinkedIn Recruiter Certification exam, candidates should concentrate on key areas throughout the entire recruiting lifecycle, encompassing skills from initiating a search to effectively managing talent pipelines [1]. A crucial aspect of this is mastering the art of searching the network, which includes understanding how to construct precise Boolean search strings, a skill still fundamental even with advancements in next-generation recruiter tools [1, 7].  This skill is directly relevant to efficiently identifying and engaging talent.

![The exam focuses on building talent pipelines, engaging talent, posting jobs and maximizing LinkedIn Recruiter efficiency.](image1)

The exam emphasizes the practical application of LinkedIn Recruiter features, ensuring certified professionals can leverage the platform's full potential for efficient and collaborative recruiting [3].  Understanding Boolean search logic, often visualized through Venn diagrams, is essential for refining search queries and accurately targeting candidate pools [8]. For instance, a search string like "Engineering AND Java NOT Manager" [6] can be better understood and adjusted using Venn diagrams to visualize the overlapping and exclusive sets of search terms. Mastering talent pipeline features is also vital, allowing recruiters to efficiently re-engage candidates for reopened roles [2, 5].  Ultimately, the certification aims to validate a recruiter's foundational skills in utilizing LinkedIn Recruiter for the entire recruiting process, ensuring they can adapt to evolving business demands and effectively display job opportunities [9].

![Boolean search logic is related to Venn diagram.](image2)

Therefore, candidates need to focus on mastering search functionalities including Boolean logic and talent pipeline management for the LinkedIn Recruiter Certification exam.

Bergen and the surrounding area are located in the heart of the world-renowned fjords, making it a central hub for fjord exploration [1]. The Sognefjord, which is celebrated as Norway's longest and deepest fjord, is easily accessible from Bergen [10]. The Nærøyfjord, a particularly narrow branch of the Sognefjord, stands out as a UNESCO World Heritage site due to its unique beauty [9].  The Hardangerfjord, often referred to as the "Queen of the Fjords", is another prominent fjord in the vicinity of Bergen [8]. These fjords, along with others found in Nordhordland, are situated between Bergen and the Sognefjord, presenting a landscape of untouched natural beauty [3]. The region's significance is further emphasized by its UNESCO World Heritage status, nestled between the Sognefjord and the Hardangerfjord [5].

The notable fjords indicated are the Sognefjord, including Nærøyfjord, and the Hardangerfjord, all positioned around Bergen and extending into regions such as Nordhordland and Vestland.

To fulfill the course requirements, several key areas are involved, starting with ensuring adequate English proficiency, especially for international students from non-English speaking universities, who are mandated to take the Diagnostic English Test (DET) [1]. The outcome of this test is crucial as it determines whether a student needs to enroll in the Graduate English Course (GEC) or can be exempted [image1], highlighting the importance of this assessment for appropriate placement in language support modules. Furthermore, the curriculum includes a substantial coursework component, requiring a minimum of 30 Modular Credits (MCs) [image5]. This coursework is structured around compulsory ISEP courses like GS6001, ES5002, and GS6883A, alongside other modules approved by the supervisor and ISEP, all typically at the 5000 or 6000 level [image5]. Interestingly, prior NUS modules, if unused for another degree and completed recently, might be eligible for credit transfer, potentially reducing the coursework load [2, 4].
![Coursework and lab rotations are key components of the program.](image5)
Beyond coursework, laboratory rotations are a fundamental aspect, with new students expected to complete two rotations under ISEP-approved supervisors within their initial four months [image5]. These rotations, each lasting around two months, precede the formal nomination of a Main Supervisor [10], and are integral to the GS5101 Research Immersion Module [8]. Adding to these academic engagements, students are also expected to participate in a workshop scheduled around September or October [5].
![The DET result determines the need for Graduate English Course.](image1)
In summary, the course requirements encompass four main areas: English language proficiency, academic coursework, laboratory rotations, and workshop participation.

Bergen offers a diverse array of attractions catering to various visitor interests, from cultural experiences to natural wonders. For art enthusiasts, the Bergen Kunsthall stands out as a centre for contemporary art, hosting exhibitions and events by international artists and offering live events like concerts and club nights [2]. History buffs can step back in time at the Old Bergen Museum, a living museum reconstructing Bergen's past with original wooden buildings and a beautiful park [3].  The city also celebrates its maritime heritage at the Bergen Maritime Museum, showcasing the development of shipping from the Viking Age to the present day with boats, models, and paintings [4].

For those seeking natural beauty and panoramic views, taking the cable car to Mount Ulriken provides a fantastic landscape and unique culinary experiences at Sky sk rape ren Restaurant [5].  Alternatively, a trip up to Mount Fløyen also rewards visitors with stunning views of the city, fjord, and ocean [7]. Families will find numerous engaging options, such as the Bergen Aquarium, home to diverse creatures from around the world, including seals and penguins, with daily feeding sessions and a cinema [9].  ![Bergen Aquarium provides accessible and family-friendly facilities, open year-round and offering shopping options, and accepting the Bergen Card.](image9).  The VilVite Science Centre offers interactive exploration of science and technology for families [7].  For a unique and insightful experience, the Storeblå Aquaculture Visitor Centre provides a comprehensive look into Norwegian aquaculture, including a RIB boat trip to a fish farm [6]. Lastly, for shopping and leisure, Vestkanten is a large centre offering a water park, spa, bowling, and various shops and restaurants [10].  The Fish Market in Bergen is a must-visit for food lovers, offering seafood delicacies and local specialties [8].

Bergen's tourist attractions are diverse, catering to art lovers, history enthusiasts, nature seekers, families, and those interested in unique experiences and local culture.

Bergen boasts several museums that offer a glimpse into its rich historical and cultural heritage. For a nostalgic experience, the Old Bergen Museum presents a meticulously reconstructed Bergen from the 19th and 20th centuries, featuring around 50 original wooden buildings, an English-style park, and even a seawater pool [1].  This living museum provides a unique window into the past [2]. To delve into the very origins of Bergen, Bryggens Museum at the UNESCO World Heritage site Bryggen is essential. Here, one can explore the ruins of the city’s first town hall hidden below street level and wander through the iconic wooden buildings of Bryggen, concluding at the Schøtstuene assembly rooms [3].  If you wish to understand life in the countryside surrounding Bergen, the Osterøy Museum showcases old buildings in a beautiful cultural landscape, illustrating rural life through storytelling, textiles, costumes, weaving, and local building customs [4].  For a different facet of Bergen's heritage, Salhus Tricotagefabrik, a textile factory dating back to 1859, reveals the history of the textile industry in Western Norway and demonstrates how wool is transformed into clothing [5]. To experience royal history, Haakon’s Hall, a 13th-century royal banqueting hall and the largest building of the royal residency, stands as a national cultural heritage site, offering a glimpse into the life of a king in the Middle Ages [6].  For those interested in art, KODE Art Museums of Bergen, which is also labeled as BERGEN ![BERGEN](image4), houses Norway’s second biggest art collection across four museums, displaying art and design from the 15th century to the present, including works by renowned artists like Munch and Picasso, with a dedicated KunstLab for children [7, 10].  Bergen's oldest Latin School, dating from 1706, the oldest school building in Norway, presents exhibitions on the Norwegian school system and society from the Middle Ages to today [8]. Lastly, for a unique island experience, Herdla museum on an island west of Bergen, delves into its dramatic role in World War II, its diverse fauna and birdlife, and features a German fighter aircraft from WWII [9].

These museums collectively highlight Bergen's diverse historical and cultural heritage, each with its own unique focus and features.

To achieve the best possible wash quality, it is important to load the dishwasher correctly, ensuring that items such as cups, glasses, and pots are placed facing downwards [5]. This orientation allows water to effectively run off curved or recessed items [9].  Load hollow items downwards to prevent water collection, and make sure all items are stacked securely so they cannot tip over and that the spray arms can rotate freely [9].

![Cups, saucers, glasses, mugs and bowls are placed in the dishwasher](image4)

For optimal cleaning, place larger and heavily soiled items in the lower basket, as depicted with pots and various plates [6]. It is preferable to load the lower basket first, followed by the upper one [4].

![Oven pot, dessert plates, dinner plates, soup plates, oval platter, melamine dessert plates, melamine bowls and small pot are placed in the dishwasher](image1)

The upper basket is best suited for more delicate and lighter dishware like glasses and cups [9].  Cutlery should also be carefully arranged; for instance, long knives should be placed horizontally in the upper basket to avoid hazards [9], while other cutlery items can be organized as shown [9].

![Soup spoons, forks, knives, tea spoons, dessert spoons, serving spoons, serving fork and gravy ladle are placed in the dishwasher](image2)

It is crucial not to overload the dishwasher to maintain good washing results and energy efficiency [9].  Failure to comply with proper loading practices can lead to poor washing quality, as highlighted in the warning [3].

![Non compliance with the loading can result to poor washing quality](image3)

In conclusion, optimal dishwasher loading involves placing larger, heavily soiled items in the lower basket and delicate items in the upper basket, orienting items downwards, correctly positioning cutlery, and avoiding overloading to ensure effective washing.

To apply for a Student's Pass, you should be aware of several fees. There is a Processing Fee which is non-refundable, an Issuance Fee, and a Multiple-Entry Visa fee which applies to nationals requiring a visa ![Fees associated with Student's Pass application including processing and issuance fees](image2).  Additionally, a replacement fee is imposed if the Student’s Pass is lost or stolen, and amendments to the application after submission will incur a processing fee [9]. It is also important to note that healthcare in Singapore can be costly, and hospitals may require a significant deposit upon admission [6]. Therefore, when budgeting for your Student's Pass and stay in Singapore, factor in these various fees. In conclusion, applying for a Student's Pass in Singapore involves processing, issuance, and potentially visa fees, along with possible replacement or amendment fees, and consideration of healthcare costs.

Thermal impedance information is available for various parts and packages, though it's noted that these values are approximations under static air conditions at 1W power dissipation and will vary with operating conditions [7]. To compare the thermal resistance between the 8051AH and 8751BH, we can refer to the provided table which lists thermal resistance values for different part prefixes and package types.  For the 8051AH in a 40-Pin Plastic DIP package, the junction-to-ambient thermal resistance is 45°C/W, and the junction-to-case thermal resistance is 16°C/W. In contrast, the 8751BH in the same 40-Pin Plastic DIP package has a junction-to-ambient thermal resistance of 36°C/W and a junction-to-case thermal resistance of 12°C/W.

![Thermal resistance values for different 8051 family parts are listed in the table.](image2)

The 8751BH part exhibits lower thermal resistance compared to the 8051AH part in the specified package.

For new students at NTU looking to manage their finances and stay connected, setting up a bank account and mobile phone service are important considerations. If your study period is six months or longer, you might want to open a bank account in Singapore, as banks offer various services tailored to student needs [2].  As part of your registration procedures, opening a bank account is listed as a step if your study duration exceeds six months [4]. You can consider banks such as Development Bank of Singapore (DBS), Overseas-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC), POSBank, and United Overseas Bank Ltd (UOB), all of which are listed with their contact details and websites for your convenience ![List of bank names, websites and contact numbers](image5).  OCBC bank even has a branch right on the NTU campus at the North Spine, Block N3, making it easily accessible, and other banks are located near NTU at Jurong Point Shopping Centre [7].

For communication needs, purchasing a Singapore mobile line is optional but can be very useful [4]. You can sign up for a mobile line at Jurong Point Shopping Centre or even at convenience stores [6]. Singapore has three main telecommunication companies you could consider: M1, SingTel, and StarHub ![logos of Singapore telecommunication companies with their websites](image2). Purchasing a mobile line and opening a bank account are part of the practical steps to get settled at NTU.

In summary, to set up a bank account at NTU, students studying for more than six months should consider visiting banks like DBS, OCBC, POSBank, or UOB, and for mobile service, they can explore plans from M1, SingTel, or StarHub.

To accurately adjust the strap size of your smartwatch, begin by measuring your wrist circumference using the ruler that comes with the watch, positioning it about two fingers away from your palm [3]. Ensure the watch body is centered on the back of your wrist, below the ulnar styloid process, and not too close to or far from it to guarantee measurement accuracy [6].  After measurement, choose the appropriate strap size [2] and start by opening both the watch buckle and the airbag buckle [7].  Then, proceed to adjust the strap according to your wrist's circumference [9]. To finalize the adjustment, securely fasten the airbag buckle [5].  Properly adjusting the strap ensures a comfortable and accurate fit based on your wrist size.
